webTitle: Refugee doctors to help ease NHS staff crisis

fields.headline: Refugee doctors to help ease NHS staff crisis
fields.standfirst: An estimated 2,000 qualified doctors are registered as refugees in Britain. Retraining them could help solve NHS staffing problems, say ministers.
fields.trailText: The government has announced an initiative to smooth the path for thousands of medically qualified refugees to fill jobs in the NHS.
fields.body:
A government initiative to smooth the path for thousands of medically qualified refugees to fill jobs in the NHS was announced yesterday.

The plan includes drawing up a database of refugees qualified as healthcare professionals and want to retrain to work in the health service.

The health minister, John Denham, said an estimated 2,000 qualified doctors were registered as refugees in Britain. Helping them to retrain could help solve NHS staffing problems, he said. The initiative - started with a £500,000 grant - will be extended shortly.

The database will concentrate on qualified doctors and dentists but will eventually encompass other healthcare professions like radiography and occupational therapy.

Mr Denham said: "It makes fundamental sense for us to enable refugees with medical skills to work in the NHS.

"We are of course training thousands more doctors, nurses and other healthcare professionals but it takes at least six years to train a doctor.

"During that time there may be as many as 2,000 refugees in this country who have already qualified as doctors abroad.

The initiative was unveiled alongside a Home Office strategy to help refugees rebuild their lives in Britain.

fields.headline: Pension cut challenged in court
fields.standfirst: Special report: human rights in the UK
fields.trailText: Age Concern yesterday launched a test case against the government in the European court of human rights challenging a loss of benefit for millions of pensioners under the state earnings related scheme.
fields.body:
Age Concern yesterday launched a test case against the government in the European court of human rights challenging a loss of benefit for millions of pensioners under the state earnings related scheme.

Gordon Lishman, the charity's director general, said it was reluctantly taking the first such action in its 60-year history to protect people who had done their best to save for retirement.

The case is being brought on behalf of a retired sales director, aged 71, from Surrey who receives £73 a week under the state earnings related pension scheme.

Under the original scheme, introduced in 1978, his wife would have continued to receive the full £73 after he died. That is about to be cut to £36.50.

Legislation in 1986 halved the entitlement for those whose spouses died after April 2000. But the government did not correct its leaflets until 1996 and benefit agency staff continued to give out incorrect information until April last year.

In March the government delayed introduction of the scheme until October 2002 and offered to compensate people who could show they were misinformed.

Age Concern said it was unfair to penalise widows and widowers who were unaware of the changes.

The case is being brought in the names of Mr and Mrs F, who contacted the benefits agency before Mr F's retirement, but were not told the changes would affect the pension Mrs F would inherit. The couple are claiming the government contravenedthe European convention on human rights guaranteeing peaceful enjoyment of possessions.

webTitle: Comment: NHS and the winter crisis

fields.headline: Being patient
fields.standfirst: The NHS is working hard to avert a winter crisis, but it is the social services that we need to look out for
fields.trailText: The NHS is planning with military efficiency to try to avert the annual NHS winter crisis. But are all social services departments doing their bit, asks Polly Toynbee
fields.body:
The clear and present danger for the government is the fuel protest. But hard on its heels comes the annual NHS winter crisis, as certain as the solstice. Often it is flammed up in the thin news time between Christmas and New Year, but last year on top of the millennium there was a genuine flu crisis. Now extraordinary measures with carrots and sticks are ready to try to stop it happening again, just before an election.

The BBC's Today programme got off the mark a bit early this week with one of its regular winter surveys on how things are going in health authorities. Having done these myself in my time at the BBC, they are usually a sure fire hit as a story: not this time. Some 90% of health authorities said they were in a better position to deal with winter pressures than last year. These surveys take a long time to do, and it must be galling to get no headline at the end of it. So instead of leading with this key fact, they stuck it down at the bottom of their report and even said that the department of health "claimed" the 90% result, when in fact it was their own survey that "found" it. Downing Street rebutted sharply - and rightly. But all this is just a small taste of what is to come: if that's the BBC, wait for the Tory press to splash with any patient who gets less than the best in any hospital. The NHS is the frontline in the run-up to an election: truth is always the first casualty.

The Tories are sharpening their knives and in some places this is starting to take a sinister turn as national politics are being played out locally over the home care, hospital beds and nursing homes for ill old people. The aim under all governments of the last 20 years has been to try to force the NHS and local social services to pool funds and work together to stop hospital beds being filled up with frail old people who have no need of very expensive acute care. Local teams of social services domiciliary care workers together with community nurses and GPs try to keep them at home, catching early signs of flu before it turns into pneumonia. Finding nursing homes to move the frailest into is a growing problem, but gradually the two sides have been working better together. However, suddenly a new political motivation rears its head.

Many councils that were formerly Labour have switched to Tory control. Why should Tory councils direct money and effort towards relieving any possible winter chaos on the NHS? The winter planning group inside the Department of Health is getting messages back that there is suddenly far less cooperation as Tory-controlled social services are drained of cash for the old. Some members of the Association of Directors of Social Services confirm that they think there has been a deliberate moving of funds away from services for the old by some Tory-led councils this winter.

The Labour group in Essex where the Tories took control question what is happening to social services there. Under the leadership of Lord Hanningfield, ennobled by William Hague, £2m was slashed from social services and council tax was cut. By August, in financial meltdown after the tax cuts, they set up a team to report on future cuts. It is not due to report until the end of November, just when the old-and-cold winter care season begins. The fear is that a massive round of new cuts will strike just as the local NHS will be expecting help from social services. Bungling inefficiency, no doubt. But once in a squeeze, there is not (to put it at its very mildest) a great political incentive to channel scarce funds into care for the elderly to stop bed-blocking in local hospitals. Similar reports are coming in from around the country, with a suggestion that Conservative central office is taking a keen interest.

However, to be fair, social services are under extreme pressure everywhere, in councils of all complexions. The chancellor ear-marked extra money for education and for children, but nothing for the frail old who are growing in number. A survey of social services two weeks ago found them badly strapped. If there is a winter crisis, the weakest point is here. For the NHS has had its largest dollop of cash for six years - a 7.4% increase. Talking to chief executives of health authorities, they say the money is there, buying more beds, more intensive care, more staff and - in a crisis - more treatment from the private sector. There are plenty of anxieties about lack of nurses - we are 30,000 short nationally - especially in rich areas where there is nowhere affordable for them to live. But broadly, most are not grumbling, which is news in itself.

So the winter plans are laid and the thumb-screws ready for any health authority that fails. Every area has its winter planning group, answerable daily to the winter emergency services team inside the department of health. The head of one local winter team describes how much pressure they are under: "It's been money with menaces, the political stakes are so high." There are calls almost daily from Whitehall. If any patient is left on a trolley waiting for a bed for more than 12 hours, the chief executive has to call the regional director, who calls Whitehall. Then, day or night, the chief executive must go in person to apologise humbly to the patient and the family. Last year this particular authority had to transfer patients needing intensive care a hundred miles away. "This year that would be career suicide." Inside the bunker in Whitehall early warning systems prepare to zap rapid response teams into any hotspot, with extra money and managers. They will bring extra GPs into Accident and Emergency. Ambulances are kept in minute by minute contact, directing them to hospitals with lowest waiting times. Any over-65s have been seized and flu-jabbed, along with NHS staff. Deals are struck with private hospitals to take cold surgery cases, so waiting lists don't fall behind. This is war.

But all is quite different inside the social services departments, though much will depend on them. They are not controlled by any central bunker. (The time may come.) They have had cuts, not increases. The Association of Social Services Directors says the south- east is hardest hit for services for the old, with no money to compensate for soaring costs. Old people with more capital now qualify for free care. Soon however rich, all will get three months free care and local social services will have to pay. The old live longer in their expensive nursing homes, costing more. Nursing homes are closing in the affluent south, as owners cash in on property values and staff are hard to find: 10,000 fewer nursing home places this year. The government needs to move fast to secure this missing link in its winter plans. It will be very difficult to prove that there are political shenanigans afoot in Tory-controlled councils deliberately provoking a winter crisis, when all social services are under genuinely critical pressure.

fields.headline: Boo rises from the ashes
fields.standfirst: Boo.com began with a splash, ended in tears and has risen again. The influence of Scorpio, however, won't make things easy.
fields.trailText: November 3: Scorpio could make things diffcult for Boo.com second time around, writes Media Medium Maggie Hyde.
fields.body:
Boo.com, the online global fashion and sports retailer, is the archetypal story of how not to do an internet start-up.

Its dramatic collapse last May coincided with the Jupiter-Saturn zeitgeist conjunction in square to high-tech Uranus. It marked an epochal moment in the birth pangs of the new economy (Uranus) and some very old economic lessons were learned (Jupiter-Saturn), such as the need for financial controls.

Fashionmail.com, a US portal, has acquired the name and relaunched Boo as a means of establishing a European foothold. It is no longer selling merchandise and aims to provide an entry point to global fashion retailers, manufacturers, catalogues and magazines. But will the new Boo fare any better?

The original site horoscope (November 3 1999) shows a status-hungry Scorpio, keen on sophistication and glamour. Mercury, the planet of trade and networking, is in fiery, jet-setting Sagittarius, in alignment with dreamy, druggy Neptune, planet of fashion and hype.

This is Boo, full of wild dreams, burning up advertising cash on champagne bashes for the fashion industry, boasting a multilingual Carnaby Street call centre. The air of fantasy is all-pervading, coupled with an unrealistic assessment of internet technology. Its much-delayed, 3D technology was so sophisticated that it crashed on most home PCs.

Boo's Virgo Moon refused to accept criticism, insisting it catered only to people with fast connections. After blowing £80m in six months, it had to end in tears.

The new Boo, launched with a slogan of "Style never dies", turns out to be another Scorpio (October 30, 2000). Scorpio, the sign of rebirth, is linked to the phoenix, the mythical bird rising from the ashes, and although in this incarnation there is less hype, there are some worrying astrological repetitions.

The technology shouldn't let it down again, but it doesn't look as if Boo will work second-time around. The fantasy line-up of Mercury and Neptune has become a tricky square, with Mercury moving retrograde - bad for communication and bad for trade.

Fashionmail.com has over-estimated the pulling-power of the Boo name, especially now that the glossy fashion magazines are getting web-wise about multi-platform branding. If it is to succeed, Boo will need to find a magic ingredient to make its site more intriguing and content-rich.

Email the Media Medium at maggie@companyguide.co.uk

webTitle: Interview with  Dominik Moll, creator of Harry, He's Here To Help

fields.headline: Angel of death
fields.standfirst: Ever wondered what it would be like to have someone sort out all the problems in your life by killing people?  Stuart Jeffries  meets Dominik Moll, creator of the surreal French hit Harry, He's Here To Help
fields.trailText: Ever wondered what it would be like to have someone sort out all the problems in your life by killing people? Stuart Jeffries meets Dominik Moll, creator of the surreal French hit Harry, He's Here To Help
fields.body:
At the start of Harry, He's Here To Help, a French family is driving down the motorway in a rotten car for their summer holiday. It's blisteringly hot, but there's no air conditioning. The three daughters in the back are screaming. One of them starts kicking the driver's seat so that the stressed father gets a royal pain in the small of his back.

We cut to Michel's sweaty, hangdog face, fringed by the kind of hairdo that that hasn't been popular since the Battle of Agincourt, and perhaps not even then. He's a ground-down thirtysomething who once dreamed of being a great writer but now teaches French at night school. He wanted to be happy and fulfilled but now he's driving down the Autoroute du Soleil to spend his holiday doing building work on the family's tumbledown farmhouse in the Auvergne which has become a source of stress and a drain on his money. How did he get this way? How can he change?

At a service station, he and his wife change the baby's nappy and Michel finds a man looking at him fixedly. The man is Harry, who claims to be an old school friend. Michel can't place him, but the man insists. In the car park they meet again. Harry and his girlfriend have a lovely Mercedes and they offer to drive his children to the farmhouse in air-conditioned splendour. Michel and his wife, Claire, agree so long as Claire travels in the Mercedes too.

We cut to Harry at the wheel. Harry's an enigma wrapped in top-of-the-range German air conditioning and backed by a soothing opera soundtrack from a state-of-the-art car stereo. Where did he come from? How did he become rich? Why does his girlfriend look like a pneumatic parody of Jean Harlow? Even his name is a puzzle: Harry isn't a common name in France. Not since the psycho killer in George Sluizer's The Vanishing has anyone quite so troubling hung around French service stations and insinuated themselves so disturbingly into other people's lives.

But Harry, even if he is a serial killer, comes not to bury Michel, but to praise him. Over dinner that evening, he recites from memory a poem Michel wrote for a school magazine nearly 20 years earlier. He clearly admires Michel, and wants him to return to his creative muse. And he's quite prepared to kill anybody who stands in Michel's way or upsets him. For instance, from the moment we see that Michel's overbearing parents have taken the liberty of installing a disgusting pink bathroom in his farmhouse without asking his permission, we know they are in trouble with Harry.

Harry is the psychoanalytical flipside to repressed Michel, who is incapable of standing up to his parents let alone taking hold of his destiny. But Harry is also - and this is what makes his character so interesting - the conscience of the film. He suffers for being an angel of vengeance for Michel. After one killing, he drives through the night howling wildly. He also eats a raw egg after each of his many orgasms during the film, but that's not important right now. In short, Harry's just the kind of stand-up friend a guy would want, but never has. At least in reality.

This disturbing, blackly comic suspense film has been a remarkable success in France, taking £10m since it was released at the start of August. But it should do well in Britain, too, since its dark humour is very attuned to our sick sensibilities.

Why has the film become one of the few pictures to keep the tricolour flying in the French box office charts this summer? The gangly, German-born director, Dominik Moll, takes a slug from his café créme and a pull on his cigarette. "It's difficult to analyse why it is a success. The film clearly touched a lot of people. It's not really the kind of film that succeeds in France normally - it's a black comedy, a little Hitchcockian and surreal. I'm a great fan of Monty Python - even when they're not funny. I think the film comes from that background."

Moll, 38, wrote the script for Harry after renovating and decorating a home for himself and his family. Is Michel based on Dominik? "No, it's not as straightforward as that. But there is something of my biography in there. When I first started thinking about the story, my girlfriend and I were in the throes of young parenthood. Our everyday life was in constant havoc due to our two little daughters: endless practical problems to solve, the lack of time and sleep, the irritation and exhaustion. There always comes a time when you can't take any more and you wonder out loud, 'How the hell did I get myself into this mess?' I realised that most of my friends who had kids were going through the same experience. Then I wondered what would happen if someone came into my life and took all those problems away, and how wonderful that would be."

And strange? "Yes, Harry is strange. But it would be strange if a person came into your life and sorted out your problems. There's a scene in the film in which Harry buys Michel a new air-conditioned 4x4 and, while Michel says he can't accept it (it's a ludicrously expensive gift from someone he barely knows), in practice he does.

"In my first film, Intimacy, an adaptation of Sartre, there was a female character who interfered in a couple's life. But with Harry, I wanted a character who wasn't overtly evil. In fact he's a complicated, even sympathetic character, and part of the reason for that is that Sergi Lopez, who plays Harry, has only played good guys up till now." (Lopez starred in the Brittany road movie Western and in last year's Une Liaison Pornographique.)

Why is he called Harry? "I wanted to give him an outsider's status and an otherworldliness. Again, Sergi brings that because he's a Catalan in a French film, but that was merely an accident. No one in France is called Harry, so immediately he is an outsider. But everybody who goes to the movies is aware of the Harrys of cinema - Dirty Harry, The Trouble with Harry, Deconstructing Harry, Harry Lime. They're all enigmas to varying degrees. The same is true of Harry's girlfriend who we constructed as a Hollywood starlet. Both of these characters are creatures of cinema rather than real-life people."

Moll is a creature of cinema, too. When he was growing up in the spa town of Baden-Baden in Germany, he used to buy Cahiers du Cinéma, the analytical French film journal. "I subscribed to it, even though my French was so bad then that I barely understood a word. I remember struggling for ages with an article by the director Olivier Assayas, and it was worth it because it taught me lots of technical things. Later, I read the conversations between Hitchock and Truffaut and that was influential too."

When he was 19, he arrived in Paris, knowing no one. "I had this great desire to make films and it seemed best to go to France. There's such a culture of film here." The Hitchcock influence runs very deep. "I love Hitchock: for me, he is the director who makes films that are not only entertaining but, more importantly, he concentrates his narrative so nothing is left out."

Moll's characters are Hitchockian: their notions of good and evil is different from ours and so, appealingly, we are never quite sure what they will do next. And much of the film's powerful suspense grows from our uncertainty about who will get bumped off next and why.

Moll's first feature film, Intimacy, was released in 1994, but was not a hit. As a result it was six years until Moll was able to film Harry. "That fallow period has made me have a very cool head. Because of Harry's success, I am under a lot of pressure to come up with another box office hit, to get a film made as soon as possible. But I haven't got one and I won't be panicked into creating one. I'm dabbling with a script and maybe, maybe, I'll start filming in 2002."

Could it be another Harry movie? "Maybe," Moll grins. That's the trouble with Harry. You never know what he'll do next.

 Harry, He's Here to Help is released in the UK next Friday.

Harry's an enigma wrapped in top-of-the-range German air conditioning and backed by a soothing opera soundtrack from a state-of-the-art car stereo. Where did he come from? How did he become rich? Why does his girlfriend look like a pneumatic parody of Jean Harlow? Even his name is a puzzle: Harry isn't a common name in France. Not since the psycho killer in George Sluizer's The Vanishing has anyone quite so troubling hung around French service stations and insinuated themselves so disturbingly into other people's lives. But Harry, even if he is a serial killer, comes not to bury Michel, but to praise him. Over dinner that evening, he recites from memory a poem Michel wrote for a school magazine nearly 20 years earlier. He clearly admires Michel, and wants him to return to his creative muse. And he's quite prepared to kill anybody who stands in Michel's way or upsets him. For instance, from the moment we see that Michel's overbearing parents have taken the liberty of installing a disgusting pink bathroom in his farmhouse without asking his permission, we know they are in trouble with Harry. Harry is the psychoanalytical flipside to repressed Michel, who is incapable of standing up to his parents let alone taking hold of his destiny. But Harry is also - and this is what makes his character so interesting - the conscience of the film. He suffers for being an angel of vengeance for Michel. After one killing, he drives through the night howling wildly. He also eats a raw egg after each of his many orgasms during the film, but that's not important right now. In short, Harry's just the kind of stand-up friend a guy would want, but never has. At least in reality. This disturbing, blackly comic suspense film has been a remarkable success in France, taking £10m since it was released at the start of August. But it should do well in Britain, too, since its dark humour is very attuned to our sick sensibilities. Why has the film become one of the few pictures to keep the tricolour flying in the French box office charts this summer? The gangly, German-born director, Dominik Moll, takes a slug from his café créme and a pull on his cigarette. "It's difficult to analyse why it is a success. The film clearly touched a lot of people. It's not really the kind of film that succeeds in France normally - it's a black comedy, a little Hitchcockian and surreal. I'm a great fan of Monty Python - even when they're not funny. I think the film comes from that background." Moll, 38, wrote the script for Harry after renovating and decorating a home for himself and his family. Is Michel based on Dominik? "No, it's not as straightforward as that. But there is something of my biography in there. When I first started thinking about the story, my girlfriend and I were in the throes of young parenthood. Our everyday life was in constant havoc due to our two little daughters: endless practical problems to solve, the lack of time and sleep, the irritation and exhaustion. There always comes a time when you can't take any more and you wonder out loud, 'How the hell did I get myself into this mess?' I realised that most of my friends who had kids were going through the same experience. Then I wondered what would happen if someone came into my life and took all those problems away, and how wonderful that would be." And strange? "Yes, Harry is strange. But it would be strange if a person came into your life and sorted out your problems. There's a scene in the film in which Harry buys Michel a new air-conditioned 4x4 and, while Michel says he can't accept it (it's a ludicrously expensive gift from someone he barely knows), in practice he does. "In my first film, Intimacy, an adaptation of Sartre, there was a female character who interfered in a couple's life. But with Harry, I wanted a character who wasn't overtly evil. In fact he's a complicated, even sympathetic character, and part of the reason for that is that Sergi Lopez, who plays Harry, has only played good guys up till now." (Lopez starred in the Brittany road movie Western and in last year's Une Liaison Pornographique.) Why is he called Harry? "I wanted to give him an outsider's status and an otherworldliness. Again, Sergi brings that because he's a Catalan in a French film, but that was merely an accident. No one in France is called Harry, so immediately he is an outsider. But everybody who goes to the movies is aware of the Harrys of cinema - Dirty Harry, The Trouble with Harry, Deconstructing Harry, Harry Lime. They're all enigmas to varying degrees. The same is true of Harry's girlfriend who we constructed as a Hollywood starlet. Both of these characters are creatures of cinema rather than real-life people." Moll is a creature of cinema, too. When he was growing up in the spa town of Baden-Baden in Germany, he used to buy Cahiers du Cinéma, the analytical French film journal. "I subscribed to it, even though my French was so bad then that I barely understood a word. I remember struggling for ages with an article by the director Olivier Assayas, and it was worth it because it taught me lots of technical things. Later, I read the conversations between Hitchock and Truffaut and that was influential too." When he was 19, he arrived in Paris, knowing no one. "I had this great desire to make films and it seemed best to go to France. There's such a culture of film here." The Hitchcock influence runs very deep. "I love Hitchock: for me, he is the director who makes films that are not only entertaining but, more importantly, he concentrates his narrative so nothing is left out." Moll's characters are Hitchockian: their notions of good and evil is different from ours and so, appealingly, we are never quite sure what they will do next. And much of the film's powerful suspense grows from our uncertainty about who will get bumped off next and why. Moll's first feature film, Intimacy, was released in 1994, but was not a hit. As a result it was six years until Moll was able to film Harry. "That fallow period has made me have a very cool head. Because of Harry's success, I am under a lot of pressure to come up with another box office hit, to get a film made as soon as possible. But I haven't got one and I won't be panicked into creating one. I'm dabbling with a script and maybe, maybe, I'll start filming in 2002." Could it be another Harry movie? "Maybe," Moll grins. That's the trouble with Harry. You never know what he'll do next.  Harry, He's Here to Help is released in the UK next Friday.

webTitle: Oxbridge to get financial help to attract poorer students

fields.headline: Oxbridge to get financial help to attract poorer students
fields.trailText: Half of the governmentês new grants to help universities attract more students from poor backgrounds are set to go to elite institutions such as Oxbridge, it was announced today.
fields.body:
Half of the governmentês new grants to help universities attract more students from poor backgrounds are set to go to elite institutions such as Oxbridge, it was announced today.

In a decision likely to infuriate the former polytechnics, which have been admitting students from a broad range of social backgrounds for some time, the higher education funding council for England plans to allocate 50% of its access funds for institutions to those with more than a fifth of students from private schools.

The council has said that £18m over the next three academic years will go to institutions where less than 80% of the student body is taken from state schools. Universities that will qualify for the money will inevitably be Oxford, Cambridge and other elite institutions.

An extra £18m over the next three years meanwhile will add to the budget already allocated to the postcode premiumê  the top-up grants for enrolling students who come from disadvantaged areas. Most of this money is allocated to new universities.

When the funding council published its performance indicators for universities last month, its statistics revealed a deep educational divide between those from rich and poor neighbourhoods. In richer areas, people stand an 80% of going to university, but less than a 10% chance when they grow up in the poorest districts.

Many academics argue money should be used to address this wider social problem rather than attract a few extra well-educated state school pupils into Oxbridge.

The government has vowed to widen access into the academic elite institutions, since the highly publicised rejection of state school pupil Laura Spence by Oxford University.

The council also plans to channel an extra £34m over the next three years into individual student bursaries

The proposals will raise the total spent annually on all access programmes from £160m in the current academic year, to nearly £190m in 2003-04.

Institutions are asked to supply data to inform the new allocations by 24 November 2000, and respond to the proposed spending plans by 5 January 2001.

The full proposals can be found at hefce.ac.uk

fields.headline: Oversubscribed...
fields.standfirst: ... Katie D London
fields.trailText: ... Katie D London
fields.body: It's not easy keeping up with where to put the slashes in your T-shirts these days. Only six months ago, we were merrily ripping the neck seams off, only to discover that, funnily enough, seams are there for a reason and without them the T-shirt falls apart in the wash. Doh. Then summer came and we ripped the sleeves off for that tanorexic roadie look. Lately, the only way to let rip has been in a horizontal slash below the neckline or straight down the middle, à la Madonna in her promotional Snatch T-shirt - a fact that has not escaped designer Katie D. Katie has the Saturday night T-shirt (rather than the Sunday morning sloppy version) down to a fine art, with printed, appliquéd, diamanté-studded numbers. Look out for the new Dallas collection, named after the Southfork gals - "Lucy" has cutesy teeny gold stars, while "Sue Ellen" has rhinestones and ranch-style silver studs. And... no rips. They're a bit draughty for this weather, after all.

webTitle: Leader: The day of the bedtime story is dying

fields.headline: The day of the bedtime story is dying
fields.standfirst:
Once upon a time... children had bedtime stories. Not now
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Only a third of children aged between two and eight now have stories read to them five nights a week, according to yet another new survey. Only 16% get a story nightly. In their parents' day, three quarters of children used to enjoy that regular night-time treat. But life is quite different now.
fields.body:
Only a third of children aged between two and eight now have stories read to them five nights a week, according to yet another new survey. Only 16% get a story nightly. In their parents' day, three quarters of children used to enjoy that regular night-time treat. But life is quite different now. What with couples working long hours, lone parents having too little time to spare, mothers who like to discuss the affairs of the day with their partners rather than wade through the umpteenth Enid Blyton, and computers and TVs installed in thousands of juvenile bedrooms, a tradition almost as old as reading itself may be dying.

All this, it has to be said, is based on a sadly meagre sample: a mere 150 children and 84 adults. But it squares with anecdotal evidence of the way life is changing and is therefore likely to be believed. And what follows is even sadder. The old rule that a night-time story is conducive to sleep is working the wrong way round. Some of these readings are never completed, because dads (never mums) doze off before the denouement.

What do the children do then? Switch on EastEnders, perhaps, or cavort for a while on the internet. But even that can hardly make up for stories without happy endings. In this new, truncated world, the ugly duckling never becomes a swan. Hansel and Gretel never get home. Jack never escapes from the giant to shin down the beanstalk; Red Riding Hood's granny is doomed to remain for ever in the wolf's belly. Cinderella waits in vain for her prince to rediscover her and remains for the rest of her life a sad skivvy. Rapunzel stays till the end of her days entrapped in her lonely tower; Snow White never gets out of her coffin. What a cold, bleak picture of life these unfinished tales must create. Older people sometimes sadly remark that children today are no longer the bright-eyed, carefree, tumbling, gambolling creatures of former times. Now - if this survey is right - we know why.

fields.headline: He was bold, but a bully
fields.standfirst:
There can now be a fresh start at Ofsted

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: He has gone. There will be few tears from Guardian readers. Indeed there will be much rejoicing in schools, teaching union headquarters, and local education authority chambers. Few people in public services have generated as much public antipathy in liberal and left circles as Chris Woodhead, chief inspector of schools, and boss of the hated Ofsted.
fields.body:
He has gone. There will be few tears from Guardian readers. Indeed there will be much rejoicing in schools, teaching union headquarters, and local education authority chambers. Few people in public services have generated as much public antipathy in liberal and left circles as Chris Woodhead, chief inspector of schools, and boss of the hated Ofsted. He was accused of arrogance and ambition. Typically, he agreed. As he told our feature writer, Sabine Durrant, in 1998: "I'm not sitting here whingeing about the way the world has received me. I accept responsibility for that." He compared his public life of courting controversy with his private passion of rock climbing. There was no point in doing either unless there was risk, fear and challenge.

And yet he was not being as brave as he sounded, because on the right there was much support for the man. He was appointed by John Major in 1994 and re-appointed for a second term by Tony Blair, in what many people saw as an appeasement move to keep the Daily Mail sweet. There will be much gnashing of teeth today in the Mail and in the Telegraph, to which, it was confirmed yesterday, he will be moving as a writer. Sunday columnists will already be preparing analysis pieces on how the upholder of school standards was finally assassinated by New Labour.

The truth is more complicated. Mr Woodhead's reports were not just filled with criticism. There were large chunks devoted to progress being achieved that were frequently ignored by the media in their search for a good knocking story. Beyond that, many of his criticisms were accurate. They began with the report of the three wise men which documented the decline of standards in our primary schools. This helped prepare the ground for Labour's literacy and numeracy hours, which have achieved outstanding success. His claim that there were 15,000 incompetent teachers produced an irrational reaction. Which profession doesn't have a 4% incompetency rate? It is easy to forget how an earlier generation of inspectors refused to say boo to a goose as the standards in our schools declined. Yet, in the end, he became too combative and ranged too wide. He lost his most crucial audience: teachers. To look for reform through bullying will never achieve the long-term change that coaxing can. People need to believe in change, for if they do not the results can only be transitory.

webTitle: Unions cheer departure of morale destroyer

fields.headline: Unions cheer departure of morale destroyer
fields.standfirst:
Tories alone in praising excellent record
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Teachers' leaders could scarcely contain their delight last night at the news of Chris Woodhead's resignation.
fields.body:
Teachers' leaders could scarcely contain their delight last night at the news of Chris Woodhead's resignation.

Doug McAvoy, general secretary of the National Union of Teachers, said: "There will be no tears, only cheers from teachers at Mr Woodhead's departure. Everything he has done has demoralised teachers. I hope the prime minister's loss will be David Blunkett's gain. Whatever teacher readership the Daily Telegraph had will disappear overnight."

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Union of Schoolmasters/Union of Women Teachers, added: "It's good news for teachers - it is long overdue.

"I think over the last few months he was on a suicide mission and teachers will breathe a sigh of relief."

John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads' Association, said: "It's a good day for education, and not just the teaching profession, because it needs someone to boost teachers' morale. No-one has done more than Mr Woodhead to lower it. I believe he brought the office of chief inspector into disrepute."

Liberal Democrat education spokesman Phil Willis, who on Wednesday called for the education secretary, David Blunkett, to sack Mr Woodhead after his controversial appearance before the education select committee, said: "This is a red letter day for the teaching profession and for Ofsted. Thankfully, we can now continue without the polemic of Chris Woodhead. His position had become untenable..."

David Triesman, general secretary of the Association of University Teachers, added: "It's an opportunity to make the first appointment in a decade that can do something positive for teaching education rather than wreck it and an opportunity to raise morale where he only succeeded in damaging it."

The shadow education secretary, Theresa May, was "very sorry" to see Mr Woodhead go. "It is a serious blow for those of us who are interested in raising standards in education. Chris Woodhead has done an excellent job."

webTitle: Comment: David Blunkett defends Labour's record on schools

fields.headline: We are making a difference
fields.standfirst:
David Blunkett rebuts Nick Davies's criticism of his policies and his department and lays out Labour's record in schools
Education Unlimited
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: I grew up in one of the most deprived parts of Britain. I know the problems which inner-city children face. I visit schools every week. Not everything I have done since 1997 has been perfect and I will always be honest where policies need improvement.
fields.body:
I grew up in one of the most deprived parts of Britain. I know the problems which inner-city children face. I visit schools every week. Not everything I have done since 1997 has been perfect and I will always be honest where policies need improvement - on exclusions, for example. Most people recognise that much has been achieved in education since 1997 - but we need to do more.

Nick Davies claims that he undertook an "in-depth study" into my department, when he did no such thing. He was given plenty of facts, yet simply distorted them. Let me take his charges in turn.

First, money. The £19bn was a cumulative sum. The press release on July 14 1998, when the money was announced, quoted me as saying: "In 2002, we will be spending £11bn more on education than the last administration planned to spend this year." It didn't take much detective work to find that out. The release also gave real terms figures.

This was money that the Tories were not prepared to spend, as is the money in the second spending review, which the Tories will cut. It means that on average, £300 more per pupil in real terms is being spent in schools this year than in 1997. That was after a £60 per pupil cut over the previous three years. Three times as much money is being spent on school capital this year than in 1996-97. We have direct grants worth up to £70,000 each next year for schools to spend as they choose. There is more needed - and it will come as a result of the spending review, where real term spending will rise by £370 more per pupil. It is absurd to pretend that there has not been a substantial increase in funding.

Second, standards. In primary schools, I set two main objectives - to cut infant class sizes and improve literacy and numeracy. The numbers in classes over 30 are down to 30,000 now (it was nearly 480,000 in 1997). Literacy and numeracy standards are rising. Davies may think it unimportant that children are taught the 3Rs effectively. I don't. Learning to read, to spell, to write and to count cannot wait until we sort out the disadvantages that have bedevilled generation after generation of youngsters.

Third, failing schools. Fresh Start is one part of our approach. It was not imported from the US, but first announced at the Association of Teachers and Lecturers conference in 1995 for schools which persist in failing and would otherwise have to close. Fresh Start is a last resort by education authorities in just 25 of the most difficult schools in the country. It takes time and determination to succeed. Most such schools have improved discipline and pupils' willingness to work, the first step towards better results.

Our main strategy on failing schools has seen over 500 come out of special measures since the election and a further 100 closed, with pupils transferred to better local schools. The time it takes to turn around such schools has fallen from 25 to 18 months. We are beginning to improve schools in areas that have been neglected for so long that the eulogies to equality of opportunity rang rather hollow in parents' ears. These are important achievements, the result of work by dedicated people of whom Davies is contemptuous.

Finally, of course we must improve secondary schools - and we have started to do so. Inner city secondaries have dedicated staff to deal with truancy and disaffection. Davies dismisses these learning mentors, yet schools with mentors see them as a way to free teachers to teach and to re-engage with families cut off from education. There are programmes to stretch gifted pupils. And there is much more support both inside and outside the school to deal with disruptive pupils. We are also improving vocational alternatives for young people. This programme - Excellence in Cities - will, by next September, cover as many as a third of all secondary schools.

Our approach doesn't patronise those of us who know poverty but it is already beginning to give schools the wherewithal to overcome that poverty. I know Excellence in Cities is having an effect because I talk to heads and teachers who benefit from it. But it isn't compulsory.

We are also moving towards free universal nursery education for all three- and four-year-olds. Sure Start is giving help and support to young mums living in poverty. Further and higher education are getting the funding they deserve. There is more money for substantially improved teacher pay, salaries for trainee teachers and teachers' professional development than ever before.

Mr Davies may regard all these as "dinky little schemes". He may want us to forget about improving our schools until we solve world poverty. To do so would be wholly wrong. I went into politics to represent the people I grew up with in Sheffield - to make a real difference to their life chances. I have no intention of forgetting my roots - and that means children on estates in my constituency learning to read and write and schools having the backing they need to deal with their day-to-day problems. They didn't get that support with the Conservatives. They are beginning to get it under Labour - and frankly, that matters a lot more to me and to my constituents than refighting the theological battles of the 1980s.

 David Blunkett MP is secretary of state for education and employment

fields.headline: Schools' master who preached the message from Tony Blair
fields.standfirst:
The legacy The Ofsted chief failed to achieve what he wanted, but to No 10 he was invaluable

Education Unlimited
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: When Tony Blair came to power in 1997, he knew he needed Chris Woodhead on board to protect the government from criticism in the rightwing media that Labour was "going soft" on teachers.
fields.body:
When Tony Blair came to power in 1997, he knew he needed Chris Woodhead on board to protect the government from criticism in the rightwing media that Labour was "going soft" on teachers.

David Blunkett, the education secretary, had been warning the prime minister that delivery of the government's education programme was damaged by Woodhead's morale-sapping assaults on incompetence within the profession.

When the time came in September 1998 to reappoint Woodhead for a further five years, the Treasury was about to spend billions on a performance pay scheme to hang on to staff. Why reappoint the man whose drip-feed criticism was driving so many of them out of the door?

But Blair saw the Tory-appointed Woodhead as a key weapon in the battle to persuade Middle England that Labour deserved its second term. Number 10 was prepared to tolerate occasional indiscipline and indiscretion as long as the chief inspector backed education programmes that he had done so much to shape.

That logic still held firm last night as Woodhead stepped down without an obvious successor in sight.

He had seen off rivals who might have stepped into his shoes. Nick Tate, chief executive of the qualifications and curriculum authority, quit this year to become headof Winchester college. Anthea Millett, chief executive of the teacher training agency, also stood down after experiencing the lash of Woodhead's tongue.

Although there is a cadre of able inspectors in the office for standards in education (Ofsted), none appears ready or willing to step into the quasi-political role that Woodhead seized and Blair played to Labour's advantage.

So his departure will leave a vacuum in the field that the prime minister has declared to be still the government's number one priority. As teachers' leaders dance on Woodhead's grave, Downing Street may be looking for other measures to show the profession who is boss.

As one Downing Street insider put it at the time of the chief executive's reappointment: "We had to do it. The progress Woodhead made could have been so easily lost. We could not let his critics think they had won."

But leaving these political considerations aside, Woodhead's departure is not likely to make as much difference in the schools as his arrival.

His predecessors had worked with the profession to achieve school improvement by exhortation and support. That is the model which still operates in Wales and Scotland, although arguments rage about whether it is more or less effective.

Abrasive

From his first day in the job, Woodhead showed his style would be more abrasive. In a series of controversial interviews, he declared war on "incompetent" teachers who had been led astray from traditional classroom techniques. He excoriated woolly-minded liberals in the teacher training colleges who had indoctrinated students into progressive "child-centred" methods, paying insufficient attention to the basics of literacy and numeracy.

The approach was consolidated when he published his first annual report, which estimated that there were 15,000 "incompetent" teachers who should be driven out of the profession. The extrapolations from Ofsted's research on which he based this claim were regarded by most education professors as an unjustifiable stretching of statistics. The professors will also be dancing this morning.

Woodhead's reorganisation of Ofsted to produce more critical inspection reports was described by Tim Brighouse, chief education officer in Birmingham and one of David Blunkett's closest advisers, as a "reign of terror".

But it was privately welcomed by the heads of middle-ranking schools who used the threat of impending Ofsted inspections to engineer change in reluctant staffrooms. The headteacher associations railed against the Woodhead regime, but for the first few years it may have had a therapeutic effect.

The biggest problem came in schools that Ofsted declared to be failing and which it put on "special measures". Many have struggled to counteract the resulting collapse in staff morale and stigma in the local community.

Woodhead adopted a combative style that is not commonly associated with public officials. He was furious if anyone described him as a civil servant. He was appointed directly by the Queen and regarded himself as a "crown servant" employed "to tell the truth" about schools without having to answer to ministers.

David Blunkett told friends that he would have preferred to have dispensed with the chief inspector's services when Labour took power in 1997, but was obliged to honour a contract that was not due to expire until 1999.

He finessed the problem by appointing the teacher-bashing Woodhead and the teacher-friendly Brighouse as joint vice-chairmen of his school standards task force. This was a government that believed in both chalk and cheese.

Woodhead took advantage of direct access to Downing Street and built a relationship with Prince Charles who espoused some of the chief inspector's views on teacher training.

There was also a close relationship between Woodhead and Stephen Byers, school standards minister during Labour's first year and the main force behind the policy of naming and shaming failing schools. Woodhead canvassed Byers' promotion to education secretary before a reshuffle took him to the DTI.

But the chief inspector did not have the power to dictate education policy. He was not the author of the literacy and numeracy strategies that have been introduced in all primary schools. He did not achieve his aim of abolishing local education authorities, although their powers and budgets have been considerably slimmed.

He did not achieve the destruction of university education departments in spite of lecturing that they were the "heart of darkness". Most teacher training remains in the universities when he wanted it to be organised by the better schools. Academic education research remains a thriving activity when he wanted it abolished.

So he did not achieve all he wanted and he was running out of new ideas. There was still an organisational job to do, as Ofsted took on responsibility for registering and inspecting 100,000 childminders, nursery and playgroup leaders.

But the chief inspector is a man who is easily bored. In his hobbies of rock climbing and mountaineering, his thrill comes from successfully taking risks. He was a one-term appointment who was never likely to last a full second term.

fields.headline: Well, thank goodness he's gone
fields.standfirst:
Chris Woodhead should have been sacked for crimes against education
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Chris Woodhead should have been sacked for crimes against education
fields.body:
My joy at the news of Chris Woodhead's resignation from Ofsted was moderated with regret that he had gone with the remnants of honour. I would have preferred him to have been sacked for one of his sundry offences against education. Examples are legion - not the least being his announcement that 15,000 teachers were failing their pupils and his later admission, without apology, that far from 4% of the profession not being up to the job, only about one in every 1,500 had been classified as inadequate.

That error - and the arrogance with which he reacted to its exposure - was not only typical of the man. It was typical of his years as chief inspector of schools.

Some of the obsequies that marked Chris Woodhead's passing spoke of his work to improve school standards. In fact Woodhead will be most widely remembered for having depressed teacher morale - and thereby holding back David Blunkett's aspirations for general improvements in the whole school system. The attacks on teachers were the secret of his survival.

Woodhead made himself indispensable to the government by becoming the scourge of creatures who existed only in his imagination - T-shirted anarchists who preached revolution in the classrooms, despised examinations, were casual about higher education standards and believed in teaching all-ability groups. The prime minister - anxious to establish his credentials as the enemy of such people - regarded Woodhead as proof of his educational orthodoxy. As a result, no matter how intolerable Woodhead's conduct and absurd his hubris, he could not be removed.

So Woodhead was allowed to politicise the inspectorate. In pursuit of his narrow view about how schools should be organised - and with the subsidiary purpose of guaranteeing his greater glory - he dismissed, normally in the most offensive language, the views of anyone who disagreed with him. The inspectorate was turned into what London University Institute of Education called a witch-hunt and Ofsted organised what Professor Tim Brighouse (chief education officer of Birmingham) described as a "reign of terror".

It was hard to find a genuine educationalist who had a good word to say either about the man or his ideas. London University's Professor Peter Mortimer attacked the "zealotry" of his punitive policies which identified - and often exaggerated - an individual school's shortcoming without making positive suggestions about how it might be remedied. Improvement, said Professor Mortimer, comes from "help not blame". But that was not Woodhead's way. He, more than any other single person, must take the blame for the policy of "naming and shaming" so-called failing schools - an initiative which was as foolish as it was brutal and has been quietly dropped.

Woodhead's performance at last Wednesday's meeting of the education sub-committee provides a suitable epitaph for his reign at Ofsted. Having refused to cooperate with the commission for racial equality's survey into racism in schools and written a deeply offensive letter to Gurbux Singh, the new chairman of the commission, he moved on to insult individual members of the committee with suggestions that their mental equipment was not adequate to follow the complexity and speed of his thought. Such behaviour might be regarded as amusing had it not come from the man who, up to that moment, was required to make judgments about our schools and their teachers.

The best that can be said in his defence is that he already knew that he was going and was therefore demob happy. But Wednesday's conduct was typical of the Woodhead debating technique. He relied on abuse rather than argument and assertion rather than evidence. That is not generally regarded as a mark of intellectual quality.

Of course his abrasive manner, no less than his reactionary views, endeared him to rightwing newspapers. When, after his first stint as chief inspector, the time for his reappointment approached, there were accusations that the "progressive establishment is trying to destroy the man who has done more than anyone to improve teaching" and claims that a "whispering campaign by critics in the teaching establishment" aimed to get Woodhead sacked. Whatever else the campaign was, it was not whispering. People with real concern for teachers and teaching demanded that he should go and backed up their calls with hard evidence of the damage which he was doing.

A chief inspector who talked in generalised terms about "hopeless incompetents" and entrenched education dogma is not the man to follow in the footsteps of Matthew Arnold. Yet the Daily Telegraph made that comparison when, yesterday, they accused the House of Commons education sub-committee of behaving "like dons but more like ones from Corleone than Cambridge". While accusing MPs of behaving like the mafia the paper was defending a man who they already knew was likely to become one of their columnists. Chris Woodhead has found his natural home.

fields.headline: Woodhead resigns
fields.standfirst:
Teachers' unions jubilant as Ofsted chief resigns

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Chris Woodhead, the chief inspector of schools in  England, resigned suddenly last night to the  undisguised relief of the education secretary, David  Blunkett, and outright joy of the teacher unions.
fields.body:
Chris Woodhead, the chief inspector of schools in England, resigned suddenly last night to the undisguised relief of the education secretary, David Blunkett, and outright joy of the teacher unions.

Union leaders queued up to wish good riddance to the man who had been the most vocal critic of the teaching profession over six tumultuous years but who enjoyed the support of Tony Blair.

Mr Blunkett's - and eventually Mr Blair's - patience ran out when the education secretary discovered Mr Woodhead had been secretly negotiating his exit from the job to go into media and public relations.

In the wake of bitter clashes between Mr Woodhead and MPs on the Commons education select committee, Mr Blunkett and Mr Blair spoke on Wednesday night. Mr Blair finally conceded that the head of Ofsted had to go.

Mr Woodhead said last night: "I think I have done my bit for Ofsted. I am proud of what I have achieved and, with an election coming up, this was an appropriate moment to move on.

"I do not think I have been abrasive in the sense that I have set out to ruffle feathers. What I have set out to do is to speak plainly."

Mr Woodhead finally agreed to go at a meeting yesterday with Sir Michael Bichard, permanent secretary at the Department for Education and Employment, and cabinet secretary Sir Richard Wilson.

Mr Blunkett believed the situation was made intolerable by a leader yesterday in the Daily Telegraph - the paper the chief inspector is to join - which described Mr Woodhead as "a valuable source of well-informed criticism".

Government sources said Mr Woodhead would effectively leave his post as chief inspector at the end of this month, giving him three months' paid leave before he joins the Telegraph as a consultant on "educational, cultural and social matters" in the spring. He will also work no more than two days a week for Bell Pottinger Public Affairs, the company chaired by Lord Bell, Lady Thatcher's former public relations guru, as an adviser on "regulatory issues" - but not, Lord Bell said, on education.

Mr Woodhead, who was earning £124,000 plus a bonus of up to 10%, was not due to leave his job until September 2003. But, he told Mr Blunkett in his resignation letter: "The time has come for me to move on and make a contribution in different ways."

Mr Woodhead delighted conservatives and infuriated liberals with his regular assaults on the education profession, beginning in his first week in September 1994 when he called for incompetent teachers to be sacked. He later said 15,000 teachers were incompetent.

The education secretary would have been happy to see Mr Woodhead resign long ago, but refused to join calls for him to go when it was alleged that he had an affair with Amanda Johnston, a pupil of his, while she was still at school. The couple later lived together but insisted that their relationship had begun once she left school.

In September, Mr Woodhead returned from holiday and, in an interview with the Guardian, angered ministers by calling for A-levels to be made more difficult.

Three and a half weeks ago Mr Blunkett called Mr Woodhead into his office after learning that he was negotiating to join the Telegraph and was looking for other work.

The education secretary was determined not to allow Mr Woodhead to dictate his departure if he had already decided to go and made it clear he was prepared to nip the problem in the bud by sacking him if necessary.

In an exchange of letters, Mr Blunkett thanked Mr Woodhead for his "significant con tribution to our shared goal of raising standards in schools".

He said later in interviews: "I think anyone who feels that their role is better to be played writing for the Daily Telegraph or being a consultant to a PR company has obviously found a different niche in life."

Mr Woodhead told the Guardian recently that his paper of choice on holiday was the Times.

Mr Woodhead's short-term replacement is Ofsted's deputy inspector, Mike Tomlinson, who once said "I don't give a monkey's toss for teachers", but is generally regarded as a more conciliatory figure.

Doug McAvoy, general secretary of the National Union of Teachers, said: "There will be no tears only cheers at Chris Woodhead's departure. Everything he has done has demoralised teachers. "

William Hague, the Tory leader, said last night: "Chris Woodhead's resignation leaves Labour's education policy in tatters. While he was chief inspector of schools parents could be sure that they had a powerful champion of high standards. Now that reassurance has gone."

fields.body:
Relations between Ofsted chief Chris Woodhead and the education secretary worsened today after David Blunkett described Mr Woodhead's style as "abrasive".

Asked on the BBC's Today programme if Mr Blunkett had wished him well, Mr Woodhead replied: "He did say that. You will have to ask him if he meant it."

Mr Woodhead also blamed the government for his resignation, saying he was finding it "increasingly hard" to defend current policies. However, he denied that he had been forced out by the education secretary and said he would explain his reasons for leaving at the end of February, when he has served out his notice.

Conservative leader William Hague claimed the government's education policy was "in tatters" after Mr Woodhead's departure. The Ofsted head will take up two posts next year - one as a consultant at Bell Pottinger Public Affairs, an agency set up by former Tory PR guru Tim Bell, and the other as a leader writer at the Daily Telegraph.

Mr Woodhead denied, however, that he was a Conservative. "I am not a Tory. I simply believe in children getting a decent education. I have never understood this right-wing, left-wing polarisation with regard to education." He insisted that schools had improved during his tenure at Ofsted.

"Both the secretary of state and the prime minister wanted me to stay on. It is my decision. They are disappointed that I am leaving," he said. "I fully appreciate that honesty, plain speaking, will be seen by some people as abrasiveness but I make no apology for speaking out over the last six years when children have been getting a raw deal," he added. "Where there are problems, those problems must be brought out into the open. I just cannot see how anybody can argue a different case."

Mr Blunkett later told the Today programme: "Of course I didn't want Chris Woodhead to hand in his resignation having spent the most enormous political energy and time defending him and the role of Ofsted over the last three and a half years, including through the terrible trauma of eight weeks of Chris's private life," he said, referring to reports that Mr Woodhead had conducted an affair with a pupil, Amanda Johnston, while married to his first wife.

Mr Blunkett also issued a statement today saying he was committed to school improvement: "The only thing that will prevent our schools continuing to improve is the election of William Hague and his damaging plans for slashing school budgets."

"We are succeeding in raising standards in our schools and this week got 450,000 fewer infants in large classes and have seen big improvements in literacy and numeracy - both programmes which the Tories would scrap," he added.

Mr Hague commented: "When Tony Blair decided to reappoint Chris Woodhead after the last election it was seen as a totem of Labour's commitment to improve education.

"Three years later it has become clear that Tony Blair and David Blunkett were all along using Mr Woodhead as the figleaf behind which to hide their complete failure to improve our schools. Judging from what Chris Woodhead has said and written recently I suspect he knew that."

fields.headline: ONdigital slams Sky price rises
fields.trailText: Friday 5.15pm: ONdigital has launched an attack on arch-rival BSkyB, calling on the Office of Fair Trading to investigate the company, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
ONdigital has launched an attack on arch-rival BSkyB, calling on the Office of Fair Trading to investigate the company.

The digital broadcaster, which is co-owned by Granada Media and Carlton Communications, is furious with BSkyB's plans to raise prices for its basic, sports and movie channels by up to £4 a month.

ONdigital has accused BSkyB of abusing its dominant position in the digital market by imposing unilateral price demands that would hit its own customers.

John Vickers, the director general of fair trading, is currently investigating BSkyB's position in the pay-TV market.

ONdigital believes BSkyB should at least hold back from implementing the price hikes until the review is completed.

Stuart Prebble, chief executive of ONdigital, said: "It is extraordinary that while it is still under investigation by the OFT, Sky should try to force through huge price rises of up to 40% on their, and our, customers.

"I hope the regulator acts swiftly to ensure that Sky's - and our - customers are protected against this sort of behaviour."

BSkyB countered ONdigital's attack, accusing it of hypocrisy after recently announcing its own package of price rises. BSkyB added that the increases did not contravene an agreement signed with ONdigital in 1997.

The Office of Fair Trading said it was waiting to receive an official complaint from ONdigital

webTitle: Weakest Link to make BBC £30m in foreign sales

fields.headline: Weakest Link to make BBC £30m in foreign sales
fields.trailText: Friday 5pm: The Weakest Link could net the BBC £30m as foreign broadcasters queue up to buy the format of the hit show, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
The Weakest Link is set to generate as much as £30m for the BBC, with more than a dozen foreign broadcasters queueing up to buy the format of the hit show.

And BBC chiefs are insisting that broadcasters find their own version of Anne Robinson to ensure the format remains intact.

BBC Worldwide head of programme and operations Colin Jarvis said: "This is the main focus of our discussions. In Germany, for example, we are trying out three different presenters to make sure we get the tone right.

"Foreign broadcasters are mesmerised by Anne. They are amazed at how tough and forthright she is, and that people are willing to be put through the emotional mill - particularly the final 'walk of shame'. They've never seen anything like it in a gameshow before."

BBC Worldwide is in talks to sell the format of the programme with broadcasters from the US, Germany, Italy, Australia, France, the Netherlands, Portugal, South Africa, Israel, Turkey, Spain, Latin America, Sweden, French Canada and Ireland.

Income from the show, which has become the BBC's biggest game show hit for 10 years, will easily outstrip previous hits such as Antiques Roadshow, That's Life and Pets Win Prizes.

Esther Rantzen's That's Life, which remained a staple of some continental schedules for nine years, generated just £2.5m for the BBC.

The Weakest Link's prospects are better, however, because the BBC will co-produce every overseas show.

Ms Robinson will not make a penny in overseas sales from her terrifying schoolmarmish manner.

However, beneficiaries will include the two amateurs who came up with the idea for the show.

fields.headline: Endgame:  Kasparov loses to protege
fields.trailText:
Garry Kasparov's 15-year reign as chess world
champion ended yesterday when his former
protege, Vladimir Kramnik, secured the draw he
needed to win the title. For Kasparov (above),
who failed to win a game in the match, it was a
tame end to an epic tenure as champion.
fields.body:
Garry Kasparov's 15-year reign as chess world champion ended yesterday when his former protege, Vladimir Kramnik, secured the draw he needed to win the title. For Kasparov (above), who failed to win a game in the match, it was a tame end to an epic tenure as champion.

Kasparov, who has dominated the sport since he won the title at 22, finished the match at the Riverside Studios in Hammersmith, west London, much as he had begun it: looking exhausted and bewildered. "I was totally out-prepared," he said. "It was difficult to play without openings as white, and I exhausted myself trying to rebuild my opening repertoire."

Unlike the icy Kramnik, who gives nothing away at the board, Kasparov never hides his feelings when under pressure. Earlier this week he hinted that personal problems had undermined his title defence. Asked why his play had been so lacklustre, he replied: "It's a long story. I will tell you when the match is over. I am tired. I don't hide it." Yesterday he refused to expand on what those problems were.

Yesterday's game was the 15th of the match, and by drawing Kramnik, who is 25, took an unassailable 8.5-6.5 lead. Kasparov made all the running and had a slight advantage for much of the game, but could not force a win. He showed flickers of his old self in the latter stages of the match, but it was too late to repair the damage of two early defeats.

fields.headline: Fuel protest website 'backed by BNP'
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol crisis
fields.trailText: The British National party is behind a website supporting a renewed round of fuel protests, a Labour MP has claimed.
fields.body:
The British National party is behind a website supporting a renewed round of fuel protests, a Labour MP has claimed.

ShaunWoodward, the MP for Witney who defected to Labour from the Conservatives earlier this year, told the Commons that the far-right site www.fuel-protest.com is concerned with who "really runs Britain". It is registered to the BNP's head of internet technology at an address in Ilford, east London.

The site tells protestors to burn an effigy of Tony Blair at bonfire parties and explains how to spin the spectacle into local newspapers' coverage.

Its authors blame the petrol duty on the cost of "political correctness". On the site they maintain that "the British people are not only expected to watch their homeland confiscated - the Labour government have the cheek to demand that we finance the process as well."

It accuses Mr Blair of wanting to turn a lorry driver's son into a "mincing faggot" through high fuel taxes and says Westminster is in the grip of a "government of perverts".

Nick Griffin, the BNP's chairman, told political magazine epxNews that the party did not initially admit to running the site to distance fuel protestors from the "Millbank spin machine". But he claims that the BNP was instrumental in the first round of fuel protests. "Many of our members who are hauliers, farmer and particularly taxi drivers were involved," he said.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, said he had seen the website but added that he did not believe that the majority of those involved in last month's protests shared its views.

The site links to the Countryside Alliance and the UK Independence party. The Road Haulage association, which asked to be removed from the BNP's list of favoured organisations, is accused of being a "bunch of pro-government stooges".

fields.headline: Minister plans inquiry into Feltham murder
fields.standfirst: Special report: deaths in custody
fields.trailText: Paul Boateng, the prisons minister, has indicated that he is convinced of the need for an independent inquiry into the the death of an Asian inmate at Feltham young offenders' institution.
fields.body:
Paul Boateng, the prisons minister, has indicated that he is convinced of the need for an independent inquiry into the the death of an Asian inmate at Feltham young offenders' institution.

After a meeting last night with the minister and Martin Narey, director general of the prison service, the family of Zahid Mubarek, 19, who was beaten to death by a racist psychopath with whom he shared a cell, said they were confident that their demands for an inquiry would be met.

Robert Stewart, 20, was sentenced to life for the murder of Mr Mubarek on Wednesday.

After the meeting at the Home Office, Suresh Grover, of the National Civil Rights Movement, which has backed the family's campaign, said: "Mr Boateng said he was convinced of the need for an inquiry... Lawyers for both parties will meet again to thrash out the terms of reference."
