webTitle: Sick institution in urgent need of cure

fields.headline: Sick institution in urgent need of cure
fields.standfirst:
New governor pledges to bring stability; others would prefer to see the place demolished

Special report: deaths in custody
Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: The conviction of an openly racist psychopath for the murder of his Asian cellmate in Feltham young offenders' institution has once again focused attention on conditions within Britain's largest youth custody centre. Variously described by former deputy governor Ian Thomas as Dickensian, and by the chief inspector of prisons, Sir David Ramsbotham, as "rotten to the core", Feltham symbolises the malaise in Britain's prison system.
fields.body:
The conviction of an openly racist psychopath for the murder of his Asian cellmate in Feltham young offenders' institution has once again focused attention on conditions within Britain's largest youth custody centre. Variously described by former deputy governor Ian Thomas as Dickensian, and by the chief inspector of prisons, Sir David Ramsbotham, as "rotten to the core", Feltham symbolises the malaise in Britain's prison system.

Zahid Mubarek, 19, was battered to death in March at Feltham by his cellmate Robert Stewart, who was jailed for life for murder on Wednesday. The pair were allocated the same cell at Feltham, despite Stewart's record of violence against fellow prisoners and hundreds of letters in which he expressed his extreme racist views.

Currently home to 631 young offenders between 15 and 21, Feltham, in Hounslow, south-west London, is operating under capacity. The chances of that situation lasting are slim. It is the only young offenders' institution serving all courts in greater London and most of the south of England. Understaffed and periodically overpopulated, it is home to some of the most disruptive youths in the country.

By almost any measure it is a failing institution. Sir David, reporting in December 1998, was unequivocal. "This report ... into Feltham is, without doubt, the most disturbing that I have had to make during my three years as HM chief inspector of prisons," he wrote in the preface to his report.

"I have to disclose to the public not only that conditions and treatment of the 922 children and young prisoners confined _ are, in many instances, totally unacceptable. They ... reveal a history of neglect of those committed to their charge and a failure to meet the demands of society to tackle the problem of offending behaviour."

He found a regime that routinely confined prisoners to cells 23 and a half hours a day, failed to provide sufficient activities and exercise for its inmates and was routinely filthy. It is blighted by violence - there have been more than 5,000 prisoner-on-prisoner assaults in the last 10 years and seven suicides. There have been four governors in six months. The latest to take up the challenge is Nick Pascoe.

Yesterday he acknowledged the difficulties he faces. "We have accepted the need for change at Feltham and I am looking forward to getting down to the job of improving the regime," he said.

"Much needs to be done but my priority is to give Feltham the stability it desperately needs."

Overcrowded
Mr Pascoe's approach were welcomed by Juliet Lyon, director of the Prison Reform Trust. According to Ms Lyon, his problems are fourfold. Feltham is overcrowded, has suffered a crisis of management, fails utterly to provide appropriate treatment for prisoners with mental health problems and is afflicted by racism, she said.

"The first thing Feltham needs is a period of stable leadership. There have been four governors in the last six months. If it was a failing school we would tolerate perhaps two changes of headmaster in that time, but Feltham isn't a school; it is responsible for some of the most vulnerable and volatile young men in society."

"It needs a period of stability, to be scaled down to a manageable size, and for the authorities to face up to the real problems of mental health inside the institution."

For three years Peter Misch, a forensic psychologist specialising in adolescent behaviour, faced those challenges on a daily basis at Feltham. He was horrified by what he found.

"Feltham exceeded every negative report I heard about it. The level of emotional and psychiatric disturbance in enormous; it was mind bogglingly high," he said.

"People who were acutely psychotic were locked up for 23 and a half hours a day, there was a lack of resources, no integral sanitation in the medical wing which rendered it filthy at times and you have to bear in mind the basic brutality of banging up 15-year-olds. Episodes of violence were depressingly frequent, we saw epidemics of self-harm and 25 hanging attempts in a single week.

"There are a lot of good people at Feltham and a small number of extraordinarily devoted staff but with the lack of resources it was just impossible to provide appropriate care."

The prison service points to recent improvements in the reception and screening processes at Feltham that they say would have prevented Robert Stewart and Zahid Mubarek sharing a cell. It would also have identified Stewart's psychopathy, they say.

But critics point out that incidents such as the one that left Mr Mubarek dead will continue to occur unless the practice of imprisoning 15- and 16-year-olds on juvenile wings is ended. These children, say the critics, are too young and too vulnerable to be exposed to the harsh regime of a prison.

"The majority of children should undoubtedly be kept in the community as long as possible," said Frances Crook, director of the Howard League for Penal Reform.

"At Feltham, you have 40 or 50 children who are simply learning the ropes of crime. The knock-on effects of introducing these kids to prison are huge. They learn the ropes of a place like Feltham at an early age and learn disruptive skills that make life harder for prison officers and other inmates.

"Far from reducing the chances of people becoming victims of crime, they increase it. I am far more likely to have my handbag nicked, and get punched in the face in the process, because these children are imprisoned."

There is support for this argument in the case of Robert Stewart. In care from the age of 14, he was inducted into the prison service as soon as he was old enough, receiving his first custodial sentence at 15. Over the next five years he became institutionalised, losing any points of reference other than those of prison life and valuing the respect of no one except his peers inside. In the process, he graduated from petty thief to murderer.

Survival
A psychiatrist giving evidence at the murder trial testified that in addition to his obvious racism and psychopathy, Stewart was motivated by a need to win the respect so vital to survival in prison. He reasoned that the quickest way to that was violence.

The message does not appear to have reached the courts. There has been an 11% increase in the number of children between 12 and 17 in detention in the last 12 months as magistrates have embraced the government's detention and training orders. Of 2,929 in custody, 209 are in Feltham. Mrs Crook said fewer than 20 of them should be there. Her solution is straightforward: "Close the juvenile wing at Feltham, take the kids out because it just isn't working."

Richard Garside, of the National Association for the Care and Resettlement of Offenders, concurs. "There is a strong argument for knocking Feltham down and building a new institution in the same place," he said.

"We would be shocked if we found the same conditions that exist in Feltham in a Romanian jail, but somehow it is acceptable in south London. The time has come to accept that it is not."

webTitle: 'I'd hear people being beaten up and know the guards wouldn't do anything about it'

fields.headline: 'I'd hear people being beaten up and know the guards wouldn't do anything about it'
fields.standfirst:
Special report: race issues in the UK
Special report: deaths in custody
fields.trailText: Harjinder Singh, 23, served three months at Feltham in 1995 for GBH. He was later cleared on appeal:
fields.body:
Harjinder Singh, 23, served three months at Feltham in 1995 for GBH. He was later cleared on appeal:

The months I spent in Feltham were the worst of my life. The place I remember was a dirty, racist, violent place where the warders didn't care about what happened to you and were happy for you to spend 23 and three-quarter hours a day banged up.

On an average day, you got woken at around 8am. You would get up, make your bed, use the toilet in the cell and then go and get your breakfast from the servery at the end of the wing. Five minutes later you would be back in your cell with your tray. I don't even want to think about the food. It was awful. About 8.30am they would open the door of the cell so you could put your tray out, and then they would bang you up again.

Every other day we got a period of association lasting up to an hour. During this time you could have a shower, make phone calls home or have visitors. You could also pick up a book from a pile of about 100 that had been donated on each wing, but they were old and had pages ripped out. Then it was back to the cell until lunch, which followed the same routine as breakfast.

All there was to look forward to after that was tea at around 4pm. After you had eaten and put your tray out on the landing the door would swing shut again until the next morning.

There was almost no work in Feltham, unless you were one of four people in the servery or the four wing cleaners. There were about 120 prisoners on my wing, which means 112 people didn't have jobs. If you had work you kept busy. If you didn't, there was nothing to do except stare at the ceiling, lying in a bed that was curved, like someone had been lying there dead for years.

The place was full of kids, all of them trying to prove how hard they were through violence. It was a dangerous, frightening place. On my second night, I was banged up with this kid who started threatening me as soon as I got in the cell about 7pm. I asked to be moved but the screw just said: 'You go where we tell you.'

The kid started going through my stuff and when I tried to stop him he started hitting me. He smashed my face up. When the guard came round for the hourly check, I went to the cell window, my face covered in blood, and asked him to move me. He just looked at me and said: 'If you've got a problem, tell the day staff about it.'

The kid thought I had tried to get him in trouble so he beat me some more. He was shouting to his mates: 'I've got a Paki in my cell,' and they were shouting back: 'Beat him up, smash him up.' I was terrified. By the morning I had a broken nose and two black eyes and I had to beg a senior officer to move me, which he did.

Sometimes I'd lie in my bed and hear other people being beaten up and know the guards wouldn't do anything about it. I just used to lie there and cry.

I thank God that if I ever have to do time again it won't be at Feltham.

fields.trailText: 'CARDS ON THE TABLE' TIME
fields.body:
'CARDS ON THE TABLE' TIME

You can say what you like about Kelvin Koogan's Camp England - and God knows the Fiver certainly has - but at least the squad was always mightily entertained. If they became bored of watching Manchester United players not speak to Liverpool players (and vice versa), they could enjoy live satellite racing - which Koog had specially installed in the team's hotel during Euro 2000 - instead. And when that became a mite tedious, they could blow £10,000 in one sitting at the card schools which Koog encouraged as "a form of relaxation". So it wasn't the greatest surprise in the world when the FA's Adam Del Boy Crozier today admitted that things had to change under Svennis the Menace. "I have heard from people within the camp, including the players, that they are not close," he admitted. "Fundamentally, we need a change in the whole set-up." But no sooner had we heard from Crozier, we bumped - quite literally - into gambling legend Mickey Quinn, who told us there was nothing wrong with a bit of a flutter.

"There were card schools at every club I was involved with," he surprisingly revealed. "You have to find a way of relieving the boredom of a four-hour coach journey. I have never known it to have a detrimental effect on team spirit." Really? "Well, I guess if you were losing vast sums of money, that might be a bit divisive. But I have never seen anyone lose more than £700," he continued with a smile.

Mickey wasn't the only one taking issue with Del Boy, either. "It's unbelievable," said Phil Neville, scything Crozier down with a completely unnecessary tackle. "I read one story this morning saying that the Liverpool lads don't talk to the United lads. But that's the biggest load of rubbish I've ever heard because I know we've got a good relationship," he added as he carefully stuck a Panini sticker of Michael Owen onto the front of a nearby urinal.

FIGO FIVER

You only have to look to the past for proof of the Premiership's pulling power. Some of the biggest talents in the game have plied their trade on these shores - who could forget the joyous sight of Ilie Dumitrescu flying down the wing, or of Tomas Brolin flying down to the club canteen? And further proof of the exalted status of our shiny profit-making league came along today when world-record signing Luis Figo spoke of his desire to play in England.

"I will play in England," Figo announced today. "The atmosphere makes me want to go to England, because of the way that they live for the game." But although this is the sort of 'come-and-get-me' announcement which normally has Premiership chairmen falling over each other to get a signature, it is in fact unlikely that Figo will be arriving here too soon. Mainly because there's a £100m buy-out clause in his Real Madrid contract.

Anyway, even if Manchester United, Arsenal or Bradford were prepared to spunk that sort of wad on one player, the Portuguese winger's arrival would still not be guaranteed. "I started playing very young," explained a doe-eyed Figo, tuning up a violin. "Depending on how things are, I don't know whether I'll have the strength or motivation to be doing this for many more years. I'm on the last lap."

But there may still be a way. Luckily, poor Luis has put his thinking cap on, and has come up with a clever plan so he can hobble on long enough to realise his dream. "If I only played 20 or 30 games a season I could reach 36," he mused. A great idea, Luis, and good luck! The Fiver - along, no doubt, with people who have to do 40 hours of manual labour every week - wishes you all the best!

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"Bryan Robson has taken [Middlesbrough] to three cup finals and two promotions. And he could still have the potential to become a future England manager. Why not?" - Arsene, Arsene... where do we start?

WHERE'S CHRISTOPH?

Where's Christoph? Can you see him? Do excuse us, we're playing the crazy new fun game which has taken the world of football by storm. Maybe you'd like to help us spot the former Germany coach-designate Christoph Daum who fled from Germany soon after testing positive for drugs and losing his job.

Can you hear cheeky Christoph taunting us? "Nobody will find me here!" My, this is a puzzle. Wherever could he be? "I am in Greater Orlando, Florida!" So you are. Well, having completely spoilt our game, perhaps you'd be good enough to give us your thoughts on testing positive for cocaine. "No comment!" Oh come on. "I will make a statement through my lawyers later over all the accusations and the incorrect hair test."

Well, that's something, we suppose. So how are you? "I'm all right." Good, good. And you're looking after yourself, we trust? "I go swimming and jogging." That's super! Eating well? "A friend brings me food every two days." That's nice. I suppose you've been keeping up with the latest action in the Bundesl... oh look, he's run away again.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Fulham are preparing a club-record £6m bid for giant Anderlecht striker Jan Koller. The 6ft 7in Czech international will be put up for sale if his team fail to qualify for the next phase of Big Cup next week.

Coventry defender Colin Hendry is expected to sign for Bolton on a free transfer.

Tottenham winger Jose Domingues could soon be on his way to Peterborough, according to Teamtalk.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Steve Archibald has insisted that Airdrie's match at Alloa will go ahead despite provisional liquidators KPMG closing the gates at the New Broomfield stadium yesterday. Airdrie supporters provided a cheque for £15,000 to KPMG which has been accepted, allowing the Diamonds to play tomorrow. "It is business as usual and I am taking training as usual," said Archibald.

Blackburn have finally signed Brad Friedel from Liverpool after having initial problems securing a work-permit.

Alex Ferguson has admitted that his current deputy Steve McClaren is ready to take over as manager of Manchester United when he steps down in 2002. "It's not my decision but I think that the credentials are there," Ferguson said. "Steve's at the stage when he can make a step like that."

Roma striker Marco Delvecchio has admitted he nearly moved to the Premiership earlier this season. "I was very close to coming to England this September," he revealed. "Perhaps one day I will play in the Premiership."

Hibs manager Alex McLeish has won the Bank of Scotland manager-of-the-month award in the SPL. Hibs striker Mixu Paatelainen was named player of the month.

Republic of Ireland squad to meet Finland at Lansdowne Road on November 15: A Kelly, Given, Kiely, G Kelly, Carr, Staunton, Harte, Breen, Dunne, Gavin, Roy Keane, Kinsella, Carsley, McAteer, Holland, Kilbane, Finnan, Delap, Quinn, Robbie Keane, Connolly, Foley.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

BBC2: Attachments (11.20pm)
Feeling suicidal? Then this pile of steaming cack should push you right over the edge.

Sky Sports 1: Futbol Mundial (5pm)
All the world's a pitch.

Live Schoolboy International Football (7pm)
Children from one country play children from another country at a game.

Sky Sports 3: Hold The Back Page (10pm)
Four journalists battle to come up with the most outrageously jingoistic analysis of the last week's events.

Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Football (7.30pm)
Alan Green and Fergie - those crazy guys just love each other!
