fields.headline: Hasbro launches dot.com Monopoly
fields.trailText: 8am: A new version of the classic board game Monopoly will feature websites instead of street names. Claire Cozens reports.
fields.body:
Monopoly-maker Hasbro is moving into the 21st century with a dot.com version of the classic board game.

Monopoly, The .com Edition is being released in time for Christmas and will feature websites including Ask Jeeves, Lycos and AltaVista in place of the more familiar street names.

It is being released in the US market initially, but is expected to roll out in the UK next year.

John Chandler, head of marketing for Hasbro Games, said: "Monopoly, The .com Edition combines the fast-paced, high-yield world of cyberspace with the fantasy of Monopoly.

"The game offers Monopoly fans, young and old, all the fun of classic Monopoly with a decidedly modern twist."

Players can select one of eight pewter tokens depicting a computer monitor, a mouse and a cursor in place of the traditional dog and hat. The traditional Chance and Community Chest cards have been replaced with cards marked E-mail Just In and Download. Houses and hotels will represent online homes and offices and the bank has been revamped to deal in hundreds of millions.

But the aim of the game remains the same - to bankrupt your opponents - which may strike too close to the bone for today's dot.commers.

webTitle: Nov 3: Diary of a monitored social services department

fields.headline: Judgment day approaches
fields.standfirst: Are hopes that past reputation won't cloud appraisal of current performance premature?
fields.trailText: Back to work on Monday, having nearly got washed away by rain in Wales over the preceding few days. Tonight is the special policy committee discussion of the Barratt report and social services inspectorate (SSI) inspection of our children's services.
fields.body:
Back to work on Monday, having nearly got washed away by rain in Wales over the preceding few days. Tonight is the special policy committee discussion of the Barratt report and social services inspectorate (SSI) inspection of our children's services.

It's difficult to think about or do anything else that day. I don't usually prepare verbatim speeches for committee presentation - but feel it is necessary this time to make sure I cover everything about our action plan. Feel very apprehensive, as it could all descend into a bear garden.

As it turns out, the discussion is very measured and thoughtful. Members demonstrate yet again how deeply they have been touched by the revelations about our children's services - and the lack of safety for the most vulnerable in our care in the past - and how much they want to put effort into ensuring improvement and that it will never be like that again. Barratt says a lot about the organisation and the role of members as well as managers. He asks how we will be sure that the current plans will succeed when previous ones have been allowed to drift and fail.

All eyes turn to me. I deliver my set piece - and receive some feedback from a trusted colleague later who says that I am much better when I speak from brief notes than when I read a speech. (Mental note: to have more confidence in future and go with my instincts).

During its presentation of its accurate report, SSI makes some generalised comments that make me feel uneasy - about "the minister having to consider all this information and decide what he will do". I refer to the fact that I am delighted that government is becoming far more rigorous in its assessment of performance (vis the dreaded PAF indicators against which we got 66% acceptable, good or very good ratings) and that I hope we will be judged on our current performance rather than our past history and reputation.

Next day it's off for a two-day away session with the corporate management team - for the first time ever. Long over due and highly productive. We get through some really important stuff and get a chance to spend time together, including our new executive director of education, who gets immediately stuck in to the discussions. High note is beating the boys at Jenga.

 Lisa Christensen is executive director, social services and health improvement, for the London borough of Lambeth

webTitle: Israeli demonstrators reveal an alternative view

fields.headline: Israeli demonstrators reveal an alternative view
fields.standfirst: As Brian Whitaker discovers in Jerusalem, not all Israelis are calling for revenge against Palestinians
fields.trailText: As Brian Whitaker discovers in Jerusalem, not all Israelis are calling for revenge against Palestinians.
fields.body:
The placards say "down with the Israeli occupation" and "stop the massacres", but the 60 protesters on a traffic roundabout in Jerusalem are not Palestinians. They are Israelis holding a lunchtime vigil.

"We're here to show a presence," says Maurice Lazla, who recently finished at university and now works for a human rights organisation.

"Jerusalem is a right-wing city and it's very important that we don't surrender to fanatics and nationalists."

The demonstrators mostly describe themselves as radical left. They come from a variety of peace groups, including Gush Shalom and Women in Black.

They believe that Israel should pull back to the 1967 border and allow Jerusalem to become the capital of two states: Israeli and Palestinian.

"We're not asking for a compromise," says Irit Umanit, one of the Women in Black. "We want to give back what was not ours in the first place. There is no reason why we can't come to some proper solution."

During the vigils they get a lot of abuse from passing drivers, most of it sexual, she says. "Get back to the kitchen - that sort of thing."

Moments later, a van driver spots her "evacuate the settlements" poster and screeches to a halt. "YOU should be evacuated," he shouts. A policeman moves the van on.

Support from motorists can be harder to detect. "Someone smiled at me just now," Ms Umanit says, interpreting it as a gesture of solidarity.

Six schoolboys in skull caps arrive and a policeman, anticipating trouble, has a word with them. They unfurl their own alternative posters - "yes to settlements, no to retreat" - and try to block the peace posters from view.

A man sitting nearby is quietly seething about the demonstrators. "There can never be peace with the Arabs," he says. "Remember Hitler and Munich."

Adam Keller of Gush Shalom says: "The strange thing is that, when this outbreak of violence started, there was less hostility than there is now. It may be because at first people felt we could be ignored."

Most of the demonstrators have done military service, which is compulsory in Israel - three years for men and two for women. The law does not recognise conscientious objection, but religious women can do social service instead.

Unlike the United States during the Vietnam war, there is little resistance to military service, and the authorities are careful not to make martyrs of the few who refuse. One objector was jailed for three months but released early.

In October, a serving soldier, Noam Kuzar, was sentenced to 28 days in military prison for refusing to take part in action against the Palestinians.

He was released last Friday but, speaking to The Guardian on a mobile phone from his barracks, said that he is still waiting to hear about his future in the army.

Other radical peace groups in Israel include Yesh Gvul, started by soldiers during the Lebanon war, New Profile, a group seeking to abolish conscription, and the Committee Against House Demolitions, set up two years ago to help Palestinians whose houses are demolished by the army.

By far the largest organisation - but less radical - is Peace Now, started 22 years ago in the wake of the Sabra and Chatila massacres in Lebanon. It has, on occasions, mustered demonstrations of more than 200,000 people.

Its guiding principle, according to director Gaby Lasky, is "not to fight wars that are not imposed upon us.

"We want peace negotiations with all Israel's neighbours - it's not a one-border issue," she said.

Unlike the more radical groups, Peace Now regards the 1967 borders as "the basis for determining Israel's final borders."

Peace Now draws its support mainly from the centre-left - the Labour and Meretz parties. This, according to the radicals, has placed its supporters in a dilemma: whether to remain loyal to Labour or to cling to their former peace slogans.

Although many continue to back the government, "we have been very outspoken against a coalition with Sharon [the Likud leader]," Ms Lasky said.

"In opinion polls, a very high number of people still support the peace process - about 62 per cent. This has strengthened our belief that we have been right."

fields.headline: Cross-border meeting sparks cross talk
fields.standfirst: With another row threatening the Northern Ireland peace process, Derek Brown looks behind the words and posturing
fields.trailText: With another row threatening the Northern Ireland peace process,Derek Brown looks behind the words and posturing.
fields.body:
The latest snarling row between the Sinn Fein and the Ulster unionists is, on the face of it, more absurd than ominous.

David Trimble, unionist leader and first minister of the power-sharing devolved executive, has barred his two Sinn Fein ministers from attending the cross-border council which links the governments in Dublin and Belfast.

But one of those ministers, Bairbre de Brun, is going ahead anyway with a meeting with her counterpart from the Irish Republic. She says that Trimble's move is all to do with keeping the peace within his own party, which is deeply divided over the peace process.

To some extent, that is true. Less than a week ago, Trimble had to fight off yet another vigorous attempt by dissidents to haul the party out of the devolved government.

His bar on Sinn Fein is at least partly intended to show the dissidents that he can act tough.

But that is only part of the story. Trimble is genuinely exasperated by the failure of the IRA, as he sees it, to honour is commitment to disarm as part of the peace process.

His block on Sinn Fein involvement with the north-south council - the part of the peace accord which republicans like best - is more than a yellow-card gesture.

It is a very real warning that, unless the arms decommissioning starts soon, the whole process could unravel.

Some might say that is happening already. Ian Paisley and his Democratic Unionists are bellowing with rage about power sharing and the imminent reform of the Royal Ulster Constabulary, and are siphoning away support from Trimble's party at an alarming rate.

The unionist community in general is gripped by fear of renewed violence, not least between the loyalist paramilitary groups, the Ulster Freedom Fighters and the Ulster Volunteer Force.

Dissident republican factions like the Real IRA and the Continuity IRA also remain active.

In the face of such dangers, nobody would expect the Provisional IRA to surrender its arsenal of weapons. In any case, whatever the unionists say, that was never the idea.

But the group's sullen, sulky refusal to comply with the spirit of the Good Friday deal is both irresponsible and deeply worrying.

It has said that it will allow two independent inspectors to re-visit arms dumps they first saw in the summer. It will also consider contacting John de Chastelain, the Canadian general who is supposed to be overseeing the decommissioning of all paramilitary arms.

It doesn't take a mighty intellect to understand that that is simply not good enough.

The republicans cannot take the bits of the agreement they like, such as the all-Ireland council, and reject the bits they don't.

In exactly the same way, the unionists cannot reject those parts of the process they find offensive, like power-sharing and police reform.

What is surprising about the latest spat is that the two sovereign governments, which are, after all, the senior partners in the peace process, have done and said so little to defuse it.

It is odd, to say the least, that the Dublin government has agreed to send a minister to Enniskillen in the north for today's controversial meeting.

And it is odder still that Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland Secretary, now seems to be Ulster's invisible man.

fields.headline: Ford faces strike at Dagenham
fields.standfirst: Special report: Ford at Dagenham
fields.trailText: Ford is heading for a clash with its workforce after union leaders failed to persuade the group to drop plans to halt car production at its Dagenham plant in Essex.
fields.body:
Ford is heading for a clash with its workforce after union leaders failed to persuade the group to drop plans to halt car production at its Dagenham plant in Essex.

Union officials have called for a meeting of the plant's 7,000 employees on November 15. Strike ballot papers will be sent out on the same day.

The unions fear that if the company closes the assembly unit at Dagenham other Ford plants in Britain would face the same fate.

No progress was made during yesterday's three-hour meeting in central London between union officials and the company team led by David Thursfield, president of European operations.

Tony Woodley, chief car industry negotiator for the Transport and General Workers' Union, said Ford had not accepted "the sound case" to keep the plant going. "They intend to break agreements they have made."

When the strike ballot result is known, probably at the end of the month, the unions will seek a meeting with Ford and the government to discuss details of assurances given by the company about job levels at its other UK plants, he said.

The unions claim that Ford promised that the new Fiesta would be built at Dagenham. Ford has since announced that the car will be made at its Cologne plant in Germany.

The car maker said in May it would halt production at Dagenham during the first quarter of 2002 but would expand the diesel engine plant on the site. Since then it has reduced planned redundancies from 1,900 to 1,300 and reiterated its intention to maintain Dagenham as the largest industrial site in the London area.

Ford also faces problems at its Jaguar plants in the Midlands, where workers have rejected a two-year, inflation-busting pay deal covering 4,200 hourly paid employees. The workforce is thought to be opposed to the deal because it offers of extra money to team leaders on the shop floor.

fields.headline: E4 gambles on Japanese game show
fields.trailText: 2.30pm: A Japanese game show in which you can bet on beer-swigging tramps is just one of the attractions coming soon from C4's new digital channel, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
A man puts down a can of beer next to a group of tramps gathered in the street. Do you fancy betting on how long it will be before one of them picks it up and takes a swig?

Well now you can, courtesy of Banzai, a spoof Japanese game show that forms part of the line-up of new programming on E4, Channel 4's soon-to-launch digital entertainment channel.

Banzai, which is being made by Radar, will also give viewers the chance to bet on The Old Lady Wheelchair Chicken Challenge and celebrity games including Can Pat Sharp stay under water for longer than a genuine German?.

An E4 spokeswoman said that Channel 4 was developing interactive technology to allow viewers to bet on elements of the show via their TV remote or the E4.com website.

Other original shows on E4 will include Five Go Dating, a Donna Air-hosted format that puts five teenage boys and five girls together in a separate houses for a week. Over the course of the week each boy goes on a date with each of the girls and at the end try to pair up with the person they like the most.

Objective Productions has been filming the dates, along with the pre-date what-to-wear dilemmas and post-date gossiping and bitching that goes on in the two houses.

Endemol's dating reality gameshow, Chained, in which five men are chained to a woman and eliminated one at a time as she gets fed up with them, will also be debuting on the channel, along with a series being developed with Perrier New Comer award-winners Noble and Silver.

The channel will also include:

 Two new dramas, As If and The Secret Life of Us, for a minimum of 20-episode runs.

 Late teen drama from Carnival Films, which E4 controller of programming Kevin Lygo described as "edgier, more urban than Hollyoaks".

 The Secret Life of Us, which he billed as a "twentysomething Cold Feet set in Sydney", will follow later in the year.

 A daily pop music show from indie producer At It. The as-yet-untitled programme will be fronted by new young presenters and feature pop news, trivia, gossip, interviews and videos.

 Interactive comedy strand from TalkBack Productions that showcases new talent. It will include animated slot Celebrity High, about a school where pupils including Britney Spears and Daniella Westbrook are taught by the likes of Jerry Springer and Kevin Keegan.

 Generation E will be a regular documentary slot featuring one-off films from a variety of independent producers.

 The second series of Absolutely Productions' Trigger Happy TV, in which presenter Dom Joly, involves members of the public unwittingly in comedy sketches, is to be premiered on E4 and then repeated on Channel 4.

E4 will also showcase the second series of critically acclaimed White House drama The West Wing, savage Hollywood satire Action, and Emmy award-winning HBO drama The Corner, which focuses on the lives of a group of New York drug dealers.

fields.headline: MPs' websites slated for e-blandness
fields.trailText: A large number of MPs' personal websites - including that of e-minister Patricia Hewitt - are "sloppy" and "bland", according to a new report.
fields.body:
A large number of MPs' personal websites - including that of e-minister Patricia Hewitt - are "sloppy" and "bland", according to a new report.

And only a handful have seized the opportunities presented by the internet to put a message to voters and get in touch with constituents.

Researchers at public policy think-tank, the Institute of Economic Affairs, looked at the personal web sites of 97 MPs and found a "mildly comic ineptitude" in the construction of the sites.

And Ms Hewitt's own site is one of the most horrid, it claims, going so far as to suggest that constituents contact her by post rather than email.

The compiler of the research, Tom Steinberg, said: "To misquote Microsoft, this is business at the speed of politics."

The report, MPs' Websites, which was published in a recent Parliamentary IT briefing paper, goes on to state that Ms Hewitt is not alone in her apparent inability to utilise the internet as a political tool.

"Labour MP Gwyneth Dunwoody's site is typical, with its inept design, smattering of broken links and absolute lack of character.

"Normally, the party machines leap at the chance to put across a message to voters. In the field of MPs' websites, they have been curiously hesitant."

Of the sites studied for the article, few members are singled out for praise.

Labour MP Paul Flynn is "a triumph of irreverent style" and is "kept lovingly up to date", the report says - although at the time of writing, the site is down.

Shadow Home Secretary Ann Widdecombe's 'Widdy Web' features "a regular and fearsome stream of attacks on the government, plus a unique children's section".

The article argues that those who are less dedicated are missing a huge opportunity.

"The opportunity for a backbench MP to build up a good impression with constituents has never been as good as that presented by the internet today.

"A sitting MP who uses his or her site to educate and communicate with constituents, like Paul Flynn or Liberal Democrat Edward Davey, can build a better relationship and so hope for a degree of local loyalty at the following election."

In the future, the article argues, MPs' websites will give "a sense that the MP is an interesting, intelligent, likeable person who is more important than just a tiny cog in a huge political machine.

"No wonder the political parties are so loath to get involved."

webTitle: Kiss FM overtakes Capital among young listeners

fields.headline: Capital proving a turn-off among young Londoners
fields.trailText: 2.45pm: Capital Radio, the number one choice of young pop lovers across the capital for years, has been overtaken by Kiss FM for the first time, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
It has been the number one choice of pop lovers across the capital for years.

But now the station that brings Londoners the voice of Chris Tarrant every morning is beginning to slip in the charts.

According to detailed radio listenership figures out today, Capital Radio has been overtaken in the all-important 16 to 24-year-old sector for the first time.

The Rajar breakdown shows that Kiss FM has 694,000 listeners in the youth market, narrowly ahead of Capital, which has 671,000 listeners.

Capital remains the overall number one station in the capital, but Kiss FM bosses are cock-a-hoop at the news.

Kiss boss Mark Story said: "This is the end of Capital's dominance on the airwaves. We are celebrating in a big way."

Some say, however, that it is a sign that Kiss, once the voice of drugged out clubbers, has just got too mainstream.

Capital remains the overall number one station in the capital, but Kiss FM bosses are cock-a-hoop at the news. Kiss boss Mark Story said: "This is the end of Capital's dominance on the airwaves. We are celebrating in a big way." Some say, however, that it is a sign that Kiss, once the voice of drugged out clubbers, has just got too mainstream.

webTitle: Sky Global flotation on track says Murdoch

fields.headline: Sky Global flotation on track says Murdoch
fields.trailText: 1.15pm: Rupert Murdoch today denied that the flotation of his Sky Global Networks satellite TV operation had been postponed. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Rupert Murdoch today denied that the much-anticipated flotation of his Sky Global Networks satellite TV operation had been postponed.

Mr Murdoch's comments came during a surprise appearance at today's BSkyB annual general meeting in London.

Speculation has been rife that the float had hit serious problems because of French media giant Vivendi's decision not to sell its 23.5% stake in BSkyB.

But Mr Murdoch said: "The flotation will happen in the last month or the first month of the year, depending on market conditions. It has not been postponed."

He added that ordinary BSkyB shareholders would not have their shares bought out in the event of a Sky Global flotation.

Mr Murdoch's appearance at the AGM came just days after the Wall Street Journal published a unusually sensational article about his 31-year-old wife Wendy Deng.

It said that Mrs Murdoch was now doing more than just choosing the decor for their fashionable Manhattan flat, implying that Ms Deng was taking an increasingly strong grip on the running of the company.

Mr Murdoch said he had "no comment" on the Wall Street Journal's report.

webTitle: Lloyd's names lose battle against insurance market

fields.headline: Lloyd's names lose battle against insurance market
fields.trailText: More than 200 "names" - individuals who pledge all their wealth to back Lloyd's of London - today lost their multi-million lawsuit against the insurance market.
fields.body:
More than 200 "names" - individuals who pledge all their wealth to back Lloyd's of London - today lost their multi-million lawsuit against the insurance market.

High Court judge Mr Justice Cresswell rejected their claim that they were persuaded to sign up under false pretences and were the victims of a sustained fraud and therefore not liable for their share of the market's huge losses connected with asbestosis policies.

The judge said there should be an independent panel set up by Lloyd's to consider the individual cases of the more than 200 names who did not agree to a financial settlement in 1996.

The great majority of the 34,000 names who lost money as a result of the crisis over claims for asbestos-related illnesses settled after Lloyd's offered the deal which vastly reduced their liabilities.

His ruling came after a hearing lasting from February to July and which he described as part of the "largest and most complex piece of civil litigation this jurisdiction has ever seen".

Lawyers have estimated the cost of this hearing at £25m.

fields.headline: BSkyB racks up £100m loss
fields.trailText: 10.15am: With 4m customers already signed up, BSkyB is breaking the bank to boost its digital subscriber figures. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
BSkyB, the satellite and digital broadcaster controlled by Rupert Murdoch, is breaking the bank to boost its digital subscriber figures with £100m-plus in losses.

The company posted a first quarter pre-tax loss of £123.4m, against a deficit of £12.1m for the same period last year.

BSkyB said the losses were due to increased investment in marketing and programming its SkyDigital service.

The gamble seems to have paid off for the company, which announced it has 4.95m customers - up 450,000 - with just over 4m signing up to the digital service.

The company now expects to hit its year-end subscriber target of 5m within the next few days. The figures make BSkyB the clear leader in the race to dominate digital TV, with closest rival ONdigital lagging far behind.

Tony Ball, BSkyB chief executive, said: "Reaching our 5m target ahead of schedule is a fantastic achievement. We are confident that we are on course to achieve our target of 7m subscribers by the end of 2003."

The company posted revenues of £520m, a 33% increase on last year's £391m, boosted by a rise in the average revenue per customer from £268 to £286.

The all-important churn rate, which registers the amount of customers who do not renew their subscriptions, fell from 14.2% to 9.8%, though analysts said price increases will threaten that figure.

Anthony de Larrinaga, analyst at SG Securities, said: "The important churn figures will be those released in the first quarter after Christmas, when rising prices begin to kick in. BSkyB's 2003 targets will hinge on customer churn."

BSkyB is expected to go through a period of management and shareholder upheaval as the company is folded into Mr Murdoch's Sky Global Networks company.

The giant broadcaster, which will house all of News Corporation's satellite interests, is expected to float over the next few months.

fields.headline: Tiger, Tiger burning bright
fields.standfirst: Eight years ago he was broke and desperate in New York. Now Ang Lee is hotly tipped to be the first Chinese director to win an Oscar.  Andrew Pulver  meets the ground-breaking creator of Sense and Sensibility and The Ice Storm
fields.trailText: Eight years ago he was broke and desperate in New York. Now Ang Lee is hotly tipped to be the first Chinese director to win an Oscar. Andrew Pulver meets the ground-breaking creator of Sense and Sensibility and The Ice Storm
fields.body:
It has been a long time coming, but Chinese cinema looks as though it has finally taken over the world. From Hong Kong, John Woo has conquered Hollywood with Face/Off and Mission: Impossible 2. The art-film cognoscenti have long been enamoured of the precision craftsmanship of mainland China's Zhang Yimou and Chen Kaige. And, after years of trying, Jackie Chan has cracked the multiplexes (and wallets) of the west wide open.

But it is a softly spoken 46-year-old who is arguably the most remarkable figure of this dazzling generation. Ang Lee, Taiwan-born but a long-time resident of the US, has in less than a decade forged a body of work that has put him at the forefront of the world's independent film-makers. The Wedding Banquet remains one of the most profitable low-budget films of the 90s. Sense and Sensibility received seven Oscar nominations (one actual statuette materialised, for Emma Thompson's screenplay). The Ice Storm is generally acknowledged as the finest treatment yet of the emotional emptiness of the 70s "me" decade. And it is conventional Hollywood wisdom that Lee will be the first Chinese film-maker to win the best director Oscar - though whether it will be for his new film, Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, is anyone's guess.

In the flesh, Lee cuts an unassuming figure, a far cry from the stroppy weirdness of most American directors of his ilk, or the expensive suavity of other Chinese film-makers feted in the west. No Wong Kar-wai sunglasses for Ang Lee - he's neatly dressed but hardly cuts a dash in his suburban-store threads, and he never raises his voice above a gentle mutter.

On the other hand, he doesn't seem as bemused by Hollywood success as John Woo, whose discomfort in the face of the west's fan worship is palpable whenever he has to appear in public. "I feel very sorry for John Woo," says Lee, with real feeling. "I was glad that he did Face/Off, but I feel he is unhappy making this movie Mission: Impossible 2. I'm glad it made so much money, though."

Woo's blood-and-fire Hong Kong thrillers were achieved through the freedom granted by the armies of willing helpers typical of Hong Kong's film-making community; now, Woo has jumped straight into the upper echelons of studio Hollywood, where every line of dialogue and every foot of film is subject to executive interference and control. Lee, on the other hand, has trodden a much more measured path, negotiating his way through the more liberal environs of New York's independent film circuit. But even Lee has no firm answer to the question of how, exactly, the Chinese have managed it.

"It's kind of a chi [energy] thing," says Lee, deadpan. "Everything is rotating. I think this generation, wherever we come from, shares a similar cultural background. We're brought up with Chinese melodrama but through education or whatever, we turn to other things. Now, in the climate of a declining film industry, no one knows what to do. Then boom-boom-boom, one or two films catch attention at film festivals and a world audience and we just keep making movies."

Sitting alongside Lee is James Schamus, the academic-cum-producer who has worked on all of Lee's feature films. Schamus, currently associate professor of film theory at Columbia University, was there at the start of Lee's film-making career, when after six years of trying, Lee finally made his debut, Pushing Hands, in 1992. Schamus, a short, bespectacled New Yorker, talks lucidly about Chinese film-making's tradition of "cross-national transactions", and Asian cinema's propensity for "co-financing interface structures". Schamus gets excited about the reaction he sees "against an uninformed but well-meaning critical community, which has often tended to pigeonhole Chinese directors into a specifically art-house idiolect. So that if you're from Taiwan, you're going to be an Edward Yang or a Hou Hsiao Hsien."

At this point Lee interjects wearily: "Long takes..."

Lee and Schamus together are conducting a war on several fronts. Firstly, as they are both acutely aware, Far East film-makers are generally the preserve of the international festival circuit, and their highly crafted films win plaudits but do little box-office. On the other hand, it is a challenge to turn a relatively sophisticated Chinese movie into a significant international hit. "I have two sons in America," says Lee, "and all they care about in Chinese culture is Jackie Chan and Jet Li. Those movies present probably the worst, most raucous part of Chinese culture. I want to straighten that out. So my parental affection comes into the project."

Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon is based on the fourth "episode" of a five-strong series of novels by Du Lu Wang, and is quite obviously Lee's attempt to integrate Asian and American cinema. Filmed with all the aesthetic grace you would expect of one of China's auteur directors, it also contains the kind of spectacular, gravity-defying martial-arts action that Hong Kong's commercial cinema specialises in and is wrapped up with the sweetener of two of the region's most internationally bankable stars, Michelle Yeoh and Chow Yun-fat.

"Because anticipation is high," Lee explains, "I try to scoop up all the audience without disgracing myself. In Asia I have to deliver the film like a summer blockbuster, like a Jackie Chan movie; but afterwards I have to bring the movie to the west and release it like an art-house film, because of subtitles. I try to please everyone." He giggles. "I look at American movies, the big muscles, and try to apply that to Chinese film-making."

Lee's student years, in which he bounced from Taiwan to the United States, offer the perfect primer for his cross-cultural agility. Born and raised in Taiwan, the son of a schoolteacher, Lee spent two years at the country's academy of art, doing plenty of acting in the film and theatre department. He transferred to a drama college in Illinois in 1978, when he was 23; two years later he won a place at New York's crucible of talent, the NYU's film-making course. Though Lee excelled at NYU, it wasn't the springboard for him that it became for contemporaries like Spike Lee and Jim Jarmusch. He spent almost two years making his "thesis" film, a Chinatown-meets-Little Italy love story called Fine Line. But by 1986, Lee was so dispirited with America's lack of interest in Chinese-inflected movies that he was on the verge of moving back to Taiwan with his wife and son.

Winning an award at a film festival stopped him. In Lee's words, he'd become a "hot student". Six years of frustration followed, when one project after another bit the dust. Broke and desperate, Lee eventually heard about a script competition set up by the Taiwanese government and knocked together a screenplay called Pushing Hands, about an elderly tai-chi master living with his son's family in the New York suburbs. He also sent in, as an afterthought, a little number called The Wedding Banquet, which had been lying in his bottom drawer for a while. Pushing Hands took the top prize, The Wedding Banquet the second. Though Lee vastly preferred Banquet, the offer by Taiwan's Central Motion Pictures office to fund the prize-winner (to the tune of $400,000) was too good to turn down. In 1992, Lee finally became a film director.

This is where Schamus, and his company Good Machine, came into the picture, producing Lee's New York-based movie. Good Machine also came on board Lee's second film, The Wedding Banquet, which unexpectedly hit a chord with its unfussy, intelligent appreciation of immigrant pressures. Released in the summer of 1993, The Wedding Banquet became one of the year's most profitable movies. Lee then headed back to Taiwan to make the cooking-equals-love movie Eat Drink Man Woman, his first attempt at continent-hopping film-making. (Says Schamus: "Chinese films have a different way of working with crew and actors. The position of director is pretty much revered. It was a shock when we went on set in Taiwan, and it was all 'Mr Director this, Mr Director that.' ")

Lee's transfer to the big league came from the most unlikely of sources - an offer to direct Emma Thompson's adaptation of Sense and Sensibility, at the height of the mid-90s Jane Austen revival. "How can you resist working with Emma Thompson?" asks Lee. "In that film I didn't think I did anything new for myself as a film-maker, but I was bringing myself up to a new level. For an eastern director, it was the first significant western movie. Sense and Sensibility scared me because I had to prove I can endure a studio production, I can direct English language, I can work with a movie star, and so on."

With that success, Lee and Schamus next embarked on The Ice Storm, the adaptation of Rick Moody's 70s-set novel, which again hit a chord with audiences, this time wallowing in 70s nostalgia. "To me The Ice Storm was the newest period piece, a costume drama so to speak," says Lee. "It was very scary, too, because it was so fresh in people's memories."

Schamus concurs: "People working on the movie were so into it. A lot of the unity of the movie's design came about because of Ang's ability to organise all the departments together in pre-production in a way that got everybody behind the vision of the film very early on. It was quite specific - he would do thematic charts, every scene, every image, and we'd sit through these endless pre-production meetings going through every scene."

It's through comments like these that you can sense the ferocious single-mindedness that must lie behind Lee's easy-going facade. But in company with Schamus, he has clearly found a relationship that serves his talents perfectly. "I'm not a business guy, I'm a director," he explains, "but I don't like to work for hire. I don't like to deal with studios. I don't like to have conversations with executives. I pitch to the studio, then never talk to them until the test screening."

If, as everyone expects, Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon takes off like the thoroughbred it is, Lee will have cemented his place as a cross-cultural colossus, bridging styles, genres and languages in a way no film-maker has managed before.

And what of the future? "I don't know," he mutters in a quiet voice. "I can make movies for ever."

 The Guardian Interview with Ang Lee will take place on Tuesday at London's National Film Theatre. Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon screens in the Regus London Film Festival on November 6 and 7 (020-7928 3232) and will go on general release in January 2001.

webTitle: McG for Dreadnaught after Charlie's Angels

fields.headline: McG for Dreadnaught after Charlie's Angels
fields.trailText: Plus: Almodovar's UK foray on hold; Gere's still got it, says Swank; and Brad and Julia may repeat collaboration with Replay
fields.body:
 McG, the coyly credited director of the Charlie's Angels movie, has been hired to direct Dreadnaught, a marine thriller about a hi-tech Navy vessel terrorising the high seas, says Yahoo News. "It's a sort of 'David and Goliath' duel at sea, against the most hi-tech warship ever created," said the film's producer, Doug Wick. Perhaps if things go better on the project, budgeted at a healthy $75m (about £54m), than on the reportedly tempestuous Angels shoot, McG (pictured here with his Angels) will be happier about using his full name: Joseph McGinty Mitchell.

 Pedro Almodovar has indefinitely postponed his long-planned English language feature, choosing instead to film the provisionally titled Hable Con Ella (Talk To Her) in Spain next year. According to Screendaily, a first draft of the script is complete but no concrete details about the plot or casting exist. Almodovar had been widely expected to proceed with The Paperboy, developed in conjunction with novelist Pete Dexter for United Artists, but has shelved the idea for reasons unknown.

 Oscar-winning tomboy sensation Hilary Swank has gotten all girly over the prospect of working with Richard Gere in Taylor Hackford's new romantic comedy Julia Pastrana. Ananova reports the actress in raptures: "With all respect to Richard, when I saw Richard in films like An Officer and A Gentleman and American Gigolo, I'd be sitting there kind of breathless. I think he was and is to many women the perfect mature man. Maybe Harrison Ford can compete. Perhaps some women prefer Michael Douglas for something with a rougher, more dangerous edge. But Richard has such a margin of sophistication and mystery about him. If you're a woman he's the sort of man you'd want around if there was trouble. He's like America's answer to James Bond. Now I'm working him. It's just too much!"

 According to Mr Showbiz, Julia Roberts and Brad Pitt, already doing screen time together on Steven Soderbergh's Ocean's Eleven, are eyeing up the Groundhog Day-esque Replay up for the double whammy A-list star treatment. If they take the two leads, then Pitt would play a heart victim marooned after death back in his college days, where he must relive and rectify old mistakes, including wooing lost love Roberts. Unusually for Hollywood, the 36-year-old Pitt would be playing someone older: the character is 43 in the current script. Could Brad emulate The Insider and do a 'Crowe'?

"It's a sort of 'David and Goliath' duel at sea, against the most hi-tech warship ever created," said the film's producer, Doug Wick. Perhaps if things go better on the project, budgeted at a healthy $75m (about £54m), than on the reportedly tempestuous Angels shoot, McG (pictured here with his Angels) will be happier about using his full name: Joseph McGinty Mitchell.  Pedro Almodovar has indefinitely postponed his long-planned English language feature, choosing instead to film the provisionally titled Hable Con Ella (Talk To Her) in Spain next year. According to Screendaily, a first draft of the script is complete but no concrete details about the plot or casting exist. Almodovar had been widely expected to proceed with The Paperboy, developed in conjunction with novelist Pete Dexter for United Artists, but has shelved the idea for reasons unknown.  Oscar-winning tomboy sensation Hilary Swank has gotten all girly over the prospect of working with Richard Gere in Taylor Hackford's new romantic comedy Julia Pastrana. Ananova reports the actress in raptures: "With all respect to Richard, when I saw Richard in films like An Officer and A Gentleman and American Gigolo, I'd be sitting there kind of breathless. I think he was and is to many women the perfect mature man. Maybe Harrison Ford can compete. Perhaps some women prefer Michael Douglas for something with a rougher, more dangerous edge. But Richard has such a margin of sophistication and mystery about him. If you're a woman he's the sort of man you'd want around if there was trouble. He's like America's answer to James Bond. Now I'm working him. It's just too much!"  According to Mr Showbiz, Julia Roberts and Brad Pitt, already doing screen time together on Steven Soderbergh's Ocean's Eleven, are eyeing up the Groundhog Day-esque Replay up for the double whammy A-list star treatment. If they take the two leads, then Pitt would play a heart victim marooned after death back in his college days, where he must relive and rectify old mistakes, including wooing lost love Roberts. Unusually for Hollywood, the 36-year-old Pitt would be playing someone older: the character is 43 in the current script. Could Brad emulate The Insider and do a 'Crowe'?

webTitle: The net election: Gore misses a trick

fields.headline: The net election: Gore misses a trick
fields.trailText: Al Gore - the internet-savvy candidate with a slight deficit in the polls - has missed a trick over the net election. Chris Alden explains why.
fields.body:
So, the US election is four days away, and it's too close to call. Some say. Unless of course they think it's a solid margin for George W. Bush. At least we all agree that the candidates are diammetrically opposed, fighting an election in which the future of the planet is at stake? Sort of, except that anybody knows they are dreadful candidates, with no burning issues dividing them, and the whole thing is as important as the candidates' hairlines. It's the fuzzy election - to every assumption about the event everyone knows nothing about, someone else will put the opposite case.

That's fine, but this was also supposed to be the net election - the poll in which voters surfed the net to look for answers and crystallise their opinions. As the USA Today claims in its report on a Bush/Gore site traffic survey, that hasn't happened. Hits to the official sites have been low, as has web advertising by the main parties. If you're Al Gore - the net-savvy candidate with a slight deficit in the polls - you have to say you've missed a trick. Here's why.

First, users tend to visit not blandly partisan websites, but pages they get told about in the office or the pub. So The Bush Files, produced by the Texas Observer, attacks Bush's record in Texas but isn't that well known. Gore's gaffes, another attack site, has a similar effect, complaining that Gore is capable of unfortunate exaggeration. But the big hit has been Slate's complete Bushisms, which proves hilariously that Bush is prone to more than the odd brain-mouth bypass. Crudely, one up to Gore.

Second, voters tend to put their faith in statistics, especially user-led statistics produced by respected sources. To this end, says Wired News, Republicans have been making good use of online polls on US sites, by voting in them early and often. "To the extent that online polls matter in changing a campaign's momentum by indicating, at the very least, which candidate's supporters feel more strongly, the Republicans beat the Democrats handily," the article says. There's a similar effect in the autotrader.com poll reported in BBC News Online, in which users are asked which car each candidate resembles: where Bush is a Porsche, Gore is a Volvo. One-all.

Third, the internet tends to give a platform to minorities. But for the Nader factor, this might act in Gore's favour. But Ralph Nader is the candidate who has probably waged the most successful internet campaign, to the extent that a main theme is now how many votes Nader will take off Gore. The Madison County Times is even claiming that it is Gore, not Nader, who is the spoiler (story hosted on Alternet.org). No score, or a slight shift to Gore.

The knock-on effect of the Nader factor has been the kerfuffle over vote-trading online. Websites have sprung up telling people to vote tactically - that is, swap their Nader vote in a swing state for a Gore vote in Texas. Left-wing magazine the Daily Nation has backed tactical voting; other articles, such as this one in Slate, have questioned vote-trading's legality. At any rate, some of the sites have been closed down. There are even sites, also closed down, backing vote auctioning - literally, selling your vote to the highest bidder. A superb article, also in Slate, deconstructs the economics of this practice and reckons that, if the election was run by eBay, the richest politician would win, which isn't so far from what is happening at the moment.

Internet users, of course, are more likely to be swayed by the candidate who appears to be more internet aware. To this extent, says a study reported by AFP, both candidates have missed out by spending comparatively little on web advertising: an advert for Bush I saw recently on Slate, home of the complete Bushisms, was so novel it gave the impression of Bush looking confident on his opponent's territory. But Gore, of course, is the candidate with the convincing tech background, as this Red Herring interview and this Daily Telegraph article demonstrate - but as both also demonstrate, that exaggeration about "taking the initiative in Congress in creating the internet" still comes back to haunt him. So only a slight shift to Gore, and overall, not much to choose.

On the net as anywhere else, though, money talks. If Gore had spent more on the net, Bush could have spent more still. And as far as real estate is concerned, says the Detroit Free Press, the Republicans lead again - 2,666 Bush sites registered compared to 1,834 Gore. Next time around, the Democrats will have to learn to get their retaliation in first.

webTitle: You Bet Your Life: week twelve

fields.headline: You Bet Your Life: week twelve
fields.standfirst: Betting site Blue Square gave three Football Unlimited writers £100 each to bet with. Please God let them win
fields.trailText: Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £160.59, Sean Ingle = £103.12, Football Unlimited punters collective = £62.89, Paul MacInnes = £61.59
fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £160.59, Sean Ingle = £103.12, Football Unlimited punters collective = £62.89, Paul MacInnes = £61.59

Scott Murray: Middlesbrough v Arsenal, Arsenal to win at half-time £10 @ evens

Arsenal are playing well at the moment. Middlesbrough are not. Apart from a win at struggling Southampton, Bryan Robson's men haven't made off with the spoils since the opening day of the season. That's if you dismiss out of hand their two pathetic Worthington Cup victories against Macclesfield, of course. Which I do.

As well as being worse than useless, Boro will be without Alen Boksic, Paul Ince, Ugo Ehiogu and Keith O'Neill - ie: all their best players. When a team like this faces a team like Arsenal, the gap in class won't take long to become apparent. I'd expect the visitors to establish an early lead - and hold it - more often than not, so evens will do for me.

Sean Ingle: £10 treble, Fulham to beat Huddersfield @ 2/7, Watford to beat Grimsby @ 4/11 and Rangers to beat St Mirren @ 1/5

Finding the shortest of short-odds favourites in the whole of Blue Square's coupon and then combining them into a low-paying treble isn't a very clever thing to do. I know that. I really do. And yet, and yet

Having searched high and wide for value, I've found nothing that really grabs me. Liverpool, I reckon are reasonable value at 7/4 to beat Leeds. As are Roma at 10/11 to win at Brescia. And Everton to draw 0-0 against Villa at 8/1 also looks enticing.

But look at the three matches I have selected again, and ask yourself: do you think Fulham, Watford and Rangers will win against their lowly opponents more often than not? I certainly do - which is why I think the even-money odds available on this treble offers good value. Whether Blue Square's Patrick Murray agrees is another matter, however.

The Football Unlimited punters' collective - Stephen Cunningham: Everton v Aston Villa, no goalscorer £5 @ 8/1

Lets face it, these two teams could bore a glass eye to sleep. Neither of them score goals with free abandon and I don't expect that to change on Sunday. Everton are short of form and, Gascoigne apart, lack real creativity. They only look like scoring from set pieces.

However, Aston Villa are defensively sound and well organised. Southgate, Barry and Alpay are as good a back three as you will find in the Premiership and will not be too troubled by Everton's attacking options.

But like Everton, Villa can't score goals (although Dublin is adept at the odd own goal). Their last Sky game was a 0-0 against Sunderland, the 0-0 was nailed on that time and it will be no different this Sunday. Which is why no goalscorer, with own goals not counting, is the bet for me.

The Punter's Collective wins some money back - and it's about time!

Paul MacInnes: Tottenham v Sunderland, no goalscorer £5 @ 8-1

Brrr. That's the onset of winter by the way, and it has to be said that the seasonal chill has affected my wagering this week. No, it's got nothing to do with the fact that I've lost every bet since the start of the season, and that I appear incapable of distinguishing between a winner and a Gary Barlow single. No, it's all to do with the weather. So, without any noticeable trembling whatever, I can proceed to this week's bet.

Spurs are rubbish. This much is known. But Sunderland, meanwhile, have only scored three goals away from home this season. Put 'em together and what have you got? That's right, a rollicking return to form for the boys from White Hart Lane, and a hat-trick for Sergei Rebrov. But, having made my name by standing apart from the crowd (just trust me on this one), I will buck everything, including probability, and back a nil-nil draw. In fact, I'm not even backing that, I'm just backing a game in which no-one scores for their own team. It's so easy!

So why am I such a loser?

webTitle: In brief: Yeoh back for Bond?

fields.headline: In brief: Yeoh back for Bond?
fields.trailText: Plus: Bruce badmouths Die Hard cussing; don't do it, Harrison!; Hudson starkers behind closed doors; Tolkien costs spiral; Phoenix flame keeps on burning; and Temuera Morrison indulges in some Fett cheese
fields.body:
 Longtime Hong Kong action queen Michelle Yeoh's (pictured) star is on the rise in the West. Not only has she got the triumphant Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon coming up, but Ain't It Cool has it that her first Bond performance, the only good thing about Tomorrow Never Dies, may be rewarded by a second appearance in the franchise. Brosnan is pushing for her inclusion in the as-yet untitled Bond 20 and her agent is currently in negotiations. She'd be only the second Bond girl to return, after Eunice Gayson's double appearance in Dr No and From Russia with Love. Not counting Moneypenny, of course.

 After the recent news that Bruce Willis will no longer don his action vest, it turns out that the flavour of his remaining raucous projects will alter somewhat in the light of his change of heart. Dark Horizons reports that the forthcoming Die Hard 4 will - according to Willis - have more of a "human dimension and focus on emotion". And there'll be no naughty words. Hmm

 New York is awash with rumours about the state of Harrison Ford's marriage, according to the Mirror. The crumpled hunk was seen chatting intimately to Lara Flynn Boyle - until recently stepping out with another spring chicken, Jack Nicholson - at a showbiz bash earlier this month. And the plot thickened when Ford was this week seen checking into an NYC hotel on his own, just blocks away from the apartment that he shares with his wife of 17 years, Melissa Mathison, and his two kids.

 Almost Famous star Kate Hudson has revealed the sartorially minimal preferences of her family to, rather foolishly, the National Enquirer. Apparently Hudson, mum Goldie Hawn and dad Kurt Russell are all fervent nudists. "I come from a totally naked family!" she says. "People are weirded out when I say that, but it's true. We don't walk around nude when other people are around, but when it's just us, I've walked around my house naked a bunch of times." A dinner invitation to the Hawn household could be interesting.

 The mammoth Lord of the Rings production currently going the distance in New Zealand has brought an incredible $15m (£10.7m) into the Queenstown area alone, according to Stuff's entertainment news. The 250-strong cast and crew have spent three one-month stints in the area since last year, doubtless flooding local businesses with demands for on-set catering and extra costumed orcs to the delight of all. The total cost of the saga has apparently risen to an astronomical $500m (£357m), which must be making New Line executives rather less ecstatic.

 The River Phoenix cult carries on strong, seven years after his death outside LA's Johnny Depp-owned Viper Room. IMDb reports that fans laid letters and flowers and lit candles on the spot where the unfortunate Phoenix expired on Halloween, the anniversary of his death. One tribute read: "As a fellow actor I will always miss you. You were a very talented and gifted person."

 Maori actor Temuera Morrison has confirmed he's playing the father of everyone's favourite bounty-hunting Star Wars lowlife Boba Fett in Episode II. He told the Sydney Morning Herald that Boba is a pimply 12-year-old in the new instalment and that as his father Jango, he must undertake such paternal duties as kick Obi-Wan Kenobi's arse. With the help of a clone army, apparently. Morrison also let slip that he says the handily quotable line: "I'm just a simple man trying to make my way in the universe." Hmm: Fett cheese?

fields.headline: Hollinger readies Express bid
fields.trailText: Hollinger International, owner of the Daily Telegraph, is nearing the final stages of a bid for the Express Newspapers.
fields.body:
Hollinger International, owner of the Daily Telegraph, is nearing the final stages of a bid for the Express Newspapers.

Hollinger confirmed it had approached Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, the bank representing United News & Media, owner of the ailing titles.

Dan Colson, vice-chairman of Hollinger, said the group had contacted Dresdner for financial documents concerning the Express newspapers, with a view to making a bid.

Mr Colson said: "We have been dealing with Dresdner and we are waiting for United to provide our advisers with the information which we requested during the last week. They have to take an expression of interest from us seriously."

He added that Hollinger's links with the Express titles, which include co-owning the West Ferry printing plant in London, have helped stoke interest in a bid.

"It is not as if we are unknown to United, as we have several joint ventures in the company," he said.

If Hollinger decides to enter the fray, it will start a three-way bidding war for the titles, which include the Daily Express and the Daily Star. The Daily Mail & General Trust and the Hinduja brothers lodged £100m-plus bids earlier this week.

fields.headline: Priceline launches in UK with £2m online ad campaign
fields.trailText: 11.30am: Priceline.com, the budget online shop, is launching in the UK, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Priceline, one of the US's leading e-commerce internet sites, is launching in the UK with its first £2m online ad campaign.

The campaign, part of its £10m launch budget, asks shoppers to "Name your own price" for goods and services.

The ads will launch this month and run to January promoting low-cost airline tickets, hotels, rental cars and long-distance phone calls.

Organic, the online advertising and marketing firm, will create banner advertising, sponsorship and email marketing for the site.

It will also explore partnerships with other sites to enable them to sell Priceline's products and services direct to their customers.

John Baker, managing director of Organic's London office, said: "Priceline has an extremely exciting proposition, which has already proved popular in the States, and we will be looking to replicate this in the UK.

"We have a very strong background in delivering online campaigns and are continually exploring new opportunities to help clients maximise the advertising opportunities offered by the internet."

The US site now has 8m users.

Priceline Europe is a joint venture between Priceline.com - the US firm once valued at more than £12bn but now worth less than £700,000 - and venture capital firm General Atlantic Partners.

fields.headline: I-love-you.com is a match for soccer star
fields.trailText: 11.45am: Soccer star John Collins has invested a 'significant sum' in a new website selling gifts for loved ones. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Top footballer John Collins has joined the internet revolution and invested a undisclosed but 'significant sum' in a new website selling gifts for loved ones.

In return, the Scotland and Fulham midfielder gets a minor stake in I-love-you.com, which has raised some £2m in private funding to get the business off the ground.

The website's founder, Ronnie Henderson, former chairman of Guildford-based fund manager Premier Investment Group, said he had also pulled in a famous golfer as a private investor but refused to name him.

"He's currently playing golf at the Volvo Masters so I haven't been able to speak to him this week," said Mr Henderson.

"John Collins came on board right from the start, when I first started talking about the idea over a year ago. He ended up fleshing out the type of gifts we offer on the site and being a good person to have on board."

The site has ambitions to become the "UK's largest gift e-tailer". Gifts on the site range from chocolates and flowers to £180,000 Ferraris and £100,000 speedboats.

"We are trying to be a Harrods rather than a Woolworths," explained Mr Henderson. "We have a name that sticks in your mind - in fact it's one of the most memorable phrases in the English language."

He added that he was working on a number of distribution deals and wanted to launch an interactive TV service soon.

fields.headline: Weighing the issues
fields.standfirst: Election day in the United States is just hours away and the polls remain deadlocked. Which factors count in the final days of the race to the White House?
fields.trailText: Election day in the United States is just hours away and the polls remain deadlocked. Which factors count in the final days of the race to the White House?
fields.body:
1. Character
From beginning to end, the presidential election race has hinged on the character of the two candidates. Voters have big doubts about both Al Gore and George Bush : the winner is likely to be the candidate Americans decide they dislike least.

George Bush has been marked as a grinning, gaffe-prone airhead with little knowledge of domestic issues and none of foreign affairs. Rumours about his behaviour at university, his conviction for drink driving in 1976 and videos of him drunk at a wedding party have not helped his cause. However, the Yale and Harvard-educated Bush is no dimwit, even if he doesn't pretend to match Al Gore for intellect and has never written a book. In fact his amiable vagueness is an attraction for many voters: it certainly didn't do Ronald Reagan any harm.

Al Gore is leaden where Mr Bush is light, informed where Mr Bush is ignorant. His worthy plugging of the merits of big government means he scores well with the electorate on policy issues. But voters see him as excruciatingly dull: a sort of know-all teacher's pet. That is not the kind of president most Americans want and is the prime reason his campaign is in trouble.

As a result, Mr Gore is trying to show the softer side to his character, kissing his wife passionately at this summer's Democratic convention and even giving an interview barefoot on a beach. Will this do the trick by polling day? If it does, the White House will almost certainly be his.

2. Bill Clinton

The sitting president, Bill Clinton, will influence the result in two big ways. The Lewinsky affair and Mr Clinton's high-pressure fundraising techniques have tainted Mr Gore's reputation for moral integrity. That has been a big boost for George Bush.

Meanwhile, Mr Clinton's success in combining economic growth with a budget surplus has helped the Democratic cause. Republicans have found it hard to convince voters that America has been mismanaged while Al Gore has been number two at the White House.

3. Vice-presidents

The battle of character extends to the deputies. Both were chosen to make up for the weaknesses of the main candidates.

Al Gore is running with the Connecticut senator Joseph Lieberman . As a strong moral critic of Bill Clinton's personal behaviour, he has added credibility to the Gore campaign. Not least because, as a devout Orthodox Jew, Mr Lieberman appeals to many voters doubtful about the integrity of his running mate. If Mr Gore wins, commentators will see Mr Lieberman's selection as a key factor in his success.

Dick Cheney, George Bush's deputy, has had a lesser impact on the campaign. A prosperous oil executive from Wyoming, he has a long record of service in high office, including a spell as defence secretary to Mr Bush's father, the former president. As such, Mr Cheney has added gravitas to a lightweight campaign, but not enough to outweigh more pressing factors.

4. Debates

In a close year, the series of televised debates between the presidential candidates can swing the election.

This year, Al Gore was widely tipped to crush George Bush in each of the three 90-minute official debates and romp to power. It did not work out that way. Mr Gore's aggressive style in the first debate saw him beat Mr Bush on points - but polls afterwards showed that voters liked Mr Bush's gentle approach.

Mr Gore changed his style in the second debate, only to find commentators slamming him for letting Mr Bush's assertions pass unchallenged. In the third debate Mr Gore came out narrowly on top, but by then it was too late. George Bush had survived.

Meanwhile, the single vice-presidential debate resembled a friendly fireside chat. Overall, then, this year's debates have settled nothing. The field is still wide open.

5. Texas

Al Gore is pushing theTexas factor hard, claiming that his rival's poor record on education and pollution as the governor of the state makes him unfit to run the country. But Mr Bush's campaign has been just as eager to rebut all the claims and the tit-for-tat warfare is likely to alienate voters, not energise them. Republicans even point to Mr Bush's links with Texas as a positive point: unlike Mr Gore, they say, he is not part of the Washington elite.

One issue can't be hidden, though: Texas' rapid-fire use of the death penalty. Though both candidates say they support its use, many voters find the 150 executions Mr Bush has authorised as governor hard to stomach. Many others, of course, welcome the Texan's hardline stance on crime. The impact on election day is hard to predict.

6. Ralph Nader

Ralph Nader , the green candidate, has found himself under the media spotlight in the past fortnight as commentators have realised that he could deny Al Gore the presidency.

Almost all his supporters are natural Democrats, whose support Al Gore will badly miss. National polls put Mr Nader on 2-5%, which is bigger than the margin of difference in many states and could hand victory to George Bush.

As a results Democrats are piling on the pressure, asserting that a vote for Nader is, in effect, a vote for Bush. Will this strategy gain Al Gore a vital extra point or two in the polls? So far, there is little sign of it.

Pat Buchanan, the fourth candidate, scores only around 1% in the polls - but as an ex-Republican running as a rightwing Reform candidate he will cost Mr Bush some votes. Mr Buchanan is most interesting for his running mate: against expectations he chose a black woman, Ezola Foster.

7. Abortion

The United States has always been unsettled about abortion. Many voters and politicians abhor it, while others defend a woman's right to choose. Al Gore comes down in the latter camp; Bush, almost certainly, in the former. Some voters fear that Bush will appoint hardline judges to the supreme court, who will overturn the court's crucial decision in favour of abortion. That fear works in Gore's favour.

8. Big government

Many American voters dislike federal government: they see it as a tax-hungry monster dominated by a metropolitian elite. Plenty of other voters, however, depend on the services that federal government protects and provides.

The election race reflects this divide. George Bush, the natural home for big-government sceptics, has taken care to paint himself as a middle-of-the road moderate. And Al Gore, who really is a moderate with a long history of backing reform of the way government works, has adopted a more traditionalist, left-of-centre pro-government agenda.

He may look back on this as his big error. By moving to shore up the core Democrat vote, he may have lost the support of the middle-class voters who twice elected Bill Clinton.

9. Health Care

Al Gore promises action to control the cost of prescription drugs and to ensure all Americans have access to health care, a stance popular with older voters. It may be the reason for his campaign proving unexpectedly competitive in Florida, the retirees' state.

George W Bush says much the same, but then describes Medicare, the state safety net for the old, as "outdated". This kind of talk worries some voters, though it reassures others who would prefer government money to return to them in the form of tax cuts.

10. Taxation

The healthy state of the US economy means that government income exceeds expenditure. The dilemma for the candidates is: what balance should they strike between tax cuts and expenditure?

George Bush plans to devote half of the surplus "to saving Social Security one-quarter for pro-growth tax cuts; and the remainder to reform education, strengthen Medicare and support other priorities".

Al Gore proposes a complex scheme of targeted tax relief, covering things such as health care, the environment, business growth and college education. This has appealed to voters worried that a Republican president would slash welfare programmes, but alienated others who see Gore as an outdated fan of interventionist big government.

11.Education

George Bush has not made education a priority, in contrast with Al Gore, the traditional Democrat.

Gore's plan involves greater federal supervision of the nation's schools and a sizeable increase in spending - another complex scheme which appeals to some voters and deters others.

12. Foreign Policy

Foreign policy issues have not made headlines in the campaign so far, but events in Yugoslavia and the Middle East have pushed them up front in these last weeks before polling day.

Polls show that Republicans are trusted more than Democrats when it comes to standing up for American interests around the world. That's the good news for George Bush.

The bad is that no one doubts that it is Al Gore who has a far better understanding of world affairs. The question is whether Americans want a foreign policy expert in the White House. The two candidates' strengths and weaknesses on the issue will probably cancel each other out.

13. Petrol

The rising price of oil has hit American motorists in their wallets and they are not happy. The issue carries dangers for both candidates.

Al Gore has a reputation as an environmentalist who wants to reduce car use and regards energy taxation as a good thing. Voters who believe that he will increase petrol prices still further will be wary of electing him.

George Bush and his running mate have both made money from oil companies, which many Americans see as one of the causes of rising gas prices. They may turn against Bush for profiting from their troubles.

webTitle: Online betting service fails to float

fields.headline: Internet blow to Lis Murdoch
fields.trailText: 11.15am: Internet investment fund Oxygen has been dealt a blow after learning that a racing tips service in which it has a 15% stake has delayed its flotation. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Elisabeth Murdoch's internet investment fund, Oxygen Holdings, was dealt a blow today after it emerged that an online racing tips service in which it has a 15% stake would not be floating this year.

Due to debut on the Alternative Investment Market in October, Solomon Sports Analysis, the company, which operates horseracing tips site Sport4cast.com, was banking on raising £2.5m through the IPO.

The postponement casts doubts on the future of Sport4cast.com amid rumours that the original Oxygen investment of £300,000 had now run out.

Shares in Oxygen, which is listed on Aim, remain unchanged at 4p. They are still up on its IPO price of 2p but significantly below their 65.5p 52-week high.

The deal also comes as a blow to Ms Murdoch's partner, Matthew Freud, and Manchester United's Martin Edwards, who are also shareholders in Oxygen.

Oxygen, which raised £2.2m through its flotation earlier this year, also has stakes in fledgling Toyzone.co.uk and TV listing service Gipsymedia.

Sport4cast said it intended to make use of the delay to build strategic alliances in the UK and overseas.

webTitle: Race to White House reveals the big picture

fields.headline: Race to White House reveals the big picture
fields.trailText: The US presidential candidates have come clean on their favourite movies - Al Gore enjoyed Being John Malkovich, George W Bush liked Austin Powers and Pat Buchanan picked The Patriot
fields.body:
Tax, capital punishment, healthcare - all important, but the real indication of the most suitable man for the White House was this week provided by Entertainment Weekly when it asked three of the presidential candidates about their favoured forms of entertainment.

On the subject of their favourite movie, the threesome differed wildly, both in terms of how discerning their tastes and how often they appeared to catch a movie. Democrat Al Gore opted for Spike Jonze's skittish take on fame, Being John Malkovich (pictured); Republican George W Bush plumped for populist crowd-pleaser Austin Powers; and Reform candidate Pat Buchanan, perhaps insecurely, selected the jingoistic The Patriot.

As for favourite actors, Gore chose the sphinx-like Tommy Lee Jones, George W Bush went for the eternally roguish Jack Nicholson and Pat Buchanan digged all-round-nice-guy and bringer of salad seasoning to the masses Paul Newman.

Telling choices continued in the other categories with Gore revealing his fondness for Stendhal's saga of personal ambition Scarlet and Black for favourite book, Bush hawking his Everyman credentials once again with the news that there's always a place in his heart for Baseball Tonight (favourite TV programme) and Pat Buchanan letting slip his hankering for the music of Patsy Cline.

The full list can be seen at Ain't It Cool.

fields.headline: Californians maintain lack of interest
fields.standfirst: With Americans still making up their minds about who to vote for, Derek Brown looks at how the California media is calling the race
fields.trailText: With Americans still making up their minds about who to vote for, Derek Brown looks at how the California media is calling the race.
fields.body:
California is the Big One. Easily the biggest state in the Union, it commands 54 votes in the presidential electoral college - that's 20% of the total needed to win the White House.

At the outset of the campaign, most commentators assumed that the California contest was cut and dried for Al Gore. Even a couple of weeks ago, he was leading in the opinion polls by nearly 15%.

All that has changed: George W Bush is campaigning vigorously in the state and has poured millions of dollars into an advertising blitz.

Gore, his lead cut to around 7%, has been forced to divert his campaign from marginal states to shore up his crumbling support on the West Coast.

President Clinton is also on the stump in California - although, at the insistence of the Gore camp, he is keeping well apart from his vice-president.

The Los Angeles Times loftily eschews endorsing either candidate in the presidential race, but shrewdly sums up the contest: "The 2000 presidential campaign boils down to this:

"Either vice president Al Gore will win because voters like his experience and positions on major issues, and because he is better prepared to be president, or Texas Gov George W. Bush will win because he is more likable and believable."

Meanwhile, the paper wears its heart on its sleeve in backing the re-election campaign of Democrat Senator Dianne Feinstein. It particularly praises her for pressing for stricter gun laws.

The San Francisco Chronicle chides those supporters of Green Party candidate Ralph Nader who argue that a Green vote will not be wasted, even if lets in a Republican president.

"The election remains close enough that even a modest-sized Nader vote could tip the result to Bush in several key states. A Field Poll released yesterday - a seven-point Gore lead, with Nader at 4% - suggested that such a scenario was unlikely, but not impossible, even in California.

"Ralph Nader is telling potential voters who are inspired by his populist-left agenda to forget about pragmatism and 'vote your dreams.' They may find, however, that the dream is a nightmare."

The Sacramento Bee reports that Al Gore's healthy lead in the state is crumbling - down from 14% to a parlous 7%.

Part of the vice-president's problem is that women voters are shifting allegiance: "The most dramatic shift in Gore's support was among women. While the vice president maintains a still-comfortable, 15-point lead among female voters, that margin is down from 29 points in early October.

"Clues that help explain the erosion in Gore's support among women are hidden in the subgroups of female respondents. While Gore leads Bush by 60% to 30% among women employed full time, he evenly splits the vote with Bush among women not employed full time."

The San Diego Union-Tribune reports President Clinton's last-minute swing through California to shore up the Gore vote

"Clinton followed Gore's trip to California earlier this week. Their trips counter Bush's decision not to simply hand the state to Gore without a fight. Bush is spending millions on statewide television ads - some in Spanish to target the Hispanic vote.

"Bush boasted that he would shock the nation by clenching California's 54 electoral votes, a fifth of the 270 needed to win. George Bush, in 1988, was the last Republican presidential candidate to carry California."

The Coast Weekly in Monterey decries the widespread lack of interest among the electorate.

"This Tuesday, in what may be the closest presidential election in 40 years, just a tad more than half the eligible voters will exercise their right to vote.

"Americans, if they aren't actually indifferent to the democratic process, are giving a very good impression of people who are. Investigating the public's apparent disdain of politics has kept a lot of political and social scientists in work.

"The putative reasons that always make the short list are Richard Nixon and Watergate, Ronald Reagan and Contragate, and Bill Clinton and Zippergate. We suspect special interest money and cronyism have done their part, too."

In Long Beach, the Press-Telegram has no doubts who should be president.

"The closer comes election day, the clearer becomes the choice. If you believe you're better off today than eight years ago, you ought to vote for George W Bush. It is Bush, not Al Gore, whose message of inclusiveness and moderation and values has resonated with voters.

"It has become a remarkable irony that Bush, not Gore, is the logical successor to the great centrist Bill Clinton."

The Long Beach paper also has an exotic item about a speech to a local boys' and girls' club by a distinguished overseas visitor - John Major. He confided to the youngsters: "I did nothing at school. I just wasted all my time there.

"To be rudely honest, I loathed school and left just before I was 16, with no qualifications." According to the paper, the former prime minister was quizzed by the fascinated youngsters about his life and work.

One question concerned "the UK's decision not to join the European Community".
