President Clinton is also on the stump in California - although, at the insistence of the Gore camp, he is keeping well apart from his vice-president. The Los Angeles Times loftily eschews endorsing either candidate in the presidential race, but shrewdly sums up the contest: "The 2000 presidential campaign boils down to this: "Either vice president Al Gore will win because voters like his experience and positions on major issues, and because he is better prepared to be president, or Texas Gov George W. Bush will win because he is more likable and believable." Meanwhile, the paper wears its heart on its sleeve in backing the re-election campaign of Democrat Senator Dianne Feinstein. It particularly praises her for pressing for stricter gun laws. The San Francisco Chronicle chides those supporters of Green Party candidate Ralph Nader who argue that a Green vote will not be wasted, even if lets in a Republican president. "The election remains close enough that even a modest-sized Nader vote could tip the result to Bush in several key states. A Field Poll released yesterday - a seven-point Gore lead, with Nader at 4% - suggested that such a scenario was unlikely, but not impossible, even in California. "Ralph Nader is telling potential voters who are inspired by his populist-left agenda to forget about pragmatism and 'vote your dreams.' They may find, however, that the dream is a nightmare." The Sacramento Bee reports that Al Gore's healthy lead in the state is crumbling - down from 14% to a parlous 7%. Part of the vice-president's problem is that women voters are shifting allegiance: "The most dramatic shift in Gore's support was among women. While the vice president maintains a still-comfortable, 15-point lead among female voters, that margin is down from 29 points in early October. "Clues that help explain the erosion in Gore's support among women are hidden in the subgroups of female respondents. While Gore leads Bush by 60% to 30% among women employed full time, he evenly splits the vote with Bush among women not employed full time." The San Diego Union-Tribune reports President Clinton's last-minute swing through California to shore up the Gore vote "Clinton followed Gore's trip to California earlier this week. Their trips counter Bush's decision not to simply hand the state to Gore without a fight. Bush is spending millions on statewide television ads - some in Spanish to target the Hispanic vote. "Bush boasted that he would shock the nation by clenching California's 54 electoral votes, a fifth of the 270 needed to win. George Bush, in 1988, was the last Republican presidential candidate to carry California." The Coast Weekly in Monterey decries the widespread lack of interest among the electorate. "This Tuesday, in what may be the closest presidential election in 40 years, just a tad more than half the eligible voters will exercise their right to vote. "Americans, if they aren't actually indifferent to the democratic process, are giving a very good impression of people who are. Investigating the public's apparent disdain of politics has kept a lot of political and social scientists in work. "The putative reasons that always make the short list are Richard Nixon and Watergate, Ronald Reagan and Contragate, and Bill Clinton and Zippergate. We suspect special interest money and cronyism have done their part, too." In Long Beach, the Press-Telegram has no doubts who should be president. "The closer comes election day, the clearer becomes the choice. If you believe you're better off today than eight years ago, you ought to vote for George W Bush. It is Bush, not Al Gore, whose message of inclusiveness and moderation and values has resonated with voters. "It has become a remarkable irony that Bush, not Gore, is the logical successor to the great centrist Bill Clinton." The Long Beach paper also has an exotic item about a speech to a local boys' and girls' club by a distinguished overseas visitor - John Major. He confided to the youngsters: "I did nothing at school. I just wasted all my time there. "To be rudely honest, I loathed school and left just before I was 16, with no qualifications." According to the paper, the former prime minister was quizzed by the fascinated youngsters about his life and work. One question concerned "the UK's decision not to join the European Community".

webTitle: Downing Street behind call for anti-Tory tactical voting

fields.headline: Downing Street behind call for anti-Tory tactical voting
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Downing Street is discreetly backing moves to encourage tactical voting at the next election in a bid to drive the Conservatives further to the margins of the politics.
fields.body:
Downing Street is discreetly backing moves to encourage tactical voting at the next election in a bid to drive the Conservatives further to the margins of the politics.

A Labour backbencher today publishes a list of seats at which only small numbers of third placed Labour or Liberal Democrat supporters need to switch votes to oust the Tories.

The call is to be made today by Denis MacShane, the Labour MP for Rotherham and an ally of the foreign secretary, Robin Cook. He has received discreet encouragement from Downing Street and does not expect Tony Blair or the Lib Dem leader Charles Kennedy to call openly for tactical voting.

Mr MacShane recognises he faces a backlash from many colleagues who would prefer to fight for every vote. The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, has been especially critical of the Lib Dems, revealing he would have quit the cabinet if Tony Blair had tried to bring Lib Dems in after the last election.

The Lib Dems have been unrelenting in their attack on the the war chest of the chancellor, Gordon Brown.

Mr Macshane will nevertheless say in a speech in York: "Liberal Democratic and Labour voters have an historic opportunity in the next election. It is to keep the seats won in 1997 and focus our anti-Tory fire on the most reactionary Conservative party seen in over a century."

He will say Labour faces a choice between "a retreat into tribalism - with its attendant ritual of insults and incantations or the continuation of an inclusive politics based on radical, progressive, tolerant ideas and policies which a broad majority of the population were willing to support".

He will insist the biggest prize is to ensure Labour MPs like Phil Woolas, Lorna Fitzsimons and Stephen Twigg as well as Lib Dem MPs such Vincent Cable or Jenny Tonge are not replaced by the new breed of Hague candidates intolerant on gays, blacks and refugees and anxious to get the levers of power to dismantle social Britain.

Mr MacShane believes Labour voters need to look to the Romsey byelection result where Labour tactical voting helped the Lib Dems win a previously safe Tory seat. He will also point out there are 12 Tory seats where, if fewer than one in 10 of electors who voted for the third place candidate had voted differently, there would have been seven more Labour MPs and five more Lib Dem MPs in Parliament.

"All it takes is for a couple of hundred voters to vote tactically and we can push back the Tories to the margins of British politics. Labour in parliament has to be big enough to shrug off the cheap little Lib Dem squibs and gnat bites and show the British people that non-tribal politics in the national interest is what we are now about".

"Economic and social questions are not where the Lib-Dems are strong but they speak for civic freedoms, for increased tolerance, for respect for the environment in language which makes sense to millions."

House of Commons figures show that if 10% of third party votes switched to the second placed candidate - either Labour or Lib Dem - then 12 Tory seats would fall. If 20% third party voters switched, 21 seats would fall.

fields.headline: Priceline.com cuts 16% of staff
fields.trailText: Priceline.com, the loss-making US online auction site, announced that it would cut 16% of its workforce yesterday as the former stock market favourite lost a high-profile member of its executive team.
fields.body:
Priceline.com, the loss-making US online auction site, announced that it would cut 16% of its workforce yesterday as the former stock market favourite lost a high-profile member of its executive team.

Chief financial officer Heidi Miller is to step down after less than a year. Her move from her post as financial chief at Citigroup, one of the world's largest banks, to the "name-your-price" website had been heralded as a sign that online companies had come of age.

This week an investor filed a lawsuit against three Priceline directors for allegedly using inside information to sell shares before the public knew the extent of the company's woes last summer. They are accused of profiting by up to $247m from the information.

The market value of Priceline has fallen more than 90% since its high of $104.25 in March. Fears over continued losses combined with weak demand for its air ticketing services prompted the decline.

The shares fell in after-hours trading yesterday to less than $7 as Priceline said sales would decline in the fourth quarter. It also announced an expected charge of about $9m related to a warrant agreement with Delta Airlines.

Priceline said cost cuts as well as new share option-based compensation would lead to a further restructuring charge. Some 87 members of the 535-strong staff are to be made redundant.

Priceline was founded four years ago by entrepreneur Jay Walker. Bob Mylod, a senior vice-president, is to succeed Ms Miller. Priceline has also appointed a new chief operating officer, Jeff Boyd.

Priceline, which is based in Connecticut, lost $2m in the third quarter, which was in line with analysts' reduced expectations; it lost $11.9m in the same period last year.

fields.headline: Fresh storms heading for Britain
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Heavy rain will continue over the weekend and is likely to last until Tuesday, weather forecasters said today.
fields.body:
Heavy rain will continue over the weekend and is likely to last until Tuesday, weather forecasters said today.

Fresh storms are expected to sweep across Britain on Sunday and Monday and swell rivers and streams already full with the past week's rainwater.

The environment agency said today that the floods are the worst since 1947, when 700,000 acres were submerged. An estimated 3,000 homes are flooded and more towns face misery as water levels continue to rise.

In Yorkshire, there are now seven severe flood warnings, 70 flood warnings and 12 flood watches. The River Ure has burst its banks in Ripon and there is concern over the lower River Aire.

The A1 north between Dishforth and Scotch Corner is blocked with 3ft of water.

The situation in York remained the same overnight, with the River Ouse still 15ft above its normal levels.

The River Severn remains the biggest concern with areas downstream of Worcester likely to flood further. A severe flood warning is in force in the city, although the waters are thought to have peaked.

All rivers in County Durham and Northumberland are steadily rising and are on a severe flood warning.

The weekend storms will hit Wales, south-west and north-west England before moving to East Anglia and the south-east. With an inch of rain expected, the environment agency says that the flood waters will rise in the worst hit parts of the country.

The low pressure system behind the storms is expected to move across the North sea to the low countries on Wednesday.

• More than 10,000 residents in Folkestone and Dover were today told that their contaminated water supplies are now safe to drink. Flood water gushing through natural bore holes usually used to filter the water meant that drinking supplies failed tests.

webTitle: Chagos islanders were unlawfully exiled, rules court

fields.headline: Chagos islanders were unlawfully exiled, rules court
fields.standfirst: Map
fields.trailText: Indian ocean islanders banished from their "paradise" home today won an historic high court battle with the British government.
fields.body:
Indian ocean islanders banished from their "paradise" home today won an historic high court battle with the British government.

A representative islander, Louis Bancoult, claimed he and hundreds of others were unlawfully sent into poverty-stricken exile from the Chagos Islands some 30 years ago to clear the way for construction of the US military base on Diego Garcia.

Today Lord Justice Laws, sitting with Mr Justice Gibbs, ruled there had been "an abject legal failure" and overturned a 1971 Immigration Ordinance which bans the islanders - the Ilois - from returning to their islands.

Richard Gifford, solicitor for the islanders, said: "The government will now have to come up with a lawful policy in the light of the judges' findings."

After the judges handed down their ruling, the court began to discuss how the judgment should be implemented, and what formal orders should be made. If, and when, the islanders get back to all, or any part, of the Chagos Islands is now the crucial question.

The Foreign and Commonwealth Office was later granted permission to appeal. The court granted a seven-day "stay" on the effect of the order to quash pending appeal moves.

It was a stunning victory for Mr Bancoult, 37, chairman of the Chagos refugee group in Mauritius. After the ruling he said: "I am very proud. This is a historic day for the people."

Mr Bancoult has long fought for the right to return to where his people had lived for up to five generations before Britain entered into an agreement in the 60s allowing the Americans to build the major strategic air and naval base, used in the bombing of Iraq.

fields.headline: The Beatles Anthology: The Beatles
fields.standfirst:
Cassell, £35
Condensed in the style of the original
Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText: Recollections and recriminations from the Fab Four
fields.body:
John: Penny Lane is a suburban district where I lived with my mother, father and grandfather. When I was 12 I thought I was a genius. Rock'n'roll was real and Paul and I hit it off straight away.

Paul: When I wrote When I'm Sixty-Four, I thought I was writing a song for Frank Sinatra. My dad gave me ten shillings once; that's the only person in my whole life who's ever given me anything for free.

George: My earliest recollection is of sitting at the top of the stairs having a poop shouting "finished". As I said in my own book, I Me Mine, my earliest memories are of things like One Meatball by Josh White. Paul and I met on the bus.

Ringo: My real name is Parkin, not Starkey. Not many people know that.

Paul: John and Stuart thought of the name. We thought the Beatles sounded a bit creepy, but it had a double meaning. Like one of our favourite groups, the Crickets. You know, cricket the game and cricket the grasshoppers.

George: It was a bit of a shambles.

Paul: Now we were truly professional.

John: We were terrible.

Ringo: I never forgave Eddie Cochran for getting killed.

Paul: Hamburg was quite an eye-opener. A sex shock.

John: We thought our songs were a bit wet, but we decided to try them.

Paul: Pete Best was a bit limited.

John: I heard he was glad to have missed becoming one of the four most famous people on the planet.

Ringo: When Love Me Do came out we'd stop the car to hear it on the radio.

Paul: In 1964 we only got Nov 23 off.

John: Drugs were around a long time.

George: I was given the Illustrated Book of Yoga on my birthday.

Ringo: I'm not sure if we had a joint in the palace or not.

John: It sort of dawned on me that love was the answer.

Paul: Magical Mystery Tour wasn't the worst Christmas programme.

John: After Yoko and I met, I didn't realise I was in love with her. Until she told me.

George: It was an establishment plot to get us busted.

Paul: Yoko in the studio created tensions.

John: I started the band. I disbanded it. Simple as that. Good night and thanks for the bread.

fields.headline: Winchester turns film distributor
fields.trailText: Winchester Entertainment, owner of children's characters the Jellabies, is moving into film distribution, with its first project being the re-release of Raging Bull
fields.body:
Winchester Entertainment, owner of Jellabies, the popular children's characters, is raising £22m to allow it to branch into film distribution in Britain.

The first film it will handle will be a re-release of Raging Bull, starring Robert De Niro, at the end of this month. Up until now Winchester has only been involved in the sales side of film distribution in the UK.

The move will be financed by a share issue at 315p per share. Gary Smith, the chief executive, said: "The funds will be used to develop the newly established UK film distribution business, to acquire rights to US studio-released films and to exploit the group's increasing catalogue of children's television rights."

In addition, the money will be used for film development and marketing.

Winchester also reported its first-half results for the six months ended September 30. The pre-tax profit rose to £972,000 from £704,000 last year, but turnover fell to £2.41m from £2.87m.

The company also announced a three-year deal with Wind Dancer, which produced the series Home Improvement and the film What Women Want, starring Mel Gibson and expected to be released in the US in December.

The deal gives Winchester Entertainment the first option to be executive producer and international sales agent for Wind Dancer's films. Winchester Entertainment's share price yesterday rose 6p, or 1.75%, to 348.5p. Its year high was 365p.

webTitle: War on prejudice as China awakes to HIV nightmare

fields.headline: War on prejudice as China awakes to HIV nightmare
fields.trailText: China has woken up to a massive HIV-Aids crisis after years of government reticence, but a new awareness drive launched in Beijing will still have to tackle widespread prejudice.
fields.body:
China has woken up to a massive HIV-Aids crisis after years of government reticence, but a new awareness drive launched in Beijing will still have to tackle widespread prejudice.

Experts say that there are now more than half-a-million cases nationwide, says the official China Daily. Other estimates put it at 1.2m, although the number of registered patients is a derisory 20,711.

This week, health minister Yin Dakui called on Chinese society "to go to war against HIV/Aids", stressing that "men are particularly important in this fight". The new campaign is being backed by film stars and popular writers. And the British government.

"The disease is out there, families have got it," said Clare Short, Britain's secretary of state for international development yesterday, at the end of her visit to China. "We went to a household where two sons had died, and there was a granny bringing up five grandchildren... Many families also have debt, because they have to borrow to buy drugs."

Ms Short inspected a Save the Children project at Ruili in Yunnan province, which borders Burma and the heroin-trafficking region known as the Golden Triangle. Seven out of every 10 new cases there are linked to drug users and the thriving sex industry.

Observers claim many provincial and local officials do not share Beijing's commitment and object strongly to outside scrutiny of China's "negative side".

Chinese Aids researcher Zeng Yi has warned that local officials conceal cases and block research, while experts say the vast majority of those infected do not register "for fear of becoming outcasts".

In a grim example of the prejudice to be overcome, Chengdu city, in south-west China, has drafted laws to ban Aids patients and venereal disease carriers from public toilets and swimming pools. Fines range between 500 yuan and 5,000 yuan (£40 to £400).

But the worst still lies ahead. China's ministry of health says that without effective counter-measures there could be 10m cases by 2010.

Britain's Department for International Development is helping, backing a new project in Yunnan and Sichuan with £15.3m over the next five years. The project will stress the need for accurate forecasting so that China's health service is not taken by surprise.

The UN Children's Fund (Unicef), which is also active in Yunnan, warns of "an expanding heterosexual-led epidemic" in China, citing the rise in casual sex among youth and businessmen, and a rapidly growing sex industry.

The agency's HIV/Aids workshops have been set up in clinics, schools, karaoke bars and other places of entertainment. They have also been run for long-distance lorry drivers and even in a Buddhist temple.

Prostitution and sexually transmitted diseases were containedunder Mao Zedong, but they quickly returned when China opened up to the outside world and restrictions on social mobility and personal behaviour were eased.

Such diseases are now rising at an annual rate of 30% in the more prosperous coastal provinces.

"Many infected people patronise 'illegal' STD clinics rather than going to an official hospital for fear of embarrassment," says a recent report from Beijing.

Rising tide
Estimates of total adult HIV
1990: 10,000.
1996: 100,000.
2000: 500,000 to 1.2m.
2010: 10m.

Obstacles to treatment
Rural doctors' ignorance of symptoms.
Use of quack "Aids clinics".
Local officials suppress statistics.
Prejudice against sufferers.
Lack of privacy at state clinics.

Other estimates put it at 1.2m, although the number of registered patients is a derisory 20,711. This week, health minister Yin Dakui called on Chinese society "to go to war against HIV/Aids", stressing that "men are particularly important in this fight". The new campaign is being backed by film stars and popular writers. And the British government. "The disease is out there, families have got it," said Clare Short, Britain's secretary of state for international development yesterday, at the end of her visit to China. "We went to a household where two sons had died, and there was a granny bringing up five grandchildren... Many families also have debt, because they have to borrow to buy drugs." Ms Short inspected a Save the Children project at Ruili in Yunnan province, which borders Burma and the heroin-trafficking region known as the Golden Triangle. Seven out of every 10 new cases there are linked to drug users and the thriving sex industry. Observers claim many provincial and local officials do not share Beijing's commitment and object strongly to outside scrutiny of China's "negative side". Chinese Aids researcher Zeng Yi has warned that local officials conceal cases and block research, while experts say the vast majority of those infected do not register "for fear of becoming outcasts". In a grim example of the prejudice to be overcome, Chengdu city, in south-west China, has drafted laws to ban Aids patients and venereal disease carriers from public toilets and swimming pools. Fines range between 500 yuan and 5,000 yuan (£40 to £400). But the worst still lies ahead. China's ministry of health says that without effective counter-measures there could be 10m cases by 2010. Britain's Department for International Development is helping, backing a new project in Yunnan and Sichuan with £15.3m over the next five years. The project will stress the need for accurate forecasting so that China's health service is not taken by surprise. The UN Children's Fund (Unicef), which is also active in Yunnan, warns of "an expanding heterosexual-led epidemic" in China, citing the rise in casual sex among youth and businessmen, and a rapidly growing sex industry. The agency's HIV/Aids workshops have been set up in clinics, schools, karaoke bars and other places of entertainment. They have also been run for long-distance lorry drivers and even in a Buddhist temple. Prostitution and sexually transmitted diseases were containedunder Mao Zedong, but they quickly returned when China opened up to the outside world and restrictions on social mobility and personal behaviour were eased. Such diseases are now rising at an annual rate of 30% in the more prosperous coastal provinces. "Many infected people patronise 'illegal' STD clinics rather than going to an official hospital for fear of embarrassment," says a recent report from Beijing. Rising tide Estimates of total adult HIV 1990: 10,000. 1996: 100,000. 2000: 500,000 to 1.2m. 2010: 10m. Obstacles to treatment Rural doctors' ignorance of symptoms. Use of quack "Aids clinics". Local officials suppress statistics. Prejudice against sufferers. Lack of privacy at state clinics.

webTitle: Adam Faith quits Money Channel board

fields.headline: Adam Faith quits Money Channel board
fields.trailText: 11.15am: Former pop star Adam Faith has stepped down from the board of Money Channel, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Former pop star Adam Faith has stepped down as executive director of Money Channel, the financial TV operator he co-founded.

Mr Faith started Money Channel in February 1999 with an investment of £20,000, after fronting Channel 4's personal finance programme, Dosh, in 1997.

The company then linked up with City firm Killik & Co, though at the time it had no studios, broadcast equipment or a broadcasting licence.

Money Channel subsequently signed deals with BSkyB and Granada Media, but has struggled to attract viewers.

The news comes as the company posted deep losses in its latest results, sending its shares on a further downward spiral.

Chairman Paul Killik said Mr Faith will take up a non-executive position with responsibility for creative strategy.

Mr Killik said: "The board took the view that the principal management strength of the company should shift from experience in television media to experience in marketing, sales and the financial services industry."

The company said pre-tax losses for the six months to September were £4.8m, on turnover of just £294,000.

Money Channel, launched in February this year, offers round-the-clock news and features on the City and personal finance.

The company's shares have suffered since the stock market plunge in March, led by a loss of confidence in tech stocks. Money Channel's prime focus is amateur investors, but many have had their fingers burnt by market turbulence this year.

This morning Money Channel's stock fell 5.6%, or 2p, to 33.5p, against a January high of 548.5p.

fields.headline: 1950s fashion
fields.trailText: Fashion from the 1950s was self-consciously retrospective. The cinched waists and fulsome skirts were a wistful look back to a more luxurious age, namely a pre-war age.
fields.body:
Fashion from the 1950s was self-consciously retrospective. The cinched waists and fulsome skirts were a wistful look back to a more luxurious age, namely a pre-war age. The layering and resplendent tulle undercoats were a rebellion against the wartime rationing of luxuries. The look was of mannered elegance - porcelain make-up and sleek hair. This was, after all, the decade of the coronation of Queen Elizabeth.

Dior's New Look, which was launched in 1947, still held sway in the next decade. Women's bodies were shaped and contorted by the clothes, and the emphasis was on the tiny waist. But instead of the 1940s pencil skirts, dresses were flouncy and layered, often with complex cuts. This was about glorious, fantasy femininity, rather than the stern restrictions of earlier decades.

The 50s are making a fashion comeback next season, taking over from this season's love of the 40s. The catwalks have become crowded with A-line skirts, large cinch belts, burgeoning cleavages and elegantly matching accessories, from designers as wide-ranging as Tommy Hilfiger to Sara Berman. Trousers are cropped and neat, skirts swing in pleats at the calves, colours are pastel and innocent. The look is wide-eyed high school prom queen; key pieces include a poodle handbag, tulle underskirts and large floral prints.

High street outlet Jigsaw has picked up on this trend and, as of January, you will be able to buy 50s fashion - real vintage items, and modern copies - from selected branches. Fashion houses from the 50s are themselves making a comeback, particularly Balenciaga under designer Nicholas Ghesquiere, and last year Dior had one of its most successful years ever. Even today's most popular style icon, Gwyneth Paltrow, has something of the 50s about her: with her perma-polish and simple style, she is a blonde Audrey Hepburn. The 50s are the new 40s. I've always wanted to write that.

fields.headline: Overexposed...
fields.standfirst: ... Pete Tong
fields.trailText: ... Pete Tong
fields.body:
Early Friday evenings belong to him. No one's arguing with that. But lately Pete Tong, international superstar DJ, record label boss, A&R man, music consultant, landscape gardener (probably) is everywhere. As rhyming slang for going wrong, "it's all gone Pete Tong" might have faded from the lexicon, but never has it been more true. Flyposters for his new Essential Mix CD featuring the Burberry check are all over town, so much so that they caught the eye of Burberry themselves, with the result that Tongy has been signed up to model alongside Stella Tennant in next season's ad campaign. (Remember last season's, with Kate Moss "marrying" Lord Freddy Windsor in a check bikini?)

That's the official story at least, though we detect a conspiracy. Tong, after all, is the top man at the All Saints' record label. So did he make Nicole wear that horrid hankie on her head in Those Liam Photos in order to secure the modelling gig? ("Oh go on, Nic, I've always wanted to be a model.")

Who knows? One thing's for sure: it's all going Pete Tong at Burberry. Lovely clothes, Roberto, but That Check is fast approaching meltdown, having lodged itself firmly in the marketing niche known as Fashion for Shouty People, and their latest invite proudly summons us to an evening featuring "live music from DJ Pete Tong". Live music? Can't wait for him to stroll in with a guitar case. He continues.

webTitle: Style: The truth about Tony's tailor

fields.headline: Shirt tales
fields.standfirst: He's famed for his little blue numbers and now we know where he buys them.  Charlie Porter  reveals the truth about Tony's tailor
fields.trailText: He's famed for his little blue numbers and now we know where he buys them. Charlie Porter reveals the truth about Tony's tailor
fields.body:
"I am the master, I'm Raja you know," booms Raja Daswani, co-owner of Raja Fashions, which claims to be the largest tailor in Hong Kong. Forty-two-year-old Daswani, who this week took an order of six shirts for Tony Blair, is in his temporary atelier, a suite at London's Sheraton Park Tower hotel. He is striding over to his next customer, minutes after emailing his last sell (£900 for a couple of sports jackets, some trousers, a suit and two shirts, all bespoke) to his warehouse in Hong Kong, where his clothes are cut, stitched and mailed out in four weeks. Around the suite there are more clients waiting - one on a sofa, the others perched on a bed next door.

"I never mention names," says Daswani, who refuses to confirm Tony Blair's three blue and three white Sea Island cotton shirts at £35 each, the measurements apparently taken from one of Tony's old shirts. "I supply the Who's Who of London, but in my business it's confidential."

Daswani and his three tailors spend most of the year travelling the world, providing their bargain bespoke (suits start at £99) to a word-of-mouth clientele. The service is fast, breezy and, to some people, less intimidating than the traditional Savile Row and Jermyn Street service.

To compare, Jermyn Street's Hilditch & Key offer a made-to-measure shirt for £145 - but a customer must buy a minimum of six shirts. "And you know Savile Row suits are made in the far east anyway," declares Daswani, though he provides no evidence to back up this contentious claim. "We produce similar quality suits for a much, much better price. We work nonstop!"

The customers bustling around the rooms can't believe their luck. "I saw a small advert in the papers the other week and made an appointment," says an Oxford-based gent, whose wife is sat against the window with views out to Crystal Palace, choosing between aubergine and rose-red fabric for her just-measured jacket. "I had two suits made in Hong Kong twelve years ago and they're still brilliant," he explains.

Daswani approaches. "I need your charge card."

"You haven't told me the damage yet," blusters the gent. "Do I get a discount for cash?"

"Charge card only. We're an offshore company. Pay in Hong Kong dollars."

This extreme version of travelling salesmanship exploits a niche in the market. Businessmen have always taken advantage of the cheap tailoring in the far east, where streets are lined with knock-down price, quick turnaround stores. As his clients can't always get to Raja Fashions in Kowloon, Daswani brings Raja Fashions to them, with startling efficiency. In an intense burst of activity, thousands of measurements are taken during a week's stay in London, then emailed immediately to his tailors, along with a scanned photograph of the client.

The speed does not take away any of the detailing - one portly customer demands an outsized watch pocket in his trousers and, against Daswani's wishes, keeps his jacket sleeves over the wrists, even though a well-known sign of a bespoke suit is a precise half-inch of shirt peeking out.

The service provided by Raja Fashions isn't unique, it's just cheap and hi-tech. As well as arranging hotel fittings with visiting businessmen, London tailors often spend time abroad, taking advantage of the Jermyn Street and Savile Row legacy.

"A lot of Americans like to be individuals and they like British shirts," says Roger Talbot, general manager of Hilditch & Key. Talbot has just returned from his bi-annual trip to America, writing individually to his clients to alert them of his arrival, then staking base-camp in New York and Washington hotels. Newly revitalised fashion houses are trading on the "bespoke" heritage, too - at their recently opened Bond Street flagship, Burberry offer a made-to-measure and bespoke suit service, with prices from £599 to £2,000.

But it is the peculiar, guilty psychology of buying bespoke at a cheaper price than off-the-peg that makes Blair's order so intriguing. His choice is in direct contrast to those of his two main rivals, William Hague and Gordon Brown. Hague caused a furore in August when he told GQ that his shoes were made bespoke at GJ Cleverly in Royal Arcade, off Bond Street, for £1,500, presumably as advised by his late friend, the dapper John Morgan. And Brown has bespoke suits made at Savile Row tailor Norton & Townsend, where a three-piece costs up to £1,200. But then, with Brown's more wayward figure, perhaps he needs the impression of corrective surgery that only ingenious tailoring can provide.

Once you get past the stigma, Daswani offers a refreshing and sometimes thrilling service. Author Beryl Bainbridge has admitted to having a suit made - hers took "five minutes" to measure and fitted her "perfectly". Clearly one client who didn't mind being associated with cut-price tailoring, she was especially impressed that her name was stitched inside in gold thread.

Daswani is in London until Sunday, before flying off to New York. He will be back in this country in December. Pre-Christmas is his busiest time and Daswani doesn't expect to see his family in Hong Kong for any length of time until the New Year. But to satisfy his clients while he's away, Daswani has set up a shirt service on the internet, at www.eshirts.com.hk, which offers shirts with a more remote service.

"This is our twentieth time here in two years," says Daswani, who shows no sign of fatigue or boredom at his life on the move. "We leave here on Sunday and we're fully booked. We'd love to stay, but we've got to go and clothe the other people in the world."

Additional reporting: Hadley Freeman

 Raja Fashions will be at London's Sheraton Park Tower hotel (020-7235 8050) on December 4-10 and Birmingham's Hyatt Regency hotel (0121 643 1234) on December 11 and 12. Appointment enquiries will be dealt with then.

webTitle: Channel 4 sets January date for E4 launch

fields.headline: Channel 4 sets January date for E4 launch
fields.trailText: 10.45am: Channel 4's new digital entertainment network, E4, is to launch on January 18, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Channel 4's new digital entertainment network, E4, is to launch on January 18.

The service will open with a 12-hour daily schedule between 4pm and 4am. The channel will have a soft launch in January with hard launch to follow in March.

The station announced that it has signed a distribution deal for E4 with the cable company NTL and is negotiating carriage with TeleWest, Sky Digital and ONdigital.

E4, which is being offered as a basic tier subscription service, will be the new home for first-run series of Friends, ER and Sex and the City.

Channel 4 entertainment website e4.com will also launch in January, alongside the E4 TV channel.

More to follow....

webTitle: Barclays/Nomura joint shopping mall, Indigosquare.com, launched

fields.headline: Barclays/Nomura shopping portal launches
fields.trailText:
10.30am: Indigosquare.com, the online shopping mall jointly financed by Barclays Bank and Nomura International, launches today. Amy Vickers reports.

October 31: Barclays in Nomura joint venture
fields.body:
Barclays Bank has earmarked a marketing budget of £10m for the first year of its new online shopping mall, Indigosquare.com.

Indigosquare.com, which launched today, has set itself a target of 500,000 shoppers by the end of next year.

The ambitious plan is to have more than 1m products on offer from some 100 retailers by Christmas.

The mall, a £30m joint venture between Barclaycard and bankers Nomura International, replaces Barclays' five-year-old shopping mall, BarclaySquare - the first UK web shopping portal.

Nomura will initially hold a 60% stake for its £10m investment, while Barclays will be able to build its stake to a maximum of 67% at any future exit point or IPO.

webTitle: Bush admits to drink driving charge

fields.headline: Bush admits to drink driving charge
fields.standfirst:
Special report: America decides

Graphic: See Bush's court records
fields.trailText: US presidential candidate George W Bush has admitted to a drink driving conviction but insists the revelation will not damage his chances in Tuesday's election
fields.body:
US presidential candidate George W Bush has admitted to a drink driving conviction but insists the revelation will not damage his chances in Tuesday's election

Mr Bush was arrested 24 years ago near his family's summer home in Maine after driving away from a bar where he had been drinking beer. He was fined $150 and banned from driving in Maine for a short period

The disclosure came in a report last night on the US cable channel Fox News. He said he had chosen to keep the incident private to protect his daughters.

Mr Bush, who was 30-years-old at the time, questioned the timing of the revelation.

"I do find it interesting that it's come out four or five days before the election," he said during a hastily arranged news conference, his first in months of campaigning.

He refused to name his top suspect, saying only, "I have my suspicions."

Chris Lehane, a spokesman for Democratic rival Al Gore, denied involvement. "We had absolutely nothing to do with this," he said.

Mr Bush said he was not proud of the arrest.

"I said that years ago I made some mistakes. I occasionally drank too much and I did on that night,"

"I have been very candid about my past. I've said I've made mistakes in the past. People know that. They've thought about that. They're making their minds up now," he added.

Mr Bush, 54, has previously refused to answer questions about "youthful indiscretions," including whether he used illegal drugs in the 1960s and early 1970s.

He said he stopped drinking the day after his 40th birthday on July 6, 1986. Alcohol "was beginning to compete for my affections," he told an interviewer in September.

fields.bodyText: US presidential candidate George W Bush has admitted to a drink driving conviction but insists the revelation will not damage his chances in Tuesday's election Mr Bush was arrested 24 years ago near his family's summer home in Maine after driving away from a bar where he had been drinking beer. He was fined $150 and banned from driving in Maine for a short period The disclosure came in a report last night on the US cable channel Fox News. He said he had chosen to keep the incident private to protect his daughters. Mr Bush, who was 30-years-old at the time, questioned the timing of the revelation. "I do find it interesting that it's come out four or five days before the election," he said during a hastily arranged news conference, his first in months of campaigning. He refused to name his top suspect, saying only, "I have my suspicions." Chris Lehane, a spokesman for Democratic rival Al Gore, denied involvement. "We had absolutely nothing to do with this," he said. Mr Bush said he was not proud of the arrest. "I said that years ago I made some mistakes. I occasionally drank too much and I did on that night," "I have been very candid about my past. I've said I've made mistakes in the past. People know that. They've thought about that. They're making their minds up now," he added. Mr Bush, 54, has previously refused to answer questions about "youthful indiscretions," including whether he used illegal drugs in the 1960s and early 1970s. He said he stopped drinking the day after his 40th birthday on July 6, 1986. Alcohol "was beginning to compete for my affections," he told an interviewer in September. webTitle: Nader threatens to produce Gore's nadir

fields.headline: Nader threatens to produce Gore's nadir
fields.standfirst: Few observers think about third parties in US presidential races, but, as Martin Kettle explains, their candidates can have a major effect
fields.trailText: Few observers think about third parties in US presidential races, but, as Martin Kettle explains, their candidates can have a major effect.
fields.body:
Ross Perot. Remember him? The Texas oil billionaire with the small frame and the huge ego won almost 20m votes in the 1992 presidential election, running as a right-wing populist outsider.

His 19 per cent share as a third-party candidate devastated President George Bush's re-election effort.

It enabled Bill Clinton to seize the presidency. For the Republican Party, which believed that it owned America's future, it was a shock from which the party has not yet recovered.

Perot proved two things in 1992. He showed that there were millions of Americans outside the two-party electoral system. They voted for him in droves in 1992, pushing the turnout total to a record high.

And Perot also showed that a vote for a strong third-party candidate was not necessarily a wasted vote at all.

Perot's votes, after all, decided the election. The problem was that they gave the victory to the man they least wanted to win it.

Four years later, Perot had a second go, and proved something else. He proved that lightning doesn't strike in the same place twice.

In the 1996 election, he polled 8m votes and took 8% of the total. This time, Clinton's comfortable re-election margin over Bob Dole exceeded Perot's share.

It wasn't a good year for third parties. A guy called Ralph Nader, running as the Green candidate, took just 0.7%.

Perot had run out of gas, even though the Reform Party had qualified for federal funding in 2000 on the strength of his showing. This time around, though, Perot has remained silent and inaccessible.

Throughout the long months in which his supporters struggled in vain to prevent Pat Buchanan's conservative takeover of his party, Perot sat in his tent, doing nothing.

Last night, Perot's ego finally got the better of his sulk. He broke his long silence to go on CNN's Larry King Live, where he endorsed George W Bush as the only man who could bring the country together and as the only candidate fit to lead Americans into war.

For Buchanan he had nothing but contempt.

Perot still looks the same. He still says the same things. He still has the self-important certainty that only billions of dollars can give a man.

But he doesn't matter any more, and nor does the party that he created, and whose decline he has been powerless to prevent. Their moment was then.

But this is now. Earlier this year, Buchanan looked as if he might be a significant figure in the 2000 election calculus.

He appeared capable, polls implied, of winning enough votes both to weaken Bush's victory chances and to requalify the Reform Party for federal funding in 2004.

But the capture of the party at the Long Beach convention in August was a completely pyrrhic victory for Buchanan. He has dwindled to utter insignificance.

He is a toothless laughing stock who will be lucky to win 1% in the polls on Tuesday, never mind the 5% he needs for federal funding next time around.

Buchanan's collapse goes some way to explain why Bush is the favourite to win on November 7. Even if Buchanan was running at a modest 3 or 4%, Bush's current poll lead over Gore - 47% to 43% on last night's polls - would be almost entirely neutralised. But it isn't.

And what's more, Al Gore is suffering precisely that problem from the revived Ralph Nader.

After two elections that the left won because the right was split, there is a certain reciprocity in what is happening in 2000. This time, it is the left that is split.

Nader hovers at 3 or 4% in most national polls, which has been enough to keep Gore in second place throughout most of the last month.

As a result, the Gore strategy has been to focus in a key group of winnable states that can supply an electoral college majority. But Nader stands in Gore's way there too.

His strong states - Washington, Oregon, Minnesota, Wisconsin and Maine - are states Gore needs to win.

Local polls show that strong Nader showings in only one of these five might make the difference in the electoral college by handing a normally Democratic state to Bush rather than Gore.

Nader has proved this year what Perot found eight years ago. There are a lot of people outside the two parties, but votes for a strong third party can hand the election to the "real" enemy.

There is very little sign in the polls that Nader is being squeezed in the final days of the campaign. He seems certain to do far better than he did in 1996.

If he does, then the Clinton presidency will end in a mirror image of the circumstances in which it began. Ross Perot, a natural man of the right, handed the presidency to Bill Clinton.

Ralph Nader, a natural man of the left, is about to hand it to George W Bush. Never let it be said that a third party vote is a wasted vote.

fields.headline: Obituary: Sir Steven Runciman
fields.standfirst: Historian whose magisterial works transformed our understanding of Byzantium, the medieval church and the crusades
fields.trailText: Sir Steven Runciman, the historian, aesthete and traveller, who has died aged 97, was the pre-eminent British specialist of the Byzantine empire and of the crusades. His three-volume A History Of The Crusades, published between 1951 and 1954, set out to exemplify his belief that the main duty of the historian was "to attempt to record, in one sweeping sequence, the greater events and movements that have swayed the destinies of man," and show that history's aim was to give a deeper understanding of humanity. fields.body:
Sir Steven Runciman, the historian, aesthete and traveller, who has died aged 97, was the pre-eminent British specialist of the Byzantine empire and of the crusades. His three-volume A History Of The Crusades, published between 1951 and 1954, set out to exemplify his belief that the main duty of the historian was "to attempt to record, in one sweeping sequence, the greater events and movements that have swayed the destinies of man," and show that history's aim was to give a deeper understanding of humanity. He aimed as much at a non- specialist audience as at fellow academics.

For Runciman, the crusades were the last of the barbarian invasions; their disaster was their failure to understand Byzantium. "High ideals were besmirched by cruelty and greed, enterprise and endurance by a blind and narrow self-righteousness," he wrote, "and the holy war itself was nothing more than a long act of intolerance in the name of God, which is a sin against the holy ghost."

Runciman was the second son of the 1st Viscount Runciman of Doxford, who was descended from the mid 18th- century Scottish painter, Alexander Runciman. His father was a member of Asquith's cabinet and his mother was MP for St Ives. He himself always welcomed the fact that, as the younger son, he was not obliged to go either into politics or the family's shipping business. Indeed, an academic career was foreshadowed by his precocious ability to read French at three, Latin at six, Greek at seven and Russian at 11.

He won a scholarship to Eton, where a combination of an early interest in Greece and medievalism led naturally to his study of Byzantium. His school friends included Cyril Connolly, George Orwell and "Puffin" Asquith, the prime minister's son.

In 1921, a further scholarship took him to Trinity College, Cambridge, where he began to demonstrate an elegant and fashionable aestheticism by papering his rooms with a French grisaille wallpaper depicting Cupid and Psyche, and being photographed by his friend, Cecil Beaton, with a parrot poised on his ringed finger. Through his school friend George Ry lands, he was introduced to John Maynard Keynes, Lytton Strachey and Virginia and Leonard Woolf, and got to know the Bloomsbury group.

After taking a first in history, Runciman became a research student of the notoriously elusive JB Bury, the first British historian to take Byzantium seriously. He artfully discovered the regius professor's regular habit of taking an afternoon walk along the Backs, and was thus able to manoeuvre Bury into giving him unofficial tutorials.

Following an attack of pleurisy - and his doctor's prescription that his best chance of recovery would come from a long sea voyage - he went to China, arriving in the middle of the civil war. But this did not prevent him from befriending the last Chinese emperor, with whom he played piano duets.

In 1924, Runciman made his first trip to Greece, was enchanted by the Byzantine town of Monemvasia and, later, by the old city of Istanbul. On his return to Cambridge, he concentrated on his fellowship thesis, with pioneering investigations into Armenian and Syriac sources, which, in 1929, resulted in his first book, The Emperor Romanus Lecapenus. After that, in quick succession, came The First Bulgarian Empire and Byzantine Civilisation.

Runciman had gone back to Trinity in 1927 to teach and hold a fellowship until 1938. His first pupil had been Guy Burgess, whom he remembered for his intellectual brilliance and his dirty fingernails. His last pupil was Donald Nicol, who became Koraes professor of modern Greek and Byzantine history at London University. Meantime, his travels had taken him to Jerusalem and Thailand, with several more visits on foot and muleback to Greece and Turkey.

When his grandfather died in 1938, Runciman could afford to give up his fellowship, and take George Trevelyan's advice to leave Cambridge and concentrate on his writing. By a happy chance, the war took him back to the countries of his choice, first as press attaché in Sofia in 1940, then to Cairo and Jerusalem for the Ministry of Information, and finally to Istanbul for three years as professor of Byzantine art and history. This gave him the opportunity to follow the tracks of the crusaders and plan his History Of The Crusades - as well as visiting Syria and becoming an honorary whirling dervish.

Immediately after the war, Runciman willingly accepted the offer to direct the work of the British Council in Greece. During the next two years, assisted by Paddy Leigh Fermor and Rex Warner, this remarkable triumvirate endeared themselves to the Greeks in a manner that has never been rivalled. In Athens, Runciman became a well-known figure in the smart Kolonaki set ("the good bandit families", as he characteristically called the descendants of the leaders of the Greek war of independence) and was a friend of George Sepheriades, the diplomat whose poetry, under the name of Sepheris, later won a Nobel prize. In his spare time, he improved his collection of icons, tanagras (figurines) and Edward Lears.

A fter the publication, in 1947, of The Medieval Man- ichee, a still unchallenged study of the Christian dualist heresy, Runciman returned to Britain to start work on the crusades, dividing his time between his house in St John's Wood, London, and the isle of Eigg, off the Scottish coast, which his father had bought in 1926. From 1951 to 1967, he was chairman of the Anglo-Hellenic League, which he nicknamed "the Anglo-Hell".

His reputation was triumphantly established when A History Of The Crusades was published in three volumes, between 1951 and 1954. Praising the pace and style of its narrative history, some critics even compared its author to Macaulay.

The Eastern Schism was published in 1955, and The Sicilian Vespers in 1958. This was the year in which Runciman was knighted, and in 1961 he was made a knight commander of the Greek Order of the Phoenix. As part of his continuing revival of interest in Byzantium, The Fall of Constantinople: 1453, appeared in 1965, The Great Church In Captivity in 1968, The Last Byzantine Renaissance in 1970, The Orthodox Churches And The Secular State in 1972, and Byzantine Style And Civilization in 1975.

When a street was named after him in Mistra, his expression of gratitude took the form of a book, published in 1980, about the Byzantine capital of the Peloponnese.

Runciman had always found theology both fascinating and entertaining. Although he did not belong to the Orthodox church, he had a profound commitment to orthodoxy and believed that it enshrined the future of Christianity.

When Eigg was sold in 1966, he quickly moved to Elshieshields, a border tower in Dumfrieshire. Indeed, throughout his long and peripatetic life, he had always known that his roots were in Scotland. This became his last home, where he happily entertained both old and new friends, introducing them to his collection of 18th- and 19th-century musical boxes, worry beads, a hubble bubble, the Alexander Runcimans and Edward Lears, the limericks as well as the watercolours.

Here, too, he could display his knowledge of the gen- ealogical ramifications of European royalty, often flavoured by well-informed gossip. The year after his 80th birthday he was made a companion of honour.

But although he settled in Scotland and made only irregular visits to London, Runciman still found time to travel abroad to lecture and discover new Coptic churches. In 1987, his name and fame reached a much wider audience when Channel 4 produced a well-directed verbal autobiography, Sir Steven Runciman: Bridge To The East."

Even in his middle 80s, there was no slackening of his energy or intellectual vitality, and his ability to charm his friends of all ages. Early in 1991, an exhibition of his collection of Lear's watercolours was held at the National Gallery of Scotland. The catalogue contained his introduction and comments on each of the pictures, as well as a photograph of Stephen Conroy's portrait of him, which hangs in the Scottish Nat- ional Portrait Gallery. Soon afterwards, he published A Traveller's Alphabet: Partial Memoirs, which colourfully recorded in alphabetical form - A for Athos, Z for Zion - a lifetime of travels that had taken him round the world, and "where a certain amount of serendipity had crept in".

In 1992, Runciman redis covered a short story or novella, written in 1935 and entitled Paradise Regained. This fictional account of an expedition to Iraqi Kurdistan, dedicated to George Rylands and revealing both his wit and sharp sense of humour, was privately printed and distributed to his friends in place of a Christmas card.

In 1993, to celebrate his 90th birthday, dinners were given for him by the Old Collegers of Eton, by the British Byzantines and by Trinity College, Cambridge. The Cambridge University Press organised a reception for him, and the National Trust for Scotland gave him its guest flat at Culzean in Ayrshire. Finally, he invited some hundreds of friends to a a lavish reception at Spencer House.

A ll the while, Runciman continued to travel. In September 1994, he took part in the ceremony on the island of Lemnos inaugurating the Aegean declaration, an agreement between Unesco and the Greek Ministry of Culture to turn the Greek archipelago into a European cultural park. In April 1995, in his capacity as president of the Friends of Mount Athos, he published a learned article in the Times deploring the fact that, on the Athonite peninsula, the tradition of faith transcending ethnic difference, which had been the practice for more than a millennium, was under threat.

As late as 1997, besides his regular visits to Bahrain and Greece, he contributed a sparkling review in the Spectator of a life of Marthe Bibesco, the Wallachian princess who was a confidante of countless heads of state. As recently as last month, he was in Athens to receive from the Greek president the international prize for culture (arts and humanities) of the Onassis Foundation. In addition to its silver trophy, he received $125,000, which he generously offered to Mount Athos.

Runciman was greatly distressed by the Kosovo war, where his sympathies lay with the Serbs. When well on in his 90s, he began writing his memoirs. He never married

 James Cochran Stevenson Runciman, historian, aesthete and traveller, born July 7 1903; died November 1 2000

fields.headline: Writers grit teeth for a literary battle
fields.standfirst: First time authors square up for live showdown
fields.trailText: Two of the authors on the Guardian First Book shortlist, announced today, will be locked in combat next week at a literary event billed as "a barroom brawl/live writing showdown".
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy,  arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
Two of the authors on the Guardian First Book shortlist, announced today, will be locked in combat next week at a literary event billed as "a barroom brawl/live writing showdown".

Zadie Smith, whose first novel, White Teeth, confounded the bookies by missing the Booker shortlist and the Orange prize, is the only British author on the Guardian shortlist: she shares it with two Americans, a Vietnamese-American, and a Canadian .

The £10,000 prize will not be announced until next month, but in the meantime Ms Smith will confront one of her rivals, Dave Eggers, at an event at the ICA in London next week.

The American writer has described most readings as "aggressively boring", and at a previous event volunteered to cut the hair of five audience members. Next week's event, Words@ICA, on November 11, will see the two authors simultaneously writing, reading, printing and finally selling pieces of work in front of a rowdy audience in the bar.

The only other novel on the list is House of Leaves, by Mark Z Danielewski, a modern view of the classic haunted house genre. The other shortlisted books are Catfish and Mandala, a Vietnamese odyssey, by Andrew Pham, now living in the US, whorevisited by bicycle the country which he and his parents fled as boat people in the 1970s; and No Logo, by Canadian Naomi Klein, regarded as a brilliant, young polemicist, whose book examines the many strands of "refusnik" culture which led to the World Trade Organisation riots in Seattle.

The award is for any first book, fiction or non fiction, prose or poetry. It will be judged by novelists Julian Barnes, David Baddiel and Toby Litt alongside Steve Jones and broadcaster Kirsty Young, with Guardian editor Alan Rusbridger and literary editor Claire Armitstead. Readers at Borders Books shops in London, York, Cheshire Oaks and Glasgow have already helped choose the shortlist.

Claire Armitstead, who will chair the judges, said: "The fact that Zadie Smith is the only British writer to be shortlisted merely underlines that these are world class writers, all of whom are working at the forefront of their genres.

"It is terrific that our judges - and particularly the Borders reading groups - have been so quick to recognise and understand these new voices."

fields.headline: TV's £500,000 winner abandons her postbag
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: A former solicitor has given up her new job as a postwoman after becoming the first woman to win £500,000 on the game show Who Wants to be a Millionaire?
fields.body:
A former solicitor has given up her new job as a postwoman after becoming the first woman to win £500,000 on the game show Who Wants to be a Millionaire?

Kate Heusser, who gave up her law career to look after her children, equals the record set by Peter Lee, a retired naval officer, who won £500,000 on the ITV show in January.

Millions of viewers saw Mrs Heusser, 44, scoop the prize last night. She had been due to start as a postwoman, to supplement her income, this week, but will not now take up the post.

"I'm still in shock," she said. "I don't think it will change what we as a family will do with our lives but, my god, it will make it easier."

Mrs Heusser lives near Brighton with her husband Peter and their children Edward, 14, and Greg, 11. She trained as a solicitor, but decided to stay at home and concentrate on becoming a writer.

She started her run on Monday, and got to £64,000 before using a lifeline. After reaching £500,000, she decided not to answer the £1m question: Which monarch was known as the wisest fool in Christendom? (Answer: James I).

Chris Tarrant, the show's host, said: "She was very brave and very cool under pressure."

webTitle: Celebrity chefs wake up and smell the coffee as Foodoo folds

fields.headline: Celebrity chefs wake up and smell the coffee as Foodoo folds
fields.trailText: 8am: Foodoo.com, a recipe website set up by celebrity chefs, has shut down because of insufficient funding, reports Amy Vickers
fields.body:
They are the masters of their trade but now celebrity chefs Gordon Ramsay, Gary Rhodes, Ken Hom and Antony Worrall-Thompson have discovered what it is like to get their fingers burnt.

Foodoo.com, the recipe website in which the chefs all have equity, has shut up shop.

A statement on the site, which launched in May, admitted it had been unable to secure further funding and was talking to creditors about voluntary liquidation.

The news comes less than a week after Foodoo incubator Eos Internet Ventures was forced to admit defeat and wind down its operations after failing to find a cash injection.

Foodoo's demise should come as a wake-up call to other fledgling dot.coms which believed that the magic ingredients - celebrity backing, former management consultants and a regular newspaper column in Sunday Business - would see them through the shake-out.

The celebrity chefs all were given sections on the site that were meant to reflect their own personality.

Foodoo.com was co-founded by former management consultants Chris Reohr and Martin Murphy, along with television producer Red Johnson and former head of PR and marketing at the Conran Restaurant Group, Victoria Parnis.

Funding came through Eos, which was believed to have taken a 40% stake in Foodoo.

Cracks begin to appear in Foodoo as early as July this year when it was disclosed that the website needed to raise £10m to enable it to move into selling food, wine and cooking equipment.

Other than tentative e-commerce plans, Foodoo's only revenue stream was from advertising on the website, which didn't kick in properly until the end of July, and content distribution deals with the likes of Amazon.

When trying to raise start-up money, Mr Worrell Thompson was quoted as saying: "There have been cock-ups in the past with food and drink sites where people have gone too far too soon. We have a much more sensible approach to running a dot.com site."

Famous last words.

webTitle: Speeding car ad research sparks row

fields.headline: Government hints at fresh curbs on car ads
fields.trailText: 8am: Research linking car ads with road deaths has prompted the government to consider new curbs on advertising. Jade Garrett reports.
fields.body:
The advertising industry is up in arms after the government made veiled threats to impose new limits on car adverts.

A furious row erupted between the Advertising Association and the Department of Environment, Transport & the Regions after the DETR said new research showed a possible correlation between speed scenes in car ads and the number of fatalities on the roads.

The research, due to be made public at the end of the month, will show a link between the images that people see in advertising and their attitudes and desires about driving.

Sara Price, head of public affairs at the AA, said: "Antony Allsworth [head of road safety publicity at the DETR] is responsible for commissioning the government's road safety campaign. He is the driving force behind it and he's got to find a scapegoat.

"The DETR is worried that its own advertising has not had the right impact. Commercial advertising is always the easy target - they have to be seen to be doing something," she added.

"But there is a total lack of evidence. If advertising made the kind of claims they are making you'd expect to be hauled up in front of the ASA. It's easy to pick one or two ads and say the whole industry is wrong but show me how legislation would be any better."

The government spends £12m a year on road safety ads concerning everything from speed, drink driving, use of mobile phones and the wearing of seat belts.

Many of them have used shockingly graphic images including the current "belt-up" campaign in which a child is hurled from the back seat to the front, killing his mother.

A senior spokesperson at the DETR admitted that a single viewing of an advertisement would not influence behaviour and added that he had no evidence that people watch ads and then immediately act upon what they've seen.

But he added that "ads showing speeding cars can reinforce existing opinions and an ingrained tendency to want to go fast.

"If an ad shows a car going fast around corners viewers may think 'yes, I'd like a car like that so I can test it to the ultimate'."

The spokesman would not say whether the DETR would seek to ban such car advertising altogether.

"What the DETR are saying to the ad industry is 'you will do what we say under the threat of legislation'," said Ms Price.

"It's like putting a picket fence around a flock of birds and expecting them to stay there," said Rupert Howell, president of the IPA.

"If you don't want people to speed, don't make cars that are capable of doing more than 50mph or start paying more attention to what's going in film. It's pathetic. The government needs to stop with all this gesture politics."

Figures from the DETR show that fatalities on the road are falling. In 1981 to 1985 the figure was 5,598 while today it stands at 3,423.

fields.headline: Mrs Murdoch deals with it
fields.standfirst: News Corp chairman's young Chinese wife pushes the family firm forward in Asia.
fields.trailText: 8am: News Corp chairman's young Chinese wife pushes the family firm forward in Asia, write Michael Ellison and Jane Martinson .
fields.byline: Michael Ellison  and Jane Martinson  in New York
fields.body:
Twelve months ago the new Mrs Rupert Murdoch was busying herself with choosing the curtains for their Manhattan apartment, improving her 69-year-old husband's diet and remodelling his wardrobe.

Now the former junior executive at his Star TV operation in Hong Kong is taking a hands-on approach to helping News Corporation develop in Asia, its most important growth market.

Wendi Deng, who is no longer an employee, is said to have helped to arrange an investment of up to £31m in Chinese internet operations and seal partnerships with cable companies.

"Wendi gives News Corp a Chinese face in China," said Joseph Ravitch, joint head of the global-media practice at the Goldman Sachs Group.

"She represents not just the company but the owner, and that's critical in a country where families are very important."

She is said to work for weeks at a time thrashing out deals in China while her husband works in New York and Europe. She is said to identify likely investments for Mr Murdoch, who controls about 30% of News Corp, valued at £6bn.

Mrs Murdoch, 31, who married her second husband 16 months ago on his yacht Morning Glory in New York harbour, has been working alongside his younger son James, 27, the chief executive of Star TV and the prime mover in Mr Murdoch's internet interests.

Bruce Churchill, head of Star TV, a 27-channel service operating in 53 countries, said that although Mrs Murdoch had no official role, she was married to the chairman and chief executive of the company, "so it seems natural that she has some voice in the business".

The revelation that Mrs Murdoch is doing more than choose the curtains comes at a difficult time for the company as it seeks investment to create a separate division for its satellite operations.

It also comes after a year in which Mr Murdoch, who is constantly accused of running one of the world's biggest media companies as a personal fiefdom, appeared to have quelled fears that his sons were being catapulted to the top.

Yesterday most US fund managers accepted that family ties were a useful way of doing business. "Using personal connections is neither unusual nor illegal, especially in China," one said. Others have reservations, however.

"The problem is, where do you draw the line between your personal life and corporate business?" a Boston-based manager said.

Gary Ginsberg, a spokesman for News Corp, said Mrs Murdoch's role was "minimal and confined to facilitating a few meetings in China and interpreting nuances of the Chinese market, which she is uniquely qualified to do".

Mrs Murdoch, whose father was a director of a factory in Guangzhou, southern China, arrived in the US 12 years ago, studied at California State University, and then graduated from the Yale school of management.

Her husband said last year that their relationship prevented her working for News Corp and that this arrangement was frustrating for her. "We'll just have to resolve that somehow," he said.

Since then she has met Chinese politicians, including President Jiang Zemin, though she said this had only happened at large gatherings: she had not instigated meetings with senior officials.

Mrs Murdoch is said to receive 100-odd emails a day from Chinese people with business propositions and to have helped complete a multimillion-dollar investment in netease.com, a popular site aimed at China.

"She's very keyed into all the News Corp and Star TV properties and how to better link them," said Anthony Cheng, founder of renren.com, a Chinese-language company with which Mrs Murdoch helped negotiated a £6.8m investment.

None of this comes as a surprise to Daniel Blake of California State University, who wrote her recommendation to study at Yale: he once predicted that she would play a role in opening China to business.

fields.headline: Woodhead quits Ofsted for Telegraph
fields.trailText: 8am: Chris Woodhead, chief inspector of education watchdog Ofsted, is to join the Daily Telegraph.
fields.body:
Chris Woodhead, chief inspector of education watchdog Ofsted, is to join the Daily Telegraph.

A spokesman for the newspaper said Mr Woodhead would be joining its staff next spring as a consultant on educational, cultural and social matters.

In a statement, the Telegraph's editor, Charles Moore, said: "I am delighted that Chris Woodhead will be coming to the Daily Telegraph. In his period as chief inspector, he has been consistently identified with the cause of high standards and educational improvement.

"His advice will be of immense benefit to our readers and to the cause of good education."

Mr Woodhead added: "I am greatly looking forward to joining the Telegraph. It is the best forum for public debate on the subjects which most concern me, and I hope to be able to make a valuable contribution."

webTitle: Fairfax joins bidding fray for RIM

fields.headline: Fairfax joins bidding fray for RIM
fields.trailText: 8am: Fairfax, the Australian publishing firm which owns the Sydney Morning Herald, has made a takeover approach to Regional Independent Media. By David Teather.
fields.body:
Fairfax, the Australian publishing firm which owns the Sydney Morning Herald, has made a takeover approach to Regional Independent Media, publisher of the Yorkshire Post.

The interest from Fairfax emerged as RIM robustly rejected an attempt by three of Britain's leading regional newspaper groups to engineer a carve-up of its assets.

Advisers to RIM told Gannett, Johnston Press and Guardian Media Group, publisher of the Guardian, that the company would not be prepared to negotiate with a consortium of buyers.

As well as Fairfax, another overseas bidder is understood to have registered interest in acquiring RIM.

A source close to the company said both overseas bidders had made their approaches after the publicity generated by Gannett, Johnston and GMG in the summer.

"They have both been to RIM's advisers and said if a sale process begins they will be keen to get involved," he said.

Analysts have valued RIM, which owns 72 regional titles, at around £550m.

Fairfax is focused on its domestic market and publishes the Sun-Herald, the Age, the Sunday Age and the Australian Financial Review as well as a number of regional newspapers. It had revenues of A$1.1bn last year and has been going through a period of restructuring. The company was unavailable for comment.

Chris Oakley, RIM's chief executive, said he had been surprised by the joint statement issued by Gannett, Johnston and GMG late on Wednesday.

"We are not prepared to get into a morass of negotiations with a consortium and we told Gannett that very clearly this morning," he said. "When you start dealing with a consortium there are all sorts of hoops you have to jump through, but we are not keen to sell and didn't initiate these talks - so these are hoops we don't have to jump through." Mr Oakley also conceded that an auction was likely raise a higher sum than a more orderly break-up of the group.

Consortium insiders were bemused by RIM's reaction. They said they would proceed with the existing plan that Gannett make an approach for the entire company with an agreement to sell on certain titles to the other two.

RIM is one of the few large independent regional newspaper groups left. It is the sixth-largest such group in Britain and was formed through the Candover-backed £360m buyout of the regional newspaper business of United News & Media in 1998.

webTitle: BSkyB urges ITV to end satellite stand-off

fields.headline: BSkyB urges ITV to end satellite stand-off
fields.trailText: 8am: : BSkyB today will put further pressure on ITV in the long running row over the commercial network's absence from the Sky Digital platform, writes David Teather.
fields.body:
BSkyB today will put further pressure on ITV in the long running row over the commercial network's absence from the Sky Digital platform.

The pay-television operator will publish figures which show that ITV's share of viewing in Sky Digital homes was 17.3% in the third quarter of the year. That compares to 20.4% in all multichannel homes and 27.9% in all UK homes.

BSkyB is aggrieved at ITV's resistance to appearing on the platform and believes the network is giving unfair advantage to ONdigital, the pay-TV service owned by Carlton and Granada Media.

The figures will be included in the company's third-quarter results. "These figures show that for as long as ITV remains off digital satellite a whole generation of viewers will not know what ITV is," a BSKyB spokesman said.

It will note that Sky channels account for 5.7% of total audience share, up from 4.8% in the same period last year.

Senior executives of Carlton and Granada, the only two ITV franchise holders left in England and Wales, have made it clear they want to be on the platform but have been unable to agree terms.

An ITV spokeswoman said publication of the figures showed BSkyB's need to secure the network's presence. ITV, she admitted, had suffered a poor third quarter but had grown its peak time audience share from 38.5% in October last year to 39.1% this year.

"In every home in Britain ITV is the most popular channel and in digital homes it is drawing viewers away from the Sky Digital platform," she said. "Our autumn schedule has performed very strongly and saw us grow audience share for the third year running. With figures like that, it's not surprising they want us on their platform."

She said ITV performed relatively better in Sky Digital homes than Channel 4, Channel 5 and BBC2 and only marginally worse than BBC1, all of which are on the platform.
