webTitle: Leader: The state of Britain's youth offender institutions

fields.headline: Indefensible institutions
fields.standfirst:
It is not only Feltham which needs reform

Special report: deaths in custody
fields.trailText: Rarely can a judge's decision have been so promptly justified. Only a week ago the lord chief justice declared that it would be wrong to transfer the two young killers of James Bulger from local authority secure units to the "corrosive atmosphere" of a young offender institution (YOI). Just how "corrosive" such institutions can be was shown yesterday in our graphic report chronicling how a 19-year-old Asian youth, sentenced to 90 days for a minor £6 theft and interfering with a motor car, was placed in the same Feltham cell as a pathologically racist psychopath, who proceeded to batter him to death when he went to sleep.
fields.body:
Rarely can a judge's decision have been so promptly justified. Only a week ago the lord chief justice declared that it would be wrong to transfer the two young killers of James Bulger from local authority secure units to the "corrosive atmosphere" of a young offender institution (YOI). Just how "corrosive" such institutions can be was shown yesterday in our graphic report chronicling how a 19-year-old Asian youth, sentenced to 90 days for a minor £6 theft and interfering with a motor car, was placed in the same Feltham cell as a pathologically racist psychopath, who proceeded to batter him to death when he went to sleep.

The desperate state of our YOIs has been set out in a succession of reports: endemic overcrowding, beatings, bullying, rape, suicides, filthy conditions, and lock-ups lasting for most of the day with a mere three hours of association or work. Then there is their record on reoffending: more than 80% of inmates reconvicted within two years of release. A major study of YOIs by the chief inspector of prisons, Sir David Ramsbotham, concluded in late 1997 that they were doing more harm than good.

Of all 15 YOIs, by far the worst is Feltham, west London. In 1996, the chief inspector found it was no better than "a gigantic transit camp". In an unannounced visit in 1998, on which he reported last year, he found conditions were still "unacceptable in a civilised country". A new £6m reception centre and education unit was opened this year, but cell life remained unchanged, prompting a young deputy governor to resign in disgust in August suggesting conditions were still "more suitable for a Dickens novel than the 21st century".

What is wrong? They are too big, too anonymous, and too lacking in leadership. They range in size from 300 to 850. Even when designed to a small scale, such as Northallerton, the 150 places have 300 crammed in. Feltham has had four governors, or acting governors, this year alone. There were three others in the previous four years. Yet, crucially, these institutions of profoundly unstable people need stable and inspiring leadership.

Then there is race. Yesterday's story coincided with the report on race relations in Brixton prison. The most shocking aspect of this internal report was that even though there is a clear and unequivocal policy on race relations, it was neither being followed nor monitored. Finally, there is mental health. Yesterday's story rightly dwelt on the criminal waste of life of the young Asian, Zahid Mubarek, who was killed. But today, our reporter Paul Kelso looks at the mental health of Robert Stewart, the convicted killer.

There were two victims in this killing, not one. Stewart was a product of YOIs. His file was filled with evidence of serious mental disorder: flooding his cell, setting fire to his cell, setting fire to himself, trying to kill himself. Yet these well documented incidents were described by prison staff as "strange". These were not strange, but perfectly clear signals of a mental disorder. No wonder the chief inspector concluded his YOI report by asserting that "more damage is done to immature adolescents than to any other type of prisoner by current conditions."

What should be done? Calls for a judicial inquiry are right. It needs to focus both on the specific (the murder) and the broader problem of YOIs. It will have to respond to unanswered questions. How did it happen? How big a part did racism play? How did these two offenders end up together? But it should also stand a good chance of generating a momentum for reform, as did the inquiry into Stephen Lawrence's death.

fields.headline: Debtor friendly regime outlined
fields.trailText: The government yesterday announced plans to rescue thousands of businesses in trouble and safeguard hundreds of thousands of jobs.
fields.body:
The government yesterday announced plans to rescue thousands of businesses in trouble and safeguard hundreds of thousands of jobs.

The measures, set out in a report by a joint Treasury and Department of Trade and Industry review group, are part of a government strategy to encourage risk-taking and enable entrepreneurs to make a fresh start without the stigma of bankruptcy.

As part of the package, banks would lose their legal right to stop a failing company going into administration rather than receivership.

As secured creditors, banks often hold what is known as a floating charge over a business's assets and, under present law, can force it into receivership almost at will. They tend to gain the bulk of the money while unsecured creditors get nothing.

Under yesterday's proposals, that would change in a move seen as likely to raise the banks' hackles - even though they themselves increasingly favour administration over receivership.

"An administrator would be responsible to all the creditors," government experts said. "We want to elevate collective insolvency procedures over individual ones and move the UK from being the most creditor friendly regime to one that is more debtor friendly."

This move, which would require legislation, was accompanied by an agreement by the inland revenue and customs and excise to treat companies going into voluntary administration more sympathetically.

Last year, according to the association of business recovery professionals, known as R3, some 16,813 companies went into insolvency, putting at risk billions of pounds in turnover and hundreds of thousands of jobs.

Government agencies, primarily the revenue and customs, forced more than 3,000 companies into liquidation - one in five of the total. They have now agreed to treat rescue proposals more favourably.

webTitle: Stumbling blocks on Ulster's path to peace

fields.headline: Stumbling blocks on Ulster's path to peace
fields.standfirst:
Today's symbolic meeting of nationalists from both sides of the border shows the gulf with unionists and bodes ill for the future
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Elderly travellers from across the world, who repair to the smartest hotel in Enniskillen for a breather by the banks of Lough Erne, will find their tranquility disturbed this morning. The Killyhevlin hotel is the venue for a meeting which could define the future of the entire Northern Ireland peace process.
fields.body:
Elderly travellers from across the world, who repair to the smartest hotel in Enniskillen for a breather by the banks of Lough Erne, will find their tranquility disturbed this morning. The Killyhevlin hotel is the venue for a meeting which could define the future of the entire Northern Ireland peace process.

As residents of the hotel finish off their "Ulster frys" this morning, leaders of nationalist Ireland will cock a snook at David Trimble by holding a cross-border ministerial meeting in the hotel.

What should have been a relatively innocuous meeting about food standards has become a hugely significant show of strength by nationalists in the face of Mr Trimble's decision to block Sinn Fein from attending the cross border council.

Michael Martin, the Irish republic's health minister, will cross the border to show solidarity with Bairbre de Brun, the Sinn Fein health minister. They will be joined by Northern Ireland's deputy first minister Seamus Mallon. The Ulster Unionists, who want to block Sinn Fein from attending cross border meetings in punishment for the IRA's "failure" to disarm, have dismissed today's meeting as "pantomime politics".

The talks will not have the status of a formal north south ministerial council because Mr Trimble, along with Mr Mallon, has the power to block ministers from appearing. However, the informal bilateral meeting will have symbolic significance. The sight of an Irish government minister sitting down with Sinn Fein and SDLP ministers - less than a week after Mr Trimble's veto threat - will demonstrate the resolve of nationalist Ireland. The talks will provide graphic proof of the gulf separating republicans and unionists, which bodes ill for efforts to save the peace process.

Sinn Fein

Sinn Fein is adamant that today's meeting had to go ahead to make clear that republicans do not sit in government courtesy of unionist "patronage". The presence of Ms de Brun also shows that Sinn Fein remains deeply committed to making the Good Friday agreement work although the party has deep reservations about the state of the peace process, principally over the Ulster Unionists' commitment to the agreement.

Martin McGuinness, Sinn Fein's education minister, accepts that Mr Trimble has faced down hardliners - at least until last Saturday. But he believes Mr Trimble's failure to promote the benefits of the agreement highlights lingering unionist doubts about the entire process.

Sinn Fein's unease is compounded by its frosty relations with the government, mainly caused by the future of policing. Republicans believe that Peter Mandelson has watered down key elements of the Patten report to appease unionists. Sinn Fein says it cannot compromise any more. Sinn Fein's mistrust of unionists is undermining the faith of republicans in the peace process which can only strengthen the hands of hardliners.

Provisional IRA

The IRA is deeply frustrated with unionists for placing such emphasis on decommissioning and with the British government for its alleged unwillingness to "demilitarise". Mr Trimble's provocative move will therefore have guaranteed that progress on disarmament has at best been set back, if not killed off altogether. In its recent statements the IRA has offered its usual support to Sinn Fein. However, security sources have suggested that there is unease among many IRA members at the sight of two Sinn Fein "ministers of the crown". The Real IRA appears to be growing in strength. Until now, it has not attracted a well-spread base of disaffected provisionals. The slow pace of the peace process could change that. The IRA leadership is particularly frustrated because it believes that it is living up to its commitment on disarmament.

SDLP

John Hume's Social Democratic and Labour party shares many of the frustrations of the republican movement, but the party believes that the IRA should make further gestures on disarmament. Mr Mallon is taking a tough stance on police reforms because he believes that the Good Friday agreement must be implemented in full.

He has accused the government of "chicanery" over the implementation of the Patten report. Some unionists have suggested that Mr Mallon has been boxed into a corner by Sinn Fein because he is terrified that republicans will overtake the SDLP as the main nationalist party at the general election.

Irish government

Dublin has resorted to its traditional role as the protector of northern nationalists amid the uncertainty of the peace process. The prime minister, Bertie Ahern, believes that Mr Trimble's ban on Sinn Fein has seriously destabilised the peace process because it undermines the one area of the agreement which was tailor-made for nationalists.

The north south ministerial council has huge significance in the Irish republic. Many members of Mr Ahern's Fianna Fail party were sceptical about renouncing Dublin's territorial claim to the north, a key element of the agreement. They set aside their reservations on the basis of the north south body. Dublin is also frustrated with the British government over the Patten reforms and for what it sees as slow progress on scaling down security measures. Republicans have not been let off the hook by Dublin which wants to see progress on the arms issue.

British government

Peter Mandelson has been working frantically all week to navigate a middle way through the present crisis which allows all sides to save face. The Northern Ireland secretary bluntly told Mr Trimble that he must lift his ban on Sinn Fein ministers attending meetings of the cross border body. At the same time, however, the IRA should re-establish contact with the disarmament body to reassure unionists.

"It is not a matter of one or the other," Mr Mandelson said yesterday. "It is both." His plans received a boost yesterday when the international arms inspectors said that the IRA was committed to the peace process.

Mr Mandelson knows, however, that he has his work cut out because Dublin, republicans and unionists are deeply angered by the police bill. He rejects republican claims that he has watered down the Patten report, insisting that he has kept to its core principles. For unionists, however, the report is all too much.

Ulster Unionists

David Trimble has been described as the Houdini of British and Irish politics after he faced down his hardline colleague, Jeffrey Donaldson. But his victory came at a high price which may eventually be seen as the death knell of the peace process. The Ulster Unionist leader is deeply committed to the Good Friday agreement and relishes his role as first minister.

Mr Trimble has no qualms about the core elements of the deal - power sharing with nationalists and co-operating with the Irish republic. However, he has barely any room for manoeuvre, thanks to Mr Donaldson who is stalking his every move.

The optimists say that the Donaldson faction is slowing buying into the process which it initially rejected. Mr Donaldson is now an enthusiastic supporter of the assembly and its committee system, something he initially opposed.

However, Mr Donaldson has drawn a line in the sand which Mr Trimble is unlikely ever to cross: without real disarmament Sinn Fein should not be in government.

The hardliners will have another chance to challenge Mr Trimble in January. If there has been no movement on arms and the police bill has received royal assent, the future of the peace process will look distinctly uncertain.

Reforming the RUC: Patten's blueprint, and the reality

The future of policing has become one of the most contentious issues in the peace process since the publication of Chris Patten's report. Nationalists claim that the police bill, implementing the Patten reforms, has been diluted to appease unionists. Unionists claim that the bill dismantles the RUC.

The main differences between the bill and the Patten proposals are:

Force's name

Patten said: The Royal Ulster Constabulary should remain but change its name to Northern Ireland Police service.

Bill says: The RUC will remain but be called Police Service of Northern Ireland (incorporating the RUC).

Badge

Patten said: The new police service should adopt a new badge and symbols free from any association with either the British or Irish states.

Bill says: The secretary of state may make regulations prescribing the design of an emblem for the police and regulating the use of that or any other emblem.

Flag

Patten said: The union flag should no longer be flown from police buildings.

Bill says: Secretary of state will make decision in consultation with police board.

Oath

Patten said: New oath, which does not mention crown, should be sworn by all members of police force, including existing RUC officers.

Bill says: Only new recruits will swear oath. But existing officers will be bound by new code of ethics which incorporates commitment in oath to uphold human rights.

Police board

Patten said: Policing board should have the power to follow up any report from the chief constable by initiating an inquiry into any aspect of the police service or police conduct. Limitations on matters of "national security, sensitive personnel matters and cases before the courts".

Bill says: Secretary of state can block an inquiry if it would "prejudice the prevention or detection of crime or the apprehension or prosecution of offenders".

Other contentious issues include:

District police partnerships

Patten said: DPPs should be able to contribute up to 3p in the pound to local policing costs.

Bill says: No mention of this in the bill. Government says the issue will be reviewed.

Oversight commissioner Thomas Constantine, former head of US drug enforcement agency

Patten said: "An eminent person, from a country other than the UK or Ireland, should be appointed... with responsibility for supervising the implementation of our recommendations." Nationalists are angry because the commissioner will oversee government's recommendations, rather than Patten's.

Linking of anti-terrorist special branch with CID

Patten said: "We recommend that, as a first step, special branch and crime branch be brought together under the command of a single assistant chief constable."

Bill says: Recommendation not in police bill because it is not a matter for legislation. Nationalists angry because government says it is commmitted to proposal only when security allows.

fields.headline: Pizza Express turns hostile
fields.trailText: Pizza Express is considering a hostile bid for City Centre Restaurants, owner of Garfunkel's and Est Est Est, after its initial 65p a share offer was rejected by management.
fields.body:
Pizza Express is considering a hostile bid for City Centre Restaurants, owner of Garfunkel's and Est Est Est, after its initial 65p a share offer was rejected by management.

City sources say that the company and a consortium of investors are ready to offer up to 75p a share - and that they may have the support of disillusioned shareholders who claim they were not told of the original approach.

There is also talk of other bidders on the scene, including Whitbread, although a spokesman for the restaurant group declined to comment.

In a statement issued to the stock market, the company said: "The senior management continues to progress its strategic review of the group with a view to maximising shareholder value."

Shares in City Centre soared 13% on the news, and were up 6.5p to 56.5p as the markets closed last night.

Analysts believe that Pizza Express may realise value by cherrypicking the key sites in City Centre's portfolio - which includes some 300 restaurants - and leave the remainder to the consortium.

Its line up of restaurants include 68 of the Caffe Uno brand, 57 Deep Pan Pizza Companies, 48 Garfunkel's and 24 Est Est Est.

This week's speculation comes at a turbulent time for City Centre, which promised a full strategic review after issuing a profits warning, following terrible summer trading, and parted company with James Naylor, its chief executive. The poor performance had seen the company's share price collapse to its lowest level for almost a decade.

Analysts have been expecting City Centre to streamline its portfolio and concentrate on brands such as Caffe Uno and Frankie & Benny's.

webTitle: New ship contract awaits DTI seal

fields.headline: New ship contract awaits DTI seal
fields.standfirst: Merseyside prepares for the production of its first cruise liner since 1960
fields.trailText: Industry minister Stephen Byers is under pressure to help finance a £344m deal which could see the first new cruise ship built on Merseyside for more than 40 years.
fields.body:
Industry minister Stephen Byers is under pressure to help finance a £344m deal which could see the first new cruise ship built on Merseyside for more than 40 years.

Cammell Laird has signed a contract to build two 28,000 tonne vessels for Luxus, a recently formed cruise ship consortium.

But the deal is conditional on support from the Department of Trade and Industry.

The company wants to split the work on the Luxus ships between its Merseyside, Tyneside and Teeside yards, with Camper and Nicholson - the Gosport yard it bought six months ago - providing luxury fittings.

It will only secure the contract if the DTI grants shipbuilding intervention funding, amounting to up to 9% of the cost of the vessels, and provides ship mortgage finance guarantees to Luxus's bankers.

News of the Luxus deal, which covers construction and later refitting of the vessels, comes only a week after Cammell Laird failed to secure a £300m government contract to build roll-on roll-off ferries.

The company's main business has until now been ship repairing and conversion. It has only just returned to shipbuilding with a contract for two £5m Norwegian ferries. A Cammell Laird spokesman said work on the Luxus vessels would start within weeks of a deal with the DTI and would take about 33 months to complete. It would protect thousands of jobs at the yards.

Frank Field, the former Labour minister whose constituency covers Cammell Laird's Birkenhead yard on Merseyside, is pleased with the developments.

He said: "This shows that what was thought to be an old industry, which was written off, can again be at the forefront of our export drive.

"The ball is now in the government's court. I call Stephen Byers' office at the end of each day to ask where we are with the shipbuilding funding and the export guarantee.

"Now the deal has been signed we need this approval as soon as possible."

Kevin Rowan, GMB northern region spokesman, said: "Cammell Laird is a very profitable yard and Luxus has shown a lot of faith in it. It is about time the government demonstrated their support and hopefully they will.

"This is a huge contract and would be tremendous news for the region.

"If Cammell Laird continues to get the level of work it is getting now then this contract will create an extra 1,000 jobs."

A DTI spokeswoman con firmed that it was looking at the deal and would be giving it "urgent attention".

The Harland & Wolff yard in Belfast had been in the running for the Luxus order.

But when it accepted £50m of Royal Navy work, it no longer had the capacity to build the cruise ships.

The Luxus ships, each with 400 berths, will be fairly large - about the size of a cross-channel ferry.

They will however be much smaller than the QE2, the 1,777 berth cruise ship built for Cunard at Upper Clyde Shipbuilders in 1967.

The last cruise ship built on Merseyside was the Windsor Castle in 1960.

fields.headline: Oil tax hopes dashed
fields.standfirst: Chancellor remains determined to resist fuel protesters' demands despite record Shell profits
fields.trailText: Hopes among Britain's fuel protestors that yesterday's record profits by energy giant Shell will prompt deep cuts in the cost of petrol will be dashed by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, next week.
fields.body:
Hopes among Britain's fuel protestors that yesterday's record profits by energy giant Shell will prompt deep cuts in the cost of petrol will be dashed by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, next week.

Mr Brown is expected to forecast a budget surplus for this year far lower than the City is expecting.

News from Shell that the tripling of the cost of crude oil since the start of 1999 had resulted in an 80% surge in profits in the third quarter prompted calls from campaigners for a windfall tax on oil companies.

But the government - which was alarmed by reports that the public finances could be £16bn or more in the black in the current financial year - was last night desperately seeking to massage down expectations of the size of the budget surplus.

It is understood that the chancellor will adopt a deliberately cautious stance in next Wednesday's pre-budget report and predict a budget surplus that is likely to be in the region of £10bn.

Although that would still be twice as high as the £5bn surplus predicted in the Budget, the chancellor is determined to quash any speculation of any massive pre-election giveaway.

The Treasury shares Shell's view that the recent oil price is unsustainably high, and also believes that the severity of global and domestic competition will lead to a squeeze on profits and corporation tax receipts.

"We have no intention of repeating the mistakes of the late 1980s, when a temporary improvement in the public finances was wrongly thought to be permanent," one source said last night.

The Anglo-Dutch oil company yesterday sought to defuse mounting anger over its profits by warning that crude oil prices could fall steeply next year.

The company insisted that it made no money from its 11,000 UK petrol forecourts.

Shell said its profits in the third quarter of this year were up to $3.25bn (£2.1bn), a rate of around £25m a day. But the company said this was almost entirely due to much higher oil and gas prices.

Fuel protesters said the profits were "scandalous" and "obscene", and one called for a windfall tax on oil companies, including BP Amoco, which is set to disclose its own record earnings next week.

But Mark Moody-Stuart, Royal Dutch-Shell chairman, said: "These are exceptional results driven by an exceptional oil price.

"I have no doubt there will be leaner periods in the future just as there were in the past.

"After all, it is less than two years ago since Brent crude [the oil market's benchmark] fetched $10 a barrel." Brent fetched $30.45 a barrel in the third quarter, compared with $20.60 a year earlier.

But Mr Moody-Stuart helped spark a fall in Shell's share price by warning that increased oil output by Opec producers and larger stock-piles could force prices down next year once this winter's peak of demand had passed.

The City had already taken issue with Shell's $35m a day profits, arguing that they should have been higher and marking the group's shares down nearly 4% to 542p, the day's third-biggest blue chip mover. Analysts had expected profits of up to £2.5bn.

Shell said its exploration and production business had contributed more than 70% of its profits, partly driven by a $4bn cost cutting programme which is ahead of schedule.

The group said 20% of its profits came from refining and marketing oil products, including its forecourt business which made no money - and had not for several years.

webTitle: 'Buy Vodafone' said the note. Everyone sold

fields.headline: 'Buy Vodafone' said the note. Everyone sold
fields.standfirst: Billion pound dog's breakfast
fields.trailText: A billion pounds worth of stock changed hands at lightening speed. The price slumped more than 8%, dragging the rest of the London market with it. Dealers speculated on how the collateral damage might be felt across Europe later today.
fields.body:
A billion pounds worth of stock changed hands at lightening speed. The price slumped more than 8%, dragging the rest of the London market with it. Dealers speculated on how the collateral damage might be felt across Europe later today.

The trigger for this selling frenzy? A "strong buy" note on Vodafone, Britain's biggest company, of course - issued by the research team at its house stock broker, UBS Warburg.

Daniel Stillit and his team reckon that shares in the mobile phone group are headed towards 460p, but the rest of the market decided 253p was a more appropriate figure yesterday - down 23p - after the Warburg man realised he had to adjust his profit projections for Vodafone to take into account the amortisation of the cost of the group's third generation mobile licences.

No matter that Mr Stillit's adjustments shaved less than 2% off his previous numbers. Word went round that Vodafone was massaging down expectations on profits ahead of its interim figures, which are less than two weeks away - a hanging offence about which chief financial policeman Howard Davies warned just a week ago.

Of course, Vodafone was doing nothing of the sort. Shrewder market participants had simply noticed figures from Deutsche Telekom earlier this week, which showed that sales in Germany were rising at such a pace that the company was having to pump money into subsidising new customers, squeezing margins in the short term.

In Vodafone's case, the assumption is that its Mannesmann business is suffering, if that is the right word, similar financial pressures. Hence analysts over here are tweaking their numbers in the run up to the formal half-time figures.

Knocking £15bn off the value of a £165bn entity because its business is growing more quickly than previously thought sounds a tad perverse. But setting jittery markets aside, the affair highlights once again the dangers associated with trying to control the flow of information in and around the City.

Vodafone is in its "closed period" - the six week run-up to its figures when it cannot discuss anything about its trading or finances with anyone without making a full and very formal announcement. And if it did make an announcement during this period, the investment community would be jump ing up and down, noting how unusual the move was and speculating endlessly on what might be "behind" it.

There must also be questions about who has a right to the research produced by investment banking analysts. If Mr Stillit can provoke an 8% run on the country's biggest company, at what stage do the regulators step in and demand that this expensively produced analysis is immediately shared with everyone, rather than restricted to the Warburg clients who are paying for it? A regulatory dogs' dinner is in the making.

Aussies advance

Be prepared for a fresh wave of takeover speculation in the banking sector if National Australia Bank sets about trying to satisfy its appetite for a much bigger presence on this side of the world.

The Australian bank, listed on the Sydney stock exchange, already owns Clydesdale and Yorkshire and is now preparing the ground for a new listing in London. On the way, City sources believe that NAB might be tempted to sweep up another bank.

The prey being lined up by corporate finance matchmakers include Alliance & Leicester and Bank of Scotland.

The former is on the list because it offers a mix of businesses - branches in the south and middle of England and a link with the Post Office - which would fit snugly alongside NAB's operations in the north of England and Scotland.

Paradoxically, the later is being touted because of its failed attempt to takeover NatWest a year ago and the fact it might complement NAB's business in Scotland, although a bell or two might go off at the competition authorities. BoS also owns part of Bank West in Australia, which could also be attractive to NAB. The BoS's highly regarded chief execu tive, Peter Burt, might even secure himself a bigger job as a result.

NAB, which reported a 20% rise in pre-tax profits yesterday, made it clear that the northern hemisphere would be the focus of its activities for this coming year. It sees scope for organic growth through Clydesdale and Yorkshire as well as Northern and National Irish Banks in Belfast and Dublin, but also has a history of making acquisitions to boost its position.

It is 10 years since NAB, one of the three largest listed companies in Australia, threw its weight around in the UK. A stock market listing would certainly make it easier to complete a takeover using shares. Daniel Stillit and his team reckon that shares in the mobile phone group are headed towards 460p, but the rest of the market decided 253p was a more appropriate figure yesterday - down 23p - after the Warburg man realised he had to adjust his profit projections for Vodafone to take into account the amortisation of the cost of the group's third generation mobile licences. No matter that Mr Stillit's adjustments shaved less than 2% off his previous numbers. Word went round that Vodafone was massaging down expectations on profits ahead of its interim figures, which are less than two weeks away - a hanging offence about which chief financial policeman Howard Davies warned just a week ago. Of course, Vodafone was doing nothing of the sort. Shrewder market participants had simply noticed figures from Deutsche Telekom earlier this week, which showed that sales in Germany were rising at such a pace that the company was having to pump money into subsidising new customers, squeezing margins in the short term. In Vodafone's case, the assumption is that its Mannesmann business is suffering, if that is the right word, similar financial pressures. Hence analysts over here are tweaking their numbers in the run up to the formal half-time figures. Knocking £15bn off the value of a £165bn entity because its business is growing more quickly than previously thought sounds a tad perverse. But setting jittery markets aside, the affair highlights once again the dangers associated with trying to control the flow of information in and around the City. Vodafone is in its "closed period" - the six week run-up to its figures when it cannot discuss anything about its trading or finances with anyone without making a full and very formal announcement. And if it did make an announcement during this period, the investment community would be jump ing up and down, noting how unusual the move was and speculating endlessly on what might be "behind" it. There must also be questions about who has a right to the research produced by investment banking analysts. webTitle: Boots warns of more job losses

fields.headline: Boots warns of more job losses
fields.trailText: Boots, the high street pharmacy chain, yesterday talked of a further round of redundancies after announcing plans to cut costs by £100m over the next two years.
fields.body:
Boots, the high street pharmacy chain, yesterday talked of a further round of redundancies after announcing plans to cut costs by £100m over the next two years.

Senior management figures are looking at departments which can save money, and are expected to announce concrete proposals early next year.

David Thompson, deputy chief executive and finance director, insisted the move - which follows the 1,000 job cuts in the chemist chain - was vital to allow future investment in current stores.

"We have to be efficient and drive the business forward," he said. "I imagine there will be some job losses, but we are not able to say how many. Much of these savings will be made by lowering our costs from suppliers." The past year has seen the Boots share price in virtual freefall, and with every decline comes a flurry of speculation over potential bidders.

Analysts say investor confidence has been damaged by the perceived threat from grocers, while the group itself is pinning hopes on services such as dentistry, opticians and health clubs.

The company has also been looking to expand product ranges and pledged to continue looking abroad to source more unusual brand products.

Mr Thompson denied any approaches had been received, but admitted the company needed to be on its guard to stay independent.

"We just have to improve the business. The only defence we have against predators is our performance." Analysts suggest the group's real value is in its break-up potential with Halfords, the car and bike accessory chain, a key target.

Yesterday Boots reported slow progress at the half-year stage which undermined the recent share price rebound.

The company branded some of its markets "sluggish" and pointed out the period was impacted by the withdrawal from leisure merchandise.

Pre-tax profits for the group, excluding exceptionals, crawled up 2.3% to £271.3m on the back of a 1.3% turnover increase at £2.5bn. The basic earnings per share was up 3.4% to 21.5p, and the interim dividend advanced 4% to 7.8p.

Among the best performing divisions was Boots Healthcare International, which recently bought the Clearasil brand for £233m as pre-tax profits surged 70% to £25m.

Overseas, the company's sales reached almost £20m and expects to hit profits in Thailand next year. The figures failed to ignite the City, however, with the company's share price falling 24.5p, just over 4%, to 536.5p last night.

"The message coming out of the company leads me to think achieving sales growth is going to remain difficult," commented one analyst.

The company's interim figures came as the British Retail Consortium said supermarket competition had pushed down prices in the shops over the past month. The consortium's monthly Shop Price Index showed prices falling by 0.5% during October, which it said was a result of competition between the big food retailers.

Seasonal products, such as apples, were deemed more expensive, while the reductions on groceries and fish as well as non-food goods meant prices fell overall.

Over the year, retailers were still seeing price deflation, with shop price inflation running at minus 0.2%, said the BRC.

Bill Moyes, BRC director general, said: "Prices have fallen once more, compared with a year earlier, after a brief upward blip during September.

"Prices have been lower in 17 out of 18 months and shoppers are still paying less than they were two years ago."

fields.headline: Hands-free mobiles 'can increase radiation risk'
fields.standfirst: Special report: mobile phone fears
fields.trailText: Government claims that hands-free mobile phone kits are safe were thrown into doubt yesterday by research which showed that they can increase radiation to the skull by more than three times.
fields.body:
Government claims that hands-free mobile phone kits are safe were thrown into doubt yesterday by research which showed that they can increase radiation to the skull by more than three times.

The research from the Consumers' Association concluded that hands-free kit users should not rely on them to reduce radiation.

The study, by electromagnetics consultants ERA Technology, contradicted a Department of Trade and Industry report in August which claimed that phone users could cut their exposure to radiation by using hands-free attachments instead of holding the phones to their ear.

The organisation acknowledged that it was unclear whether the form of radiation emitted by mobile phones - radio waves which are non-ionising radiation was harmful to the brain. Exposure to this type of radiation can cause a rise in temperature which makes the heart work faster. Claims have been made that phones can cause more serious problems such as tumours, headaches and memory loss.

The CA tested five popular brands of mobile phone with 10 hands-free kits. Researchers found that when the kit was worn in the usual position, with the wire hanging down, the amount of radiation beamed into the brains of users was influenced by the distance between the earpiece and the top of the phone's aerial. Changing the position of the wire also affected levels of radiation.

In positions where the kits gave higher radiation readings, levels were between 46% and 259% more than when the phone was used without the kit. Between 8% and 97% of emissions were cut when a change in position lowered radiation levels.

Helen Parker, editor of Which? magazine said: "The government was unwise to give such categorical assurances. The most important advice is to reduce the length and number of your calls."

The CA is calling on the government to set up a European standard specifically for hands-free kits.

A DTI spokeswoman said the CA's report was the first to question the government tests. "We do have reservations about their methodology. We now need to develop a transparent standard for measuring the specific absorption ratio rate in hands-free kits."

The federation of the electronics industry which represents UK mobile phone companies said it would study the Which? results.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Rejection costs Dresdner dear
fields.body:
Rejection costs Dresdner dear

Germany's Dresdner Bank demonstrated the impact of two failed marriages yesterday by reporting lower than expected profits for its third quarter. The bank, which finalised takeover of Wall Street firm Wasserstein Perella earlier this year, is expected to to alter the name of its London-based Dresdner Kleinwort Benson investment banking unit to incorporate the Wasserstein name.

The takeover of Wasserstein followed botched attempts to complete a domestic merger, first with Deutsche and then with Commerzbank.

Excluding restructuring and retention payments, Dresdner made third-quarter pre-tax profits of €296m (£174m), compared to some €747m in the second quarter.

Jiway gains go-ahead

Jiway, the online brokerage in which OM of Sweden has a 60% stake, has received regulatory approval from the financial services authority and intends to begin operating in two weeks' time.

Jiway aims to make it easier for shares to be traded across national boundaries and it will open just days after OM discovers whether its £800m hostile takeover bid for the London Stock Exchange has been successful.

Separately, Don Cruickshank, chairman of the LSE, yesterday repeated his pledge to step up marketing of its Techmark exchange for hi-tech stocks and its expansion into European stocks.

Selfridges selects builder

Selfridges' ambitious plans to redevelop its Oxford Street store moved up a step yesterday when the retailer handed the contract to property developer Stanhope.

Stanhope won the £250m redevelopment work ahead of British Land, which has a 13%stake in the retailer.

Leicester City on the move

Premiership club Leicester City will spend up to £35m on a new 32,000-seat stadium to replace Filbert Street, its home since 1891.

It is paying Powergen £7m for a 22-acre site which it hopes to transform into a leisure complex, complete with hotel, by August 2002.

The club said yesterday the £11m sale of striker Emile Heskey to Liverpool helped it make a £600,000 pre-tax profit, compared to a £6.2m loss last year. Turnover was up 9% to £26m in a year which saw a £12.5m media alliance with Premium TV. Shares slipped 0.5p to 52.5p.

BT promises web speed-up

British Telecom has promised internet service providers it will resolve problems whch have delayed the installation of high-speed web connections in Britain.

It promised to triple its installation rate to 15,000 a month by March. It predicted 70,000-80,000 users by that time. "Volume demand began only in September and we have experienced some difficulties," said Steve Andrews, BT broadband president.

webTitle: Contrarywise: Hi-tech machine that actively handwashes clothes

fields.headline: Contrarywise: Hi-tech machine that actively handwashes clothes
fields.trailText: James Dyson, maverick inventor, yesterday launched a new device for washing clothes cleaner and allegedly quicker.
fields.body:
James Dyson, maverick inventor, yesterday launched a new device for washing clothes cleaner and allegedly quicker.

Seven years after he sprang the bagless, dual cyclone vacuum cleaner on the market, Mr Dyson unveiled the world's first two-drummed washing machine, the contrarotator.

Rebuffed by other manufacturers, the entrepreneur's vacuum cleaner is now produced at a rate of 8,000 a day and has won more than half the British market by value against fierce competition from its rivals.

The futuristic washing machine comes, like Dyson's cleaners, in purple, blue-yellow and silver.

But it will cost two or three times more, retailing at between £999 and £1,199 when it goes into selected shops from the end of this month.

Mr Dyson, a multimillionaire devoted to resurrecting Britain's manufacturing base from his plant in Malmesbury, Wiltshire, claimed his new machine can clean clothes better at any temperature than any of its rivals.

He said the twin drums, which rotate in opposite directions at the same time, cleaned clothes in half the time of rival machines - two hours 18 minutes compared with five hours 54 minutes for an average weekly load.

The machine, launched to the blare of catwalk music and swathed in dry ice, works on the same basic principle as handwashing, according to its inventor.

The twin drums mirror the action of two hands which, Mr Dyson said, can get clothes cleaner in 15 minutes than a normal machine can achieve in 67 minutes. Instead of "dropping and flopping" in one drum, they are "much more active" in the contrarotator.

"It's shocking that your hands can wash cleaner than your machine. Hands knead the fabric properly to release the dirt. With a second drum going in the other direction we can even improve on hand washing," Mr Dyson said.

It took four years, a million man hours and £25m to develop the machine which comes with a built-in jack and trolley and a coin trap to capture stray pennies and buttons.

Mr Dyson, who employs 350 engineers and designers among the 1600-strong workforce at Malmesbury, last month won two notable high court victories against Hoover.

A judge ruled that Hoover's triple vortex cleaner infringed Dyson's copyright and, 10 days later, banned the Italian-owned group from making or selling it.

webTitle: ICI says it will cut dividend to fund expansion

fields.headline: ICI says it will cut dividend to fund expansion
fields.trailText: ICI said yesterday that it plans to halve its dividend payouts from next year in order to spend more on expanding its business. This is the first time the chemicals group has made such a move since the oil crisis of the early 1980s.
fields.body:
ICI said yesterday that it plans to halve its dividend payouts from next year in order to spend more on expanding its business. This is the first time the chemicals group has made such a move since the oil crisis of the early 1980s.

It expects to have an extra £200m a year to invest as a result of the dividend cut and a £90m reduction in pension fund payments. In addition it is raising £250m through the sale of its 30% stake in Huntsman ICI Holdings to Huntsman Speciality Chemicals, the US group which bought a chunk of its chemicals businesses last year.

ICI is also seeking to sell some of its remaining industrial chemicals businesses in the north-west of England and some regional interests, especially in Pakistan.

Charles Miller Smith, the chairman, said: "The board now considers that most value can be created longer term for shareholders by increasing our options for investment in profitable growth."

The full year dividend for 2000 would be maintained at 32p a share but would be halved next year. After that dividends would account for about a third of net profit be fore exceptionals and goodwill amortisation.

ICI first cut its dividend in 1938. It repeated the move in 1981 and in effect reduced its payout in 1993 when it spun off Zeneca.

An ICI spokesman said the group had considered the impact of the dividend cut on the private shareholders who own 15% of the company.

The board believed its new growth policy would eventually benefit small shareholders. "The dividend cut takes place next year so they still have time to change," a spokesman said. "But the company hopes they will stay and see the growth in both the share value and the dividend."

ICI, which bought Unilever's speciality chemicals business for £5bn in mid-1997, is not planning any further big deals. "The board wants to make bolt-on acquisitions, adding in new technologies or geographic areas to the core businesses," the spokesman said.

Recently the group has sold most of its industrial chemicals business so it could focus on adhesives and starch, paint, fragrances and food flavours, and speciality chemicals.

During the third quarter, the group's core businesses reported a 4% rise in turnover and trading profit to £1.48bn and £163m respectively.

fields.headline: Baroness Ryder of Warsaw
fields.standfirst: Inspirational figure who never forgot, and gave new life to, the forgotten victims of war
fields.trailText: Inspirational figure who never forgot, and gave new life to, the forgotten victims of war
fields.body:
Sue Ryder, Baroness Ryder of Warsaw, who has died aged 77, was a great crusader for humanity long before her second marriage, to Leonard Cheshire, became a parallel enterprise. She started with her intensely personal care for the sick, disabled, or otherwise suffering survivors of Nazi concentration camps and their children.

She was born into a happy Yorkshire family and planned to farm and breed prize cattle. But "she always wanted to help people", according to the mother, from whom she derived so much. Educated at Benenden school, in 1939 she gave a false age to join the First Aid Nursing Yeomanry, then went to work for the Special Operations Executive, that strange secret world into which members half-disappeared from their own families. At 18, she was married for a few weeks to a young naval officer, soon killed.

In SOE, she lived and worked with men and women of different nations, who were smuggling themselves into occupied Europe as allied agents to probable capture, torture and death. She knew their greatest fears - whether they would be able to endure Nazi torture in interrogation; she knew the heroism of the resistance, in Poland and elsewhere, of ordinary people volunteering to help agents and allied prisoners-of-war, completely aware of what they faced.

Thus she acquired a vast new family, and her life's course was set. She crossed into Europe in 1944 and, in 1945, saw - in the newly- liberated concentration camps - the living, dead and dying, the price that she had already known from afar, and the children they left.

She joined relief organisations, and worked in the displaced persons camps, where, amid the ruins of Germany, people waited for permits to go to a new country. The young and strong could go, but the old, sick and disabled were regarded as wreckage. The relief organisations withdrew in 1952. Ryder stayed on, working alone.

That year, she took some for a holiday to Norway and Denmark, with the help of former Norwegian and Danish resistance friends. Soon after, she obtained permission to bring camp survivors and former re sistance fighters to England for short holidays and treatment. She went on to establish homes for sick and disabled survivors in the European countries where hospitals had been destroyed, and holiday homes in England for people who had not known a holiday since before the war. For all this, she trusted in God and human love for funds and voluntary workers. Both came.

In 1956, she founded the Sue Ryder Forgotten Allies Trust. Always, she felt fiercely about that forgetting, making her own work a living memorial to the millions of dead from the camps. The West German government initially refused compensation to national persecutees, resistance members, and those in the eastern European countries with which it had no diplo matic relations. In 1956, too, she made over her own home to become the centre of the work: the Old Rectory at Cavendish, Suffolk, a 16th-century house set in gardens.

In 1959, World Refugee Year, Ryder won British government permission to bring 30 disabled survivors as permanent residents to Cavendish, on condition that she guaranteed their complete support for life. By 1965, she had established 30 homes in England, Poland, Yugoslavia, Greece and Germany, and had plans for one in Israel. Each was truly a home - some with family bungalows or flats, and no regulations.

Ryder's firm rule for her "bods", her affectionate term for her life guests or workers, was designed to reverse all camp regulations. There was chintz and flowers everywhere, privacy respected, and occupation for those able to undertake work. These were all attempts to restore personality and dignity to people bearing, with other wounds, their camp tattoo numbers. Through her, "I learned to trust people again," was a constant refrain.

Ryder travelled 50,000 miles a year, often driving herself in a van, carrying medical and other supplies over Europe, directing the erection of new homes, visiting each and everyone in them, sending Christmas presents and cards, each inscribed in the recipient's own language.

She alone remembered the "jail birds" - boys, Russian or Polish especially, released from the camps in 1945, their families dead, homes destroyed, flung into grim postwar Germany to live on their wits. Some stole, others took vengeance, when chance came, on SS men. Many were executed by British and American courts; others were given life sentences in German prisons.

For lesser criminals, no provision was made for education, rehabilitation, help to employment on release, or even citizenship. Like so many, they landed on Ryder's lap. She got a little help from a very few Germans - notably in Hesse - and from the German Red Cross, but, generally, met obstruction from authority. She drove regularly to visit, in different prisons, men, now grown up, who had not seen a woman for years until she came and fought for them, appeared in court for them, and sought amnesties or jobs overseas.

I n 1959, she married Group Captain (later Lord) Leonard Cheshire, VC, a meeting and marriage of common dedication to suffering humanity. Working with them was Mother Teresa.

The two Cheshire children, Jeremy and Elizabeth, completed the happy family atmosphere at Cavendish. There was amazing normality and laughter there, although men and women lived (and died) there suffering from unique physical and nervous damage.

In her adolescence, Ryder was a typically fair English girl, with wavy hair and a small slender figure. Her frequent light smile was indescribable, flashing against grim backgrounds, illuminating her face, shadowed, when still, with her experience. When appealing for her survivors, she could look like the woman carrying the world's sorrows. Her brilliant blue, hooded eyes blazed from under striking eyebrows. By contrast, when she turned suddenly and lifted her daughter in her arms, her smile showed the natural joy that might have been hers completely, in a different world.

She was without fear, moral or physical, ate little, slept little, was completely indifferent to her own comfort and often looked exhausted, yet she seemed, borne on by some inner fire of strength. She dictated and signed innumerable letters, spoke at countless meetings, putting her "chains" on listeners to help her lastingly, appeared on radio and television, interviewed the press and always continued her personal role of "mamusia" - "mother" as the Poles called her - for each of her charges.

She was sometimes compared with Florence Nightingale. But from the Crimea onwards, Nightingale worked with government support. Ryder's people were her own - stateless, voteless, disabled, apparently useless. She knew better. In 1965, the Polish government awarded her the Officer's Cross of the Order of Polonia Restituta, one of their highest honours. Her own country took its time to create her a baroness; it came only in 1979.

Ryder had been ill since last year, and her last months were accompanied by disagreements over the policies of the Sue Ryder Fooundation. Last month, she set up a new charity, the Bouverie Foundation.

Her two autobiographical books were And The Morrow Is Theirs (1975) and Child Of My Love (1986, revised 1998). Her husband died in 1992, she is survived by her son and daughter.

webTitle: Time to find an exit from this daily ritual of suffering

fields.headline: Time to find an exit from this daily ritual of suffering
fields.standfirst:
Shimon Peres may provide a way out of the Middle East impasse
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Shimon Peres may provide a way out of the Middle East impasse
fields.body:
Shimon Peres is the last big card Israel had to play in the attempt to contain the fighting in the West Bank and Gaza. Because of his advocacy of peace in the past and because he stands above day to day politics, he has the weight to act as an envoy of last resort. So there is perhaps a chance that his intervention will succeed where the Sharm el-Sheikh agreement failed. It is not so much that Peres has a special relationship with Yasser Arafat or can bring arguments to bear that the Palestinian would not accept from anybody else.

This is not a matter of sentiment but of the fact that, if the Israelis and the Palestinians really want a way out, Peres could provide a label for it, allowing Arafat to meet some Israeli requirements without conceding anything directly to Ehud Barak, and Barak to redeploy some of his forces without this being seen as a huge victory for the Palestinians.

The daily suffering of both Israelis and Palestinians since this conflict ignited has not been of the same degree. The difference is that the Palestinians are suffering physically now, taking the bulk of the casualties and the physical damage to communities, yet imagine, as they have done before in times of violence and the elation violence sometimes brings, that a victory lies ahead. The Israelis have lost far fewer people, yet begin to perceive just how dangerous and dismal a future may lie before them.

For all that is written about how Israelis have never been free of their fears of Arab revenge, the clouds had begun to lift for them, and now have closed in again. The Israelis may speak of strong measures, but the reality is of conscript soldiers who, as time goes on, would start to fall to Palestinian fire, if never in the same numbers as their enemies but still in numbers intensely painful for a society that had begun to believe that all that was soon going to be over. The Palestinians may speak of fighting for as long as it takes to hoist their flag over Jerusalem, but must know that Israel has the means, both military and economic, to make life truly hellish in the territories, as opposed to merely nasty. They may feel, fecklessly or otherwise, that they can bear it, but would surely avoid if they could.

But not wanting war is not a sufficient condition for peace. If there is to be a change now, a shift away from fighting, it will be because lessons have been learned both from the failed diplomacy of the Oslo process and from the little war of the last six weeks. The lesson of the diplomacy is partly that leaders can confect arrangements that peoples will reject, but more specifically that Israel used its greater strength to try to impose terms too favourable to its interests.

At what point, if ever, it will begin to dawn on the majority of Israelis that the terms Ehud Barak offered at Camp David were not too generous, as they think at the moment, but not generous enough, is hard to know. But the lessons of the fighting are not irrelevant here, because as it has developed it has dramatised the issues that led to failure at Camp David. Palestinians confronted the Israeli presence in the territories by marching up to the camps and check points and stoning and shooting at them. They have gone on from that to make attacks on settlements and on the roads that sustain the settlements. And the fighting has, in some cases, come to the outskirts of East Jerusalem, and the violence, in the shape of bombers, to the heart of the city.

All this should be conveying to the Israelis that most of the settlements are not easily defended, that the military presence needed to sustain them is provocative, and that Jerusalem will be an endless cause of trouble unless it is fairly divided. Israelis may bitterly reflect that the degree of success of this new intifada owes much to the fact that they permitted the Palestinians to establish armed security forces but that, too, establishes a lesson.

Arafat's forces were designed, as the Israelis saw it, to protect Israel's security by keeping Palestinian extremists under control. But they could only fulfill that function if the Palestinians were on the road to a state worthy of the name.

A false symmetry often marks comment on the Middle East, distributing blame or assigning responsibilities to Israel and the Palestinians in equal measure. They are far from equal in strength, and they are not equally responsible. Much the greater responsibility rests with Israel. But there are also lessons for the Palestinians, whose ragged-trousered triumphalism seems sometimes to know no limits and whose emotional conformism produces a repetitive and extreme rhetoric from the lips of every single leader and spokesman. The idea is abroad in the Arab world that Israel is on the run - that it was pushed out of Lebanon and that it can be pushed out of other places, too. Countries can indeed be pushed - but they can only be pushed so far, as the Palestinians themselves have demonstrated.

Jews and Arabs have fought in these lands now for three generations. In the 30s, Arab rebels fired on Jewish settlements, and repeatedly blew up the main oil pipeline, while Jewish soldiers in Orde Wingate's night squads staged lethal ambushes as Arab fighters set off from their villages. Military force then, and for many years afterwards, was an instrument of absolute solutions. Now it is exhausted, on both sides, except as a means of demonstrating limits. Yet, if a ceasefire of some kind should take hold this week, or at some future point, it will not mean that the old peace process resumes, even if the meetings that President Clinton hopes to hold this month with the two leaders do take place. Violence at some level will probably continue. It may move off the streets, because Palestinians are surely getting sick of the daily slaughter, but there could be more occasional, targeted Palestinian attacks and Israeli responses to them, and a bad tempered low level diplomacy full of excuses and accusations going on alongside.

The likelihood is that there will be a clash over what should replace Oslo, with the Palestinians demanding that a range of countries other than the United States, as well as the United Nations, be brought in to help set up a new framework for negotiations. The Israelis will resist this in favour of an interim bilateral agreement of some kind with the Americans continuing as referees. This would be a separation without settlement and could involve both some Israeli withdrawals and a claimed or even an agreed statehood. Separation without settlement may seem the least bad course to many Israelis, and the best course to some leaders like Ariel Sharon, but in reality it would solve nothing. What was unacceptable to the Palestinians in a settlement would be equally unacceptable without one, and would be bound to lead to further violence.

fields.headline: Trainer banned for drink-driving
fields.trailText: The millionaire racehorse trainer Henry Cecil was yesterday banned from driving for five years and fined £3,000 after admitting knocking down two elderly pedestrians while more than twice over the drink driving limit.
fields.body:
The millionaire racehorse trainer Henry Cecil was yesterday banned from driving for five years and fined £3,000 after admitting knocking down two elderly pedestrians while more than twice over the drink driving limit.

Cambridgeshire magistrates heard how Cecil initially told police that a friend had been driving his blue Mercedes when it struck Len Hurrell, 78, and his wife Joan, 77, in Ashley on July 16.

But the Newmarket trainer confessed at the police station the following day that he had been behind the wheel. Mrs Hurrell suffered a broken arm and Mr Hurrell needed stitches after the accident, which happened after Cecil had been drinking during a lunch with a male friend and their children.

Magistrate Sue Thompson said he had shown "a complete disregard for the safety of other road users".

Cecil, 57, was told that his ban would be reduced by a quarter if he completed a drink-driving awareness course.

Earlier magistrates were told that the accident happened at a time when Cecil was due to return his six-year-old son, Jake, to his estranged wife Natalie, and was also struggling to come to terms with his twin brother David's terminal cancer.

Aidan Tevlin, for the prosecution, said that initially Cecil denied being the driver, claiming it was his friend, but police breathalysed him anyway.

He said: "His eyes were glazed and he was unsteady on his feet. After numerous attempts he was unable to provide a specimen of breath and was arrested, but once in the police car he did provide one."

The test result showed that Cecil had 88mg of alcohol in 100ml of breath. The legal limit is 35mg.

fields.headline: Tackling the peaks and troughs
fields.standfirst:
Profile: Plain speaker with a dislike for liberal views
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Sometime soon, Chris Woodhead will pack his ropes, his boots and his ice axe and head for the place he loves best, the mountains.
fields.body:
Sometime soon, Chris Woodhead will pack his ropes, his boots and his ice axe and head for the place he loves best, the mountains.

In the clear air of Snowdonia, or perhaps the Lake District, this keen climber will reflect on a career with more than its fair share of peaks, scrambles and plunges.

There will be few rank and file teachers who will be sad to see him spend more time in the hills but his strident views on old-fashioned educational standards will, no doubt, be missed by some parents and not a few politicians.

From day one, Mr Woodhead made it clear that he would be no friend of teachers. Indeed, even before taking up his new post he gave an interview to the Daily Mail spelling out his distaste for poor teachers. The headline read: Sack The Useless Teachers.

Since then, he has waged war not only on teachers who are not up to the job but also on those who espouse the liberal views which he despises.

Yet those outside the profession will probably remember Mr Woodhead not for his views but for his alleged affair with a sixth-former while teaching at the Gordano school in Portishead, near Bristol.

The scandal broke in February last year when he was asked about student-teacher relationships. His answer was curiously equivocal: "I don't think necessarily that a teacher should be automatically drummed out of the profession."

It was the sort of answer bound to intrigue. Five years earlier, the News of the World had carried a story alleging he had a sexual relationship with pupil Amanda Johnston. His solicitors had put out a statement claiming he did not have a "sexual relationship or any improper relationship" with her when he was a teacher and she a pupil, though they had a relationship "a long time afterwards" when separated from his wife, Cathy.

Mr Woodhead's ambiguous reply last year triggered further examination of the relationship. Amanda Johnston backed the chief inspector's version. But former colleagues emerged to cast doubt on his story.

His ex-wife Cathy claimed that her husband did have an affair with Amanda Johnston when she was a pupil and he a teacher. Mrs Woodhead claimed that he had told her about the affair in April 1976 when their daughter was 11 months old.

His first job was as an English teacher at Priory school, Shrewsbury. He taught in Gloucester and then became head of English at Gordano school.

But he was not content to stay in the classroom. He became a teacher trainer at Oxford, moved into officialdom and quickly moved through the ranks.

He has never been afraid of criticism, once saying: "You can no more do this job and be popular than you can climb a vertical cliff and relax and feel that everything is totally safe."

The big rows
Rebecca Smithers

Incompetent teachers

In 1994 Woodhead said there were 13,000 incompetent teachers. He readily backed the naming and shaming of underperforming schools and an increasing scrutiny of pupils' examination scores. In 1998 he infuriated teachers' leaders when he said that 15,000 members of the teaching profession were "incompetent" and directly responsible for undermining the "considerable improvement" in raising standards

Sex with pupils

In the spring of last year he announced that relationships between sixth-formers and teachers could be "experiential and educative" - at a time when the government was planning legislation to make such relationships illegal. His ex-wife subsequently claimed that his relationship with Amanda Johnston, a former pupil of his, had begun while she was still at school

Teachers' excuses

Last November he told MPs on the education select committee that teachers were prepared to blame anybody but themselves for pupils' poor performance. Teachers in a minority of schools had low expectations of their pupils and blamed everyone else for their lack of progress. "They blame the government for a lack of resources, they blame parents for not producing intelligent enough pupils, and they blame the collapse of western civilisation as we know it"

Vocational degrees

Last August he accused universities of offering "vacuous" courses, though he had no responsibility for higher education. He claimed universities were devaluing higher education by offering a "plethora of quasi-academic courses", citing examples such as media studies and beauty therapy

A-levels

In September, in an interview with the Guardian, he said A-levels did not challenge the brightest pupils, and should be made more difficult. While being questioned by MPs on the education select committee on Wednesday, he admitted there was no evidence to back up his claim

fields.standfirst:
A month ago the world's media descended on Belgrade to witness the bloody last stand of a defiant tyrant. But instead we were treated to the surreal sight of Slobodan Milosevic declaring his intention to spend more time with his family. Timothy Garton Ash on how TV - and a dash of old-fashioned conspiracy - toppled a dictator

Special report: Serbia
